PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent notice No. 3, private members' business, given for Wednesday, 25 March 1992, relating to a motion of censure of the Minister for Finance, being called on forthwith.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does this relate to the censure motion, notice No. 3?
—This is the censure motion which was gagged yesterday and which raises a matter of substance, for the information of the Leader of the House. It has now been gagged twice.

PARA.TAB: Mr Peacock interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the honourable member for Kooyong wants to interject from outside the members' area of the House, I will ask him to leave the House. He should have been here long enough to know not to do that.

PARA.TAB: Mr Carlton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable member for Mackellar continues to interject, I will deal with him also. Is there a seconder for the motion?
—I second the motion.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative, with an absolute majority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House censures the Minister for Finance for misleading the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek the support of honourable members in respect of a matter of very great significance. A censure motion which asserts that a Minister of the Crown has misled the Parliament is one of very great significance. It is a serious matter which goes very much to the heart of the democratic system and institutions in this country. To say that a Minister has misled the Parliament does raise issues, and such an assertion ought to be defended and responded to by the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), who so far in the last 24 hours has twice avoided a debate on this issue.

PARA.TAB: If Ministers are to be fully accountable, this Parliament must be fully informed. Regardless of politics, regardless of political views, all honourable members on both sides of this House have an interest to ensure that at all times the House is fully informed by Ministers. Without that, we have very little in this parliamentary institution.

This matter arises as a result of a question which was put to the Minister for Finance yesterday. The question related to advice which he had received from Treasury on the impact of the coalition's Fightback proposals. In his response, the Minister for Finance attempted to provide justification for the fact that on 16 December in a press conference he made certain claims about interest rates—claims which we now know were contradicted by advice given to the Minister in a minute from Treasury two weeks earlier. In other words, he was saying one thing publicly but being advised to the contrary by his very own Department.

Yesterday when the question was put to him during Question Time he basically fumbled the ball and we had an embarrassed Minister unable to explain the discrepancy between what he had been saying in public and the advice that he had been receiving in private. So it was that he struggled to explain this difference. Realising the struggle that he had encountered during Question Time, he obviously went back to his office, and his advisers told him that he was in hot water. Their advice to him was that he ought to go back into the Parliament to explain himself. That, of course, is a practice which many of us have seen over the years: if you make a mistake, you go back to your office, your advisers tell you the mistake that you have made and the advice will be, `Go back into the Parliament and correct the record so that the House is fully informed'.

The Minister went back to his office, sat down at about 3 o'clock when Question Time finished and for 2 1/2 hours received a full briefing on this issue from his Department. He then came back into the Parliament to explain the reason why what he had said publicly was different from the advice that he had received privately. When he responded at half past five, the Minister clearly misled the Parliament. He said that the reason for the discrepancy between what he had been saying publicly and the advice he had been receiving privately was that at the time of Treasury's advice on 2 December—and I will quote from what he said yesterday at 5.30—it `did not have available to it its own analysis of the revenue side of the Fightback package'.

That is just plain wrong. That is wrong on the face of it, and I will demonstrate that absolutely beyond doubt. If the jury in here is not certain, I can assure you that the jury out there will be—overwhelmingly so. He went back to his office, he came into the Parliament and he misled the Parliament about the state of advice and the advice that Treasury had available to it as at 2 December.

The charge goes to three matters. Firstly, the Minister said that Treasury did not have an expenditure analysis as at 2 December; it clearly did. Secondly, he said that as at 2 December it did not have a revenue analysis; it clearly did. Thirdly, he repeated the misrepresentations he made in a press conference on 16 December about this very issue and, thereby, misled the Parliament. Not only had he misled the Australian people back in December; he compounded his misleading of the Australian people by coming in here and reaffirming to the Parliament the very misleading statements that he had made at that time.

Mr Speaker, let me take you specifically to the words of the Minister yesterday in the Parliament which go to the heart of the issues that we are raising. By way of a response and in an attempt to clean up his embarrassed answer at Question Time—and I want to put some of this on the record so that the matter is absolutely beyond doubt—he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The whole point of the comments that I made in the press conference of 16 December was that that assumption was not one which the Government shared. It did not believe that it was a realistic assumption. The Government believed that, if the GST were introduced, there would then be a flow on of further wage increases, particularly in the context of there not having been adequate compensation paid to wage and salary earners.

I pause there for a moment. One of the reasons that the Minister puts to the House for the difference between what he says publicly and what he has been advised privately goes to the question of wages assumption. We are happy to have that debate and we appreciate that it is a matter of debate and argument. He then went on to substantiate further the reasons for the difference. He said:
The other point that should be mentioned in this context is that at the time Treasury did this modelling . . .
I pause there. This is the modelling which provided the basis of a minute of advice to the Treasurer and to the Government on 2 December. So at that time he said:
. . . it did not have available to it its own analysis of the revenue side of the Fightback package; nor. . . the finance modelling of the expenditure side of the package.

On both of those matters, Minister, you have misled the Parliament in the most open and shut, black and white, clearest case possible. Let me take you specifically to the minutes which you tabled on 3 March in this Parliament in a debate in which you participated. I know you were swamped with pieces of paper and that maybe you had not read the minute, but there is absolutely no excuse for you, Minister. You participated in the debate just a few short weeks ago in which the two documents which we today rely upon revealed that the Treasury had this analysis prior to 2 December.

PARA.TAB: It is nonsense for the Minister to make a claim to the contrary, as he attempted to do yesterday. He claimed that on 2 December Treasury did not have the expenditure side analysis available. I take the Minister to document No. 27 tabled in the Parliament on 3 March, headed `Costings of Outlays Measures'. The Minister says that the Treasury has done no modelling of the expenditure side; yet he received a minute dated 26 November, a week or so before 2 December, which shows that Treasury has not just had a cursory look at the expenditure side, but it has done it to the nth degree.

As the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) says, the document is dated November, before 2 December. Treasury did not take a quick look at the expenditure side. The document is not flimsy or superficial; it is about 170 pages, would you believe. The Minister said, `We did not have anything on 2 December'.

For heavens sake, the Government could hardly get out of its offices for the paper which had come across from Treasury explaining and detailing each and every aspect of the expenditure side of Fightback. For those who are in any doubt, Table 1 is headed `Outlined Savings in Standard Cumulative Format' and goes on for pages and pages—170 pages. This document that the Minister says does not exist, and did not exist on 2 December, has 170 pages. As I say, the document is not superficial. The health portfolio has been gone over in the most minute detail on pages 263 and 264. There is also page after page on industrial relations, immigration, industry and commerce.

After the tables we have a description blow by blow, line by line, of the totality of the coalition's expenditure package, and the Minister told us yesterday that Treasury did not have available to it modelling of the expenditure side. It has never had so much modelling. There is more modelling than you have had hot Sunday dinners—page after page on government advertising and promotional expenditure, political grants, ministerial councils, reducing expenditure on CDEs, ATSIC, enterprise programs, cultural heritage programs and communications. Do I need to go on?

This Parliament yesterday was misled in the clearest case of misleading the Parliament we could possibly ever get. The truth is that the Minister had that advice. He cannot stand here and say that Treasury did not have it on 2 December; it had it in spades to the umpteenth degree. The expenditure side is charge No. 1 and, on that charge alone, he is clearly guilty.
I will now refer to charge No. 2. I will take honourable members back to what the Minister said yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . at the time Treasury did this modelling it did not have available to it its own analysis of the revenue side of the Fightback package. . .

The minute to the Minister is dated 2 December. We find in the documents, contrary to the Minister's assertion that there was nothing, that days and days before 2 December Treasury had another minute on the revenue side. Let me take the Minister to the document—document No. 25, tabled in the Parliament in the debate in which the Minister participated. It is dated 27 November, nearly a week before he reckons Treasury had nothing. It is headed `Opposition Tax and Expenditure Document—Changes in Indirect Taxation'. Again, this is not some superficial, quick, cursory glance at the issues.

PARA.TAB: Page 4, attachment 5, has the heading `Difference in Revenue Estimates for the GST'. It also has a heading about the black economy. In fact, it has all of the substantial issues which formed the basis of the Minister's press release of 16 December which claimed this fictitious hole of $3.9 billion. For the Minister to stand in the Parliament and say that Treasury had nothing on the revenue side as at 2 December is patently and clearly an open and shut case. It did have.

It is not just in that minute. You can go to some of these other minutes which, again, pre-date 2 December. They give a detailed analysis of things like capital gains tax and there are pages and pages on superannuation which goes to the revenue side. How can the Minister stand in the Parliament and say that Treasury did not have it when just a couple of weeks ago he tabled the documents which showed that it did have it? It is as clear as day; it could not be clearer.

Charge No. 1: the Minister said that as at 2 December Treasury had nothing on the expenditure side; but it had 170 pages. Charge No. 2: he said that Treasury had nothing on the revenue side; yet it had an 18-page document dated 27 November, which is a clear exposition of Treasury's views in respect of the revenue side. So on charge No. 2 the Minister is guilty. It is as clear as day; it could not be clearer. It is just amazing that he could go back to his office, receive that advice and then come in here and say exactly the opposite.

Charge No. 3 goes to the Minister's re-affirmation of the misleading comments he made in a press conference on 16 December. He was caught absolutely red-handed on two issues. I rely upon only two issues today. I take you to page 2 of the transcript of that press conference. It was very hard to get this transcript, by the way. It went on walkabout yesterday. It is just amazing how pieces of paper get lost, is it not? The transcript reads:

SPEECH.PARA: JOURNALIST: You basically argued today about the macro economic impact of the Opposition's package. Is the Treasury also going to model how it assumes that package would affect the economy?
WILLIS: I have not asked it to do so, nor am I aware that my predecessor has asked for that to be done.

JOURNALIST: Don't you think that's fairly worthwhile? I mean, the issue is starting to revolve around how many jobs there are, what. . . interest rates. And, at the moment all we've got is the claims and counterclaims between you and the Opposition.

WILLIS: I'd be quite happy for them to do that. . . it's quite clear, on the basis of what we now know, indeed, it was clear even on the Opposition's own figures. . . that the proposals from the Opposition must involve a large increase in interest rates in year 2. . .

The Minister said, `I have not asked them to do so, nor do I believe that my predecessor has asked them to do so'. For heaven's sake, Minister, if you read the minute dated 2 December—two weeks before that press conference—you will see that it starts with the words, `as requested'. He says, `I haven't asked them to do so and I don't think anybody else has asked them to do so'. Yet we have a minute that you tabled—you participated in the debate—which says, `as requested'. It has both the modelling and the macro impact. The second point I pick up on in respect of 16 December is this little exchange:

JOURNALIST: Mr Willis, that's just your assertion. Couldn't you give us some idea, or couldn't you ask your Department, what they think would happen to macro policy? What would happen to interest rates?
WILLIS: Well, I'm quite certain what the advice would be.
JOURNALIST: Do you know that. I mean, have they told you?
WILLIS: No, I've not had a detailed economic discussion with my Department about this matter.

I do not know what the nature of his discussions might have been with the Department, but he did not just have a discussion with it, he had a minute from it. He sat there in a press conference and said, `I am quite certain what the advice would be'. That is not bad. The advice was that, under us, interest rates would go down and he was deliberately attempting to create the impression that the advice would be that interest rates would go up.

PARA.TAB: You have been caught out, Minister. That was a clear misrepresentation. Yet yesterday you came into the Parliament and misled the Parliament by reaffirming that misrepresentation. You have been caught out misleading the Parliament.

Mr Speaker, there are a lot of other matters that flow from this Minister's duplicity on this issue, but for the case that this Minister has misled the Parliament I rely on the documents which, on the face of them, make this matter beyond doubt. The Minister claimed that on 2 December Treasury did not have an analysis of both the revenue side and the expenditure side. The truth is that Treasury did, and you provided us with the documents that show that. In fact, the documents show that it had had that material for about a week at least prior to 2 December.

I do not know what your response will be, Minister. You have already said, `Well, you know, we were all playing musical chairs at the time'. But you are not going to rely upon that fact, nor should you, because you have a responsibility to the public at large and, regardless of the musical chairs going on at the time, the fact is that you were in this debate on 3 March at which time these documents were tabled. Yesterday you went back to your office and you must have received a full briefing on this matter. You then came into the Parliament and misled the Parliament, and that goes to the heart of our system. You have an obligation to tell the truth in this place so that we can have a fully informed debate.

It is interesting that you have never denied one simple fact, which is the political end of this, and that is that interest rates under us will fall. That is the advice you have had and that is an objective assessment which you have received from your Department which you have not yet contradicted.

You have been playing games with this. This is a good policy move—the GST and Fightback—and you yourself supported it some years ago. I think you do this Parliament a great disservice when you play silly political games, when you mislead this Parliament. You deserve to be censured for misleading the Parliament. I urge the support of all honourable members for this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Resign!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will be heard in silence.

—Let me say at the outset that there is no charge to answer in respect of this motion. The Opposition engaged in a scurrilous exercise in trying to make something out of an issue which it knows to be a non-issue. Honourable members opposite are desperate to try to retain some credibility in regard to their Fightback package, knowing that that package is vulnerable on a host of fronts including, of course, not only the fact that there is a $4 billion hole in it which they have never been able to make any response to, but also because its implications for monetary policy are indeed severe.

PARA.TAB: The basis of the allegation against me is that the Opposition has a Treasury document dated 2 December which produces the results of an analysis of the key elements of the tax switch and government expenditure elements of the Opposition package using the Access Economics Murphy model, assuming that the Opposition's claims about wage behaviour under such a package were correct. It was asked to do that. That was the request: to do it on the basis that the Opposition's assumptions about wage behaviour under the package were correct.

That was a request made for a particular purpose, but it was certainly not an indication of the Government's belief that that was the likely wages behaviour that would come with the introduction of such a package; nor do the results indicate in any way that this is the Treasury's belief. They do not indicate in any way that this is the Treasury's belief. All that Treasury did, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) said, was `as requested, we have done this work'—

TALK.START.PARA: —From you.
—Not by me—by Treasurer Kerin.
—You didn't know that?
—It is just an historical fact. It was done when Treasurer Kerin was in office.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition was heard in silence. He has moved a censure motion on the Minister. The Minister should be allowed to respond without interjection.

—This minute was requested to be produced on a basis which assumed that the Opposition's wages policy approach was correct. The document of 2 December reported those results. As I have said, they in no way represent either the Government's view of what wages behaviour would be under such an approach as the Opposition's Fightback policy, nor do they indicate in any way that Treasury believes that. Treasury simply did what it was requested to do. When it did that exercise it produced the outcome which showed that there were interest rate falls for a couple of years and then some subsequent increases. But essentially that is an irrelevancy in terms of how we would expect the package to eventuate, because the wages outcome is simply going to be very different from that. Let me make it quite clear what Treasury was actually doing. It said in its document:

SPEECH.PARA: As requested, we have attempted to simulate the main components . . . the monetary policy has been set to allow a one off increase in consumer price inflation of around 5 per cent . . . No direct wage flow-ons are allowed:

PARA.TAB: these monetary policy and wage assumptions are critical in the simulations—ie the results (especially in the short-run) are sensitive to the assumed behaviour of monetary policy and wage outcomes:

SPEECH.PARA: But the assumption that Treasury was making was an assumption it was asked to make. In respect of further detail on that, Treasury said on page 2 of attachment A:
Adjustments were made to the wage equation residuals in order to discount wage increases for the direct inflationary impact of the GST.

In other words, Treasury is saying that when it did this model and put it through the Murphy model, it was throwing up higher wage increases as a result of this 5 per cent impact from the GST. Once it saw them it said, `That is not allowed'. It went back into the model and took those wage increases out because they are not allowed under the assumption.

PARA.TAB: So what sort of analysis is that? What are those opposite making out of this? Is it that it is the Murphy model pure and simple? It is not, obviously, because the Murphy model was throwing up wage increases that the Treasury went back to and took out as the assumptions on which it was asked to make the analysis did not allow for them.So one could not say one could not have under that type of analysis further wage increases and higher levels of inflation, which of course would have great implications for the macro-economic policy stance.

There is no doubt that the basis upon which this modelling was done was the basis upon which the Opposition's assumptions were assumed to be correct in relation to wage behaviour and inflation. That is not an assumption that the Treasury shares. There is certainly no evidence in this document that that is what the Treasury believes, nor is there any belief by the Government that that would be the case.

In relation to actual wage behaviour, what could we really expect? Surely we could expect that we would get much different wage behaviour from that which is assumed in this document. The Murphy model itself was throwing up higher wage increases, which were then taken out. The ACTU has said that, as a result of this package, there would be additional wage claims. A total of 70 per cent of wage and salary earners have been shown by the Treasury analysis to be worse off. Is it expected that they are not going to make additional wage claims?

The whole assumption that the Treasury document of 2 December represents some kind of credo which the Government is locked into, and that anything we say in contradiction to that is evidence of duplicity on my part or the Government's part, is a complete and utter nonsense, a complete and utter fabrication. It is simply an analysis, a piece of advice, based on certain assumptions which Treasury was asked to use. It was asked to give us an analysis based on those assumptions. They are obviously assumptions which would not be borne out in reality.

There is no way in which I or the Government would accept that the Treasury document of 2 December represents a pure analysis of the Fightback package and the results that it is likely to achieve. On the face of it, it is not a pure analysis, because Treasury went back to the model and threw out the bits that did not accord with the Opposition's assumptions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is just playing with words.

—Who has been playing with words? The other element concerns the fiscal policy stance. The Opposition is saying that the approach we have taken in respect of that is not in accord with the advice. In fact Treasury, in undertaking this analysis, made it clear that in respect of its fiscal policy analysis it assumed a $1.3 billion reduction in government expenditure in net terms for each of three years. In other words, it would happen in a balanced way over that three-year period. That is not what the Fightback package proposes. It proposes substantial cuts in the first year. It proposes cuts in expenditure, in net terms, of $3.2 billion in year one, growing to $4.5 billion in year two and falling in year three.

PARA.TAB: The Treasury assumed that the Opposition's figuring of $4 billion net reduction in government expenditure would apply. But the analysis done by Finance indicated that there would be no such reductions; that there would be a $2.6 billion hole. Instead of there being over $4 billion in savings, the figure would be more like $1.7 billion. It was $2.6 billion short. So the assumption on which the fiscal policy modelling was undertaken by Treasury, as reported on 2 December, was not in accord with the package, either as proposed by the Opposition or as, in fact, it would have been if proper costings had been done—as they were done by Finance.

There would not be a $1.3 billion reduction in government expenditure for each of the three years. On the basis of the figures we only ever get a figure of $1.9 billion, and that is in year two. That figure is cumulative. In year three the amount drops back. We never get anywhere near $4 billion in savings. So the fiscal policy assumptions in this modelling are totally out of line with the assumptions which the Opposition made in its package and what they would have been if the Opposition had done proper costings, as Finance did. In regard to both wages policy and fiscal policy, the whole analysis proceeded on a basis not in accord with the reality of the Fightback package. There is no doubt that the package, as modelled, simply does not represent a package analysis which accords with reality.

Let me make a couple more points quickly about what the Opposition is saying in this respect. Honourable members opposite seem very anxious to embrace this Treasury document because they see some advantage on the interest rate side of things. The document says that interest rates would go down for a year or two—even though, of course, that Treasury analysis is patently inappropriate in terms of how the package would operate. If honourable members want to be tied to that package, what about some of the other aspects of it? If honourable members opposite want to grab hold of the interest rate side and say that that is really important and that they should adhere to that because that was their advice, what about the rest of it? What about the employment side? Did honourable members look at that? What that shows is that their two million jobs—

TALK.START.PARA: —Two billion.

—It might as well be two billion, the way Opposition members rave on about it. Do honourable members know what the long run increase in employment is? It is not two million jobs, not one million jobs, not 100,000 jobs, not 10,000 jobs, but no jobs—none. There would be no increase whatever in the long run.

PARA.TAB: If you want to embrace that analysis, you can embrace the rest of it, which shows no jobs. What do you say about this pack of lies which you are telling the Australian people in the Fightback! document which has been circulated? Spread all over it, in every part, is `two million jobs' and `GST equals two million more jobs'. It is at every point of this document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Yesterday, while you were in the chair you made great play about references to deliberate dishonesties. You forced me to withdraw words to that effect, yet you allow an allegation of a pack of lies to go unrebuked. You should get him to withdraw it and not have double standards in this House.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—The honourable member for Bennelong will not reflect upon the Chair. The Minister was using it as a generality rather than in a specific sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the Opposition's sensitivity because it is sending this pamphlet around the whole of Australia telling people that the Fightback analysis produces two million jobs; for example, `GST = two million more jobs'. Where does that come from? You want to embrace that Treasury analysis, but it is not two million jobs, it is no jobs—not any in the long term, in that 10-year timeframe. The analysis shows that job increases reach 30,000 or 40,000 in about year five but then drop back to zero. So, do not tell us that there will be two million more jobs. In so far as the two million more jobs has any basis at all, as you know, it comes from the application of the Murphy model, which does not include the GST; it is not even there. Your whole argument about two million jobs, which you are trying to tell the Australian people your Fightback package would produce, is based on an analysis which does not even include the GST.

PARA.TAB: Yet this package says, `GST equals two million more jobs created by abolishing seven unfair taxes'. However, it does not abolish any taxes along with providing the two million additional jobs; the analysis does not include the whole of the GST. You are telling blatant fibs to the whole Australian populace in saying that this is the case. It is a complete misrepresentation. For you to come in here and suggest that I am misleading the Australian people is just a nonsense. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), who is subject to a censure motion here today, has had 15 minutes to respond to that censure motion for misleading the House. In that 15 minutes, he has not once addressed the issue of the misrepresentation. In fact, he did not even allude to it once.

PARA.TAB: What is more, he has compounded the problem by misleading the House yet again, this time on the issue of advice he received when he was the Treasurer and his predecessor received when he was Treasurer—it is hard to keep track of who the Treasurer has been under the Labor Party during the last year, but I am referring to the two former Treasurers—from the Treasury on the issue of wages. In a moment I will point out how he has misled the House.

By the way, the Minister has also completely contradicted what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said back in 1977 when he was in the Opposition calling, honourable members might like to recall, for the abolition of the payroll tax and claiming that if the Fraser Government abolished payroll tax it would create what—no jobs; is that right? No, when the Labor Party was calling for it it was going to create 200,000 jobs. Now, apparently, it will not have any effect at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could do that at a dog show.
—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory should remain silent.

PARA.TAB: Mr Snowdon interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory will restrain himself.

—I am concerned about the honourable member for the Northern Territory. He is getting a little overexcited, and I wonder why. The point that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) made is the point we need to focus on here; that is, that the Minister for Finance misled the House yesterday when he came into the House at 5.30 p.m. or so to make a statement. SPEECH.PARA: The other point that should be mentioned in this context is that at the time Treasury did this modelling—
we are referring to the 2 December minute—
it did not have available to it its own analysis of the revenue side of the package; nor . . . the finance modelling—
that means the Finance Department's modelling, presumably—
of the expenditure side of the package.

Did you say that, or did you not? Did you? You did. Of course you said that. The whole point that we are making is that you claimed that the Treasury did not have that information available to it—that is what you said yesterday; but it did. And you did not address that issue. You spent 15 minutes on the sanctimonious, self-righteous criticism of Fightback that we get from the Labor Party now, which I must admit could be described only as risible. In that 15 minutes you did not once address the issue of this censure motion—and I must admit there it is a question of relevance. In other words, did you or did you not, or did the Treasurer or did the Treasurer not, at the time of 2 December have that analysis from the Treasury and the Department of Finance?

PARA.TAB: You said yesterday that they did not have it. Is that true? The answer is that it is not true. As the shadow Treasurer, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, pointed out, on 26 November the Treasurer had received the costings of outlays by the Treasury—170 pages of analysis. You said yesterday that the Treasurer had not received that by 2 December. That is what you said. You are wrong. On 27 November the Treasurer received the revenue estimates, document 25, `Opposition tax and expenditure document: changes in direct taxation'. There it all is—the revenue estimates. But you said that you did not receive those.

I must say that any reasonable minded person in this debate who would vote on the basis of conscience and reasonable human behaviour would censure you. You are hanged by your own words—or lack of words—at the dispatch box here because not once did you address that question.

The interesting thing is that you actually compounded your problem. You compounded your problem by going on further to mislead the House. This is the whole strategy. It does not matter what the documents say; it does not matter what the facts are: you just rush out into the community and say anything, hoping that you will convince the Australian public. Truth plays no part in the modern Labor Party's campaign. People like Curtin and Chifley would turn in their graves watching you people and your disgraceful lack of integrity.

PARA.TAB: The Minister's whole effort here today, as well yesterday evening, is misleading. I suppose that, because of the whole of the Labor Party's approach, we should not be surprised. Another one of the Labor members who are part of this approach is walking into the House now. That approach is to run a scare campaign out in the community of the most childish but perhaps traditional type, to make a whole range of claims, not based on fact but based on the wild hope that people will accept them.

Let us take this claim that there will be a wages blow-out. The Government's distributional analysis claims there will be a wages blow-out in the community if the coalition's Fightback package is introduced. You say that all these people are going to be worse off, the sky is going to fall in and so on. That is all built on some assumptions. That is not a wages blow-out. You assume the worst possible outcome in terms of wages and of course some extraordinary and inflated figure in terms of inflation during that period, which bears no relationship whatsoever to the inflation assumptions that are used in the same years in your One Nation package.

You just hid it like a little boy hiding his toys under his bed. Is that what the Treasury says in its documents? Its documents say that farmers' costs under the Fightback package will be reduced by over $1 billion, that is, by $8,000 per farm. That is not the same thing as 80 per cent of farmers being worse off.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the distributional impact?

PARA.TAB: It is sad that we have a Treasurer who relies not on reasoned argument in answering but on abuse of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith)—the louder the more effective. He has said things such as, `the Deputy has no scruples'—people in glass houses should not throw stones—`the shadow Treasurer is the bovver boy of the Opposition' and so on.

The style of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) is quite different; but he is still wrong. Therefore, I want to turn to the central point of this censure motion. That is, that the way this matter has been handled by the Minister for Finance at his press conference on 16 December, at Question Time yesterday and then later in the afternoon has led to the impression being created in this Parliament and outside it that the Treasury itself, just like the Government, was of the view that the Fightback package, on its own assumptions, was wrong. Yet the Treasury clearly says that it is not, and that is the central point I want to stress.

I say again: the impression has been created that Treasury says that the Fightback package is wrong and misleading on its assumptions. That is wrong. The Treasury did not say that. The Treasury modelled the expenditure and revenue effects of our package—not the whole package, which is very important in relation to a point I want to make in a moment when I come to jobs—and confirmed the Fightback conclusions that there would be a fall in interest rates in the period of the Hewson government's programs, as assuredly there will be.

It is true that, when the Treasury was doing that, the model threw up a wage increase, which it subsequently explicitly took out in order to model the Fightback package. It threw it up because that is a model based on years of past experience. It should have been trying to model something which is always a once over, whenever it occurs. Whenever a goods and services tax is introduced to replace a large swag of income tax, that is a once over; it only happens once. So there is no model based on past experience—a Murphy model or any other. We have to put that expected outcome—that with the once over increase there will be no boost to subsequent inflation—explicitly into the calculation, which is what the Treasury did. When Treasury did it the answer was, `There will in fact be, as we, the coalition, claim, a fall in interest rates in that period'. That is an outcome which the Minister for Finance, in his speech, said he believed the Treasury would not share.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasury says it exists.

—As my colleague said, it is very likely that the Treasury does share it, and not only the Treasury. I quote from a major study that was undertaken at the time of the 1985 draft White Paper when government members—and in particular the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—were fostering a goods and services tax. That study was conducted by the Fiscal Affairs Department of the International Monetary Fund. The Hawke Government at that time noted:

PARA.TAB: The study covered 31 cases of the introduction of a Value Added Tax (VAT) concluding that only in four of them could the VAT have contributed to an increase in the rate of inflation; in each of those cases the changes were associated with expansionary wage and credit policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, that will not be so in our case. The quote continues:
In general, even where there was a lift in the level of the CPI, there was no continuing effect on the rate of inflation.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that the circumstances in which Australian reform is being developed would, in comparison with the international experience, maximise the possibilities for confining price effects to an initial change in levels.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the position. There was no way that the model used would not throw up some wage increases, as the Minister for Finance said, but it could not possibly do otherwise. It could not be modelling the circumstances of the Opposition's case . Were there time, I would like to enlarge on the circumstances in which the Opposition will be introducing the goods and services tax. Let us look at our account of the sequence of the implementation of our program. In a situation where everybody, including all taxpayers, will be adequately compensated, action in pursuit of wage increases merely in response to that initial price increase would indeed amount to an irresponsible industrial action. There are very good reasons, therefore, why we believe that this will be a once over effect. When you put that into the modelling, the Fightback conclusions are justified.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Finance also referred to the Treasury's expenditure and revenue estimates which were in fact available by 2 December. They were out in the public domain in December, we were debating them in various forums around the country. The Treasury analysis was widely known and was supposed to show a $4 billion hole: we had overestimated revenue, Treasury said, by about $1.2 billion and we had overestimated what we would achieve in expenditure cuts by about $2.7 billion. That is the $4 billion hole. In all cases, in the estimates which the Treasury came up with there were either differences in assumption, or they were based on assumptions which were just plain wrong. I expanded on that in my speech in the last week of sitting. Some honourable members might care to have a look at that. The Australian Financial Review, when discussing them, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department's analysis did not reveal any errors of the kind which have destroyed the credibility of policies in the past.

It still has not destroyed the credibility of those policies. The $4 billion hole is a figment of the Government's imagination. Honourable members should look at the 170 pages of analysis that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition referred to and make up their own minds who is right. They can feed in different assumptions. We feed in, for instance, that when bulkbilling is ended there will be a very significant reduction in the overuse of medical services; they feed in a reduction of only about 2 per cent. Honourable members can make up their own minds. I invite the Australian people to make up their own minds. There is no such hole on the revenue side. The $1 billion difference is nearly all attributable to simply ignoring the black economy and not coming up with a different estimate. In the passage that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition referred to concerning the black economy, they say, `It is unknowable. We will put in no figure'. Because one is trying to measure the immeasurable, that is no reason for ignoring the best efforts of authorities in the past, including government departments and the Treasury, to try to arrive at an estimate. But the estimate we put in, which virtually makes up that difference in the revenue estimate, is a very reasonable one.

TALK.START.PARA: —A conservative figure.
—In fact, it is very conservative; it is very modest, as my colleague says.

The fact is that the Treasury, referring to the simulations, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The simulations are based on our best attempts to use AEM to model the tax expenditure measures contained in the Opposition's package. The Opposition's material does not attempt to model this type of package using AEM. Rather, scenario C'—
which is not precisely a model of, but its best exposition of, what the Fightback package will achieve—
essentially drives off the assumption that micro economic reform (including the efficiency effects of tax reform) adds 0.4 percentage points to labour productivity. . .

And they are not going to take that into account. So the model you have got here is modelling one aspect of reality, namely, the expenditure and revenue effects, and the model in scenario C is modelling another aspect, namely, taking into account that which is central to the Fightback package, namely, the total program of fundamental structural and taxation change in land and sea transport, on the wharves, electricity pricing, communications and so on, and the potential for the extension of that to the private sector, to the achievement of best international practice in every corner of the nation. That is the central feature around which the Fightback package revolves. When you model that in, you get the sort of employment outcome of scenario C, and that employment outcome is the increase in jobs of the order of two million by the turn of the century.
