PARA.TAB: This debate arises out of two central problems for the Liberal Party and the coalition. One is long term and one is one which they have immediately had to confront following an embarrassing statement made by the Opposition spokesman for Treasury matters to Laura Tingle. That I will deal with in a minute.

The first one comes from the fact that they have attempted to devise a total picture of their economic policy, their propositions for the reform and reconstruction of this country, around a 15 per cent goods and services tax. There is no country on earth which has introduced a goods and services tax on the basis that by doing so it is going to improve the productivity of the economy. That has not been the reason why countries have introduced a goods and services tax. They have introduced it sometimes to pay for heinous agricultural subsidies, which tends to be the case of the value added taxes that operate in Europe. The Opposition has introduced this as a revenue raising measure for general government outlays—one good way governments of the day think of getting into the pockets of the taxpayers. But nobody has ever seriously suggested until now that a goods and services tax, which fundamentally operates on the assumption that every time you add value to an article you will be taxed for doing so and you will scramble to grab that tax back from the next person who adds further value to that until it finally arrives in the hands of the consumer who actually ends up paying the tax plus an increase in price along the way which impacts on the inflation rate, actually constitutes an act that is aimed directly at improving the productivity of the economy. It is a novel theory, but it is an extraordinarily difficult one to explain to the electorate because most reasonable people cannot see that outcome. That is the central difficulty of the Liberal Party. Its members impose upon that all sorts of other objectives such as their objective which was arrived at not under any assumptions about the likely impact of the goods and services tax on the economy but by the operations of another series of their prejudices, and the Reserve Bank will be tasked to arrive at a 0 to 2 per cent inflation rate and rendered independent of government so that that will be its principle charge, not the maintenance of full employment—we will drop that from the Reserve Bank's charge. The Reserve Bank simply will be obliged to retain a 0 to 2 per cent inflation rate. They keep reiterating that. Of course, the consequences of that in the sort of environment they are talking about here would be devastating.

The substance of the attack by members of the Opposition on the Finance Minister in this particular exercise goes to a suggestion that, in stating that the inevitable impact of Opposition policy would be an increase in interest rates, he was in some way misleading the House. That is the central feature of their attack. What they base that charge on is a Treasury document that we tabled here in this place which is supposed to demonstrate that, in coming forward and saying that there would be an interest rate impact from this, he was speaking outside the material that was available to him. What does this Treasury document say? It is headed `Macroeconomic implications of a change in the tax mix : AEM model simulations'. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: In interpreting these simulations, the following provisos should be borne in mind.
It goes through a series of them and it comes to this:
Monetary policy has been set to allow a one off increase in consumer price inflation of around 5 per cent in the year of implementation of GST. No direct wage flow-ons are allowed:
-these monetary policy and wage assumptions are critical in the simulations—ie the results (especially in the short run) are sensitive to the assumed behaviour of monetary policy and wage outcomes.

I would think that the Finance Minister, or Treasurer as he was at the time, in making some sort of statement of what he thought the overall impact of the package was going to be on the inflation rate, is entitled to step aside from a simple simulation of the Opposition's model. All Treasury did was effectively replicate the Opposition's position as far as that was concerned. He was entitled to do that, and include all the other factors that Treasury had made in its interpretation of what the actual impact of a goods and services tax would be on his assessments of whether or not interest rates would rise. Indeed, the fellow who provided that model—Murphy—does himself indicate to us what would be the impact if the wages assumptions referred to there as kept out of it were in fact played into it, and what he says is this, `Unemployment rises sharply to be 2.1 per cent above a baseline after five years. This is partly due to the increase in real wages. Consumer after tax real wages are up 2.6 per cent by the end of the first year and producer real wages would be up by a similar margin. The other factor is the de facto tightening of monetary policy which sees the 90-day bill rate rise 2.3 percentage points per annum above the base line by the end of the second year'.

PARA.TAB: That is Murphy's own figuring of his own model if you actually include in it the sorts of wages assumptions that the Treasury would subsequently include in it were it to make a real life assessment of what the particular outcome would be as opposed to simply that model. Indeed, Murphy provides it with advice on that himself; that is to say, `Well, expect the rates to rise 2.3 per cent'. He also makes other interesting implications on employment which I will get to.

The fact is that, irrespective of whether Treasury had available to it at the time its own assessments of the holes in the Opposition's GST and whether it sought to put that into the package, it chose not to do so for this particular paper. There is no element in the assessment by Treasury or Finance—on their own estimates—of the Opposition's package, the impact of the GST, that there is effectively a $4 billion hole. It chose not to include that in the way in which it treated the Opposition position.

Furthermore, Treasury accepted at face value in that particular exercise the Opposition's view that there would be an even spread of the impact of cuts and increases in expenditure over the four-year period, and not the front-end loaded way that was revealed when Treasury subsequently produced documents on the impact of the Opposition's proposition. So in fact the Treasury in that particular document was dealing with unreality—unreality in terms of the operation of the Australian economy overall but, above all, unreality on any reasonable assessment of what Opposition policy actually was, and unreality in terms of its own assessment of what Opposition policy means.

But, if the Opposition really wants to hang that particular model around its neck, I point out that there is an interesting feature of this particular piece of unreality, which is that it is assumed that, with the operation of this particular model, there would be no increase in employment—none. If members of the Opposition really want to take the totality of this picture around their necks as their proposition, then the estimate as far as employment is concerned is that there would be no increase in employment—not the two million that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has been touting about the country. But, if this particular model were to actually be applied, and if this were the outcome, then we would have two million jobs less from the point at which the Leader of the Opposition predicted we would be. Indeed, that is one of the most farcical elements of the Opposition's position as far as the goods and services tax is concerned.

When the great scenario C for the GST was announced by the Leader of the Opposition, almost sotto voce, sort of mumbling under his coat, it boiled down to the good doctor saying to us all, `Well, I hate to say this to you all, but scenario C does not in fact include any modelling for the operation of a goods and services tax. But don't worry about it because everything else that goes into making up scenario C we will actually put in place'. What a ridiculous position to finally arrive at!

You are throwing this mad, massive dead cat into the middle of the Australian economy, and then you produce a set of flowery assumptions about what its impact will be! Then you have to confess at the end that the stinking dead cat in the middle of the road actually is unrelated to the flowers on either side of it, but it is essentially related to what it is that you intend to do. What you intend to do is to scoop up that dead cat and make a cat hat out of it. You will wear that cat hat down the road yourself to demonstrate what you intend to do. That stinking cat hat that you will then be wearing will mean, of course, that at the end of the day the situation will be that 80 per cent of Australian taxpayers will be worse off; the unemployment assessments that you have made are totally out of court and will not be achieved; and the inflation rate in this country will mean, inevitably, that interest rates will rise. Then you will say to the Reserve Bank, after you have been confronted by all these horrifying things, `Look, what we would really like you to do, boys, is to establish your control of the economy independent of any democratic processes. We will legislate to make you totally independent, except for one thing: we will remove from your charter the obligation to ensure the economy moves towards full employment and include simply a line which says that you must keep the inflation rate between 0 and 2 per cent'. Will that not have a doozey little effect down the line so far as people are concerned?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer might well be right in those circumstances. That actually may be the critical point. The critical point in ensuring that the outcome the Treasury has here modelled is actually achieved is that 0 to 2 per cent element, because that will actually guarantee that no jobs will be created in this economy over the next five to 10 years—none at all. If the Reserve Bank has to impose those sorts of inflation targets on top of this mess of the Opposition's GST package, then we are guaranteed to have a good 15 to 20 per cent of the Australian public whiling away their time—not on the dole queues, because they will be removed from that—in some form of starvation. That is where the Opposition would get us, and this is the central problem with Opposition policy and with the Fightback proposal. It is massive in size and utterly confused in content.

PARA.TAB: What the Opposition cannot handle is the fact that the Finance and Treasury departments have gone straight to the heart of the problem of the exercise and pointed out the extraordinary effects on the livelihood of the Australian people. That is a matter of some regret for Opposition backbenchers because they wished simply to follow David Lange's advice to the Opposition in the circumstances in which he figured the Opposition found itself here; that was to remain warm and breathing and to hope that government would fall into its lap. It would have been a better idea for those opposite had they attempted to do that because, in displaying their hand to the Australian public, they displayed to the Australian people a suggestion that they intend to economically devastate those people. The problem for those opposite is that the Australian people are beginning to figure this out.

If anyone ought to be censured here, it is not the Minister for Finance, who has made amply clear the basis on which his comments were made. Those comments were perfectly adequate in terms of any charges made in the censure motion in this place. The people who ought to be censured are the clowns opposite who have wandered across the country presenting these absurd propositions which do not balance and which are not matched. They ought to be censured for debauching the economic debate in this country while they do that. So that we can have an opportunity to vote down this absurd motion and get on with the business of the day, I move:
That the question be now put.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Reith's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on the Print Media

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Select Committee on the Print Media, I present the report of the Committee, incorporating dissenting reports, entitled News & Fair Facts: The Australian Print Media Industry, together with the minutes of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last six months the House of Representatives Select Committee on the Print Media has conducted the most wide-ranging and exhaustive national inquiry ever conducted into the Australian print media. Over three thousand pages of written submissions were received, more than 70 witnesses appeared at public and in-camera hearings, and the Hansard transcript exceeded 1,600 pages. During February and March the Committee spent more than 40 hours finalising our 438 page report, entitled News & Fair Facts.

PARA.TAB: On behalf of the Committee I wish to thank the many individuals, organisations and corporations who provided submissions, especially those who also gave evidence. Our five-person secretariat has had to burn the midnight oil over many months. Our thanks go to Malcolm Aldons, our Committee secretary, who was a source of much wise advice and good counsel; Sue Morton, who prepared chapters two and eight; and Sally Dunn, who assisted with most chapters and also suggested the snappy title of the report.

We extend our thanks also for the generosity of the Trade Practices Commission and the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics. The Committee had the benefit of the expertise of Susan Johnson, who prepared chapters five and six, and Franco Papandrea, who prepared chapters four, seven and nine and coordinated other chapters. Without the hard work during December and January of our Committee secretariat, and Franco in particular, I suspect that our report would not have seen the light of day before the end of the year.

The report acknowledges many others who have helped the Committee, but I would like to place on record our appreciation of Hansard, the Sound and Vision Office, the Parliamentary Library, the House Duplicating Service and AGPS. The Committee also appreciated the invitation from News Ltd and the John Fairfax Group to inspect their premises in Sydney and Melbourne, as this gave Committee members an opportunity to speak to some newspaper staff informally.

Finally, I wish to thank the other eleven members of the Committee for their contributions. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) was a very able Deputy Chairman. I appreciate his very positive approach, despite my own personal disappointment at the polemic views put forward in the minority reports. Anyone reading the minority reports may underestimate the lengths to which both Government and Opposition members went in seeking to find common ground and to minimise differences.

My colleagues know that, when we started this journey some six months ago, many pundits were predicting that Labor would produce three minority reports, in addition to any Opposition opinions. The fact that at the end of that journey all seven Labor members have reached agreement without dissent, while the Opposition has produced two dissenting reports, is testament to a constructive approach which those of us on this side of the House intend to ensure continues during the debate on the Government's response to our report.

In many ways the Committee's journey has been as important as the final report, coming as it did during the bidding for control of the John Fairfax Group. In our first meeting, the Committee unanimously resolved to request each of the bidders for John Fairfax to appear before the Committee to answer questions on oath. My aim in suggesting this course of action to the Committee was to have the bidders' promises and assurances, which at that time were being given only to merchant bankers and some interest groups, given on oath in public hearings of a committee of this Parliament. The minority report described this as a `sideshow' and went on to claim:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee in an inappropriate manner was absorbed in a matter in which it should not have been involved.
For the record, I point out that no Opposition member raised any objection to this course of action at the time.

PARA.TAB: Our 400-page report puts forward proposals which our Committee believes will improve competition and diversity over time by strengthening the Trade Practices Act. Our report also puts forward recommendations on limits on foreign ownership and cross-media ownership. The establishment of the Committee followed increasing debate about the concentration of ownership in the print media, fuelled by the takeover of the Herald and Weekly Times group by News Ltd in 1987 and by the appointment, of course, of a receiver for the John Fairfax Group in 1990.

The report discusses various overseas inquiries which have investigated newspaper ownership concentration and made recommendations to encourage competition and diversity of opinion. However, in most cases the governments which have received those recommendations have not implemented them. We are pretty confident that that will not happen with this report.

Prior to the establishment of this Committee, the only major inquiry into the print media in Australia was conducted in Victoria in 1981. The Norris inquiry found a very high and increasing concentration of ownership and control of newspapers in Victoria and warned of several associated dangers. But the recommendations of the Norris inquiry were not implemented by the Thompson or Cain Victorian governments. To date, a similar fate has befallen the recommendations of the Working Party into Print Media Ownership, which reported to the Victorian Attorney-General in December 1990.

The print media industry is not as highly regulated as the electronic media in most Western countries. In Australia, the print media industry is subject to the Trade Practices Act and cross-media ownership rules set out in the Broadcasting Act. Advice from the Attorney-General's Department to the Committee indicates that the Federal Parliament has the constitutional power to regulate corporations involved in the print media. The question which this report addresses is what, if any, additional regulation of the Australian print media is required.

Concentration of the ownership of the print media appears to be driven by economic forces which inexorably favour monopoly newspapers in a particular market segment and group ownership of newspapers in different markets. These forces arise from economies of scale inherent in newspaper publishing. While there is some competition between newspapers and other media for both audiences and advertising, the level of competition is not high, as advertisers use the different media for largely different functions. For example, a national fast food chain which uses extensive television advertising to promote the association of its products with a desirable lifestyle would be unlikely to redirect this advertising to newspapers if television advertising rates increased. Similarly, newspaper classified and supermarket display advertisements would be unlikely to be transferred to television.

The Committee's analysis of the print media was hampered by the lack of data on the industry. The Committee has recommended that the Australian Bureau of Statistics regularly collect and publish information on the characteristics and performance of the Australian print media industry.

The Australian print media industry is highly concentrated. In almost every sector of the industry, one or two groups dominate in terms of the number of publications and the related circulation under their control. The highest level of concentration exists in metropolitan and national newspapers. Suburban newspapers are also highly concentrated.

Although ownership of the national magazine sector is widely dispersed, many magazines have a relatively small, specialised readership. Ownership of the major high circulation magazines is concentrated within two groups. A high level of concentration would not be a problem if the print media market were highly contestable. In such a situation, the mere threat of entry into the market by a new publisher would act as a constraining force on the activities of established proprietors.

There was general agreement that the barriers to entry are high for aspiring publishers of metropolitan or national daily newspapers, but that enterprising publishers could break into niche markets. Although there are virtually no regulatory barriers, apart from cross-media ownership rules, economic barriers to entry are relatively high, particularly for newspapers. Until a new entrant achieves economies of scale, the average cost of production and distribution will be substantially higher than those of its established competitors.

Readers' habits and their loyalty to established mastheads will make it difficult to attract circulation and increase the risk of failure. Furthermore, the need to commit large amounts of capital to specialised equipment and facilities means that failure would be accompanied by very large losses because the equipment and facilities are not easily adaptable to alternative uses.

The high fixed cost of newspaper production, including virtually all the costs of collecting information and preparing a newspaper for printing, means that the average cost of production per copy declines rapidly with increases in the number of copies printed. This gives an established newspaper a relatively large cost advantage over new entrants with lower circulation. In addition, since advertisers favour higher circulation and are prepared to pay a premium for it, the new entrant will receive a lower return per copy sold. Similar scale factors apply to the distribution of newspapers. Additional benefits accrue to publishers of more than one publication at the same or different locations.

These benefits arise from the ability to share production and distribution facilities, and other facilities and services such as computers, facsimile machines, library services, copy swapping and foreign correspondents. The Committee is convinced of the existence of formidable barriers to entry which militate against the successful establishment of new metropolitan or national daily newspapers. Entry to other segments of the print media market is not as difficult. Although the prospect of entry to magazine publishing and suburban and regional newspaper publication is less daunting, it should not be forgotten that the predominance of the major publishing groups will see new publishers entering at a distinct disadvantage.

Vertical integration represents another barrier to entry to the print media industry. Some degree of vertical integration is a relatively common feature of print media groups, particularly those engaged in the publication of metropolitan newspapers. I do not need to tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, of News Ltd's investments in ANM, the only newsprint manufacturer in Australia, as well as AAP, the main independent source of news, which also shares a significant degree of control over the distribution of print media products.

Vertical integration may provide substantial competitive advantages over rivals if it confers preferential access to scarce supply or facilities or access on especially attractive terms. The main advantage enjoyed by News Ltd in purchasing newsprint from ANM is security of domestic supply. The advantage, however, reflects the size and importance of News Ltd as a customer of ANM rather than the part-ownership link and is available to other customers entering into long term supply contracts with ANM.

The Committee received no evidence that indicated ANM gave preferential treatment to News Ltd on newsprint prices or delivery times. The Committee was concerned about the effects of the AAP pricing policy, which sets a price for each metropolitan area based on its population. That policy does not encourage new entrants and acts to reduce the cost of the news service to established producers when a new entrant seeks access to that service in that city.

Furthermore, since the pricing policy does not take account of the circulation of the subscribers' publications, it generates further economies of scale for the established publication. There was no suggestion, however, that anyone had been denied access to AAP. There is no doubt that the current newsagency system provides definite competitive advantages to incumbent publishers by members of the newsagency councils.

On the one hand, the advantages include the ability to influence the business operations of newsagents, such as opening hours and home delivery conditions; influence on the range of publications stocked by the newsagents; and access to customer base details for marketing purposes. On the other hand, the newsagency system encourages the carrying of a large range of publications, some of which have low circulations unlikely to be attractive to other retailers such as supermarkets. In addition, newsagents claimed that loss of exclusive areas will threaten the home delivery service. Overall, it is not suggested that vertical integration by the major publishers has been set up to deliberately discourage new entrants. Rather, it is a feature of the industry which inhibits new entry.

I now turn to the most important recommendations of our report, which aim to improve competition and diversity in the Australian print media. It is the view of the Committee that competition and diversity of views are inextricably linked. More sources of information are likely to offer readers wider diversity than are fewer sources. While the range of views offered by a wide circulation newspaper has to be necessarily broad, it is unlikely that such a newspaper will offer views which appeal to minorities but which may offend the sensitivities of some other readers. Also, it is likely that two newspapers will regularly interpret the same stories differently.

Some members of the Committee concluded that there was a connection between the unprecedented high concentration of media ownership and the lack of information and ideas in the Australian press, and that the former is likely to be a significant cause of the latter. However, a majority of the Committee considered that there was insufficient evidence to conclude that the current high level of concentration in the Australian print media has resulted in biased reporting, news suppression or lack of diversity.

All members of the Committee agreed that concentration of ownership is potentially harmful to plurality of opinion and increases the potential risk that news may be distorted. The Committee considered but rejected calls for some form of divestiture and the imposition of some numerical limits on the number of newspapers or magazines which any proprietor can own. The Committee decided that in addition to the argument that such drastic action would be inherently unfair, it would be difficult to implement and would raise questions about the continued viability of some units that would be created as a result.

The Committee therefore concluded that the preferred course of action was to encourage greater competition in the Australian print media and wider diversity of ownership over time by recommending amendments to the Trade Practices Act. The print media industry, like other industries, is currently subject to that Act. The provisions of the Act are essentially economic in nature. However, at authorisation hearings wider examination of the public benefit or detriment of proposals are taken into consideration by the Trade Practices Commission.

The Committee concluded that the process, as distinct from the criteria, for ensuring competition and thus ensuring diversity is adequate. However, whether the application of this process ultimately leads to adequate levels of competition and diversity depends entirely on the criteria which are used. The merger test was weakened by the Fraser Government in 1977 with legislation introduced by the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). The Trade Practices Commission has argued strongly for a tighter merger test both in evidence to our Committee and before the Cooney inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser has described the current dominance test, which his own Government introduced, as a complete and absolute disaster.

The current dominance threshold for mergers has failed to preserve a desirable level of competition in some sections of the print media, particularly metropolitan daily newspapers. Further concentration of the ownership of metropolitan daily newspapers is unlikely to be in the public interest. Consequently, the risk that it might occur has to be minimised. In doing so, we have tried to be careful that we do not introduce unnecessary distortions to market forces.A tightening of the merger test threshold would satisfy these requirements.

The Committee concluded that there was very strong justification for the adoption of a substantial lessening of the competition threshold for future print media mergers. This report examined the print media industry only and therefore makes no recommendations on whether the merger test should be tightened for other industries. However, if the Government implements the Cooney report and the Martin report on banking from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which also recommended a tighter merger test for that industry, then our recommendation which would ensure that the competition test apply to print media mergers would have the advantage of being consistent across all industries.

A substantial lessening of the competition test, on its own, may not dispel community concerns about the public detriment which may result from undue concentration of print media. Diversity of opinion and truth and accuracy in reporting are of fundamental importance to the public interest. While no law will be able to guarantee these ideals totally, steps can be taken to ensure that any potential threat to them which may arise from a merger or acquisition is fully evaluated in a forum which allows all interested parties opportunities to air their concerns.

The Committee has therefore recommended that the Trade Practices Act be amended to incorporate a new section specific to print media requiring that, during authorisation hearings, the Trade Practices Commission should examine and take account of the likely impact of a merger on three things: firstly, free expression of opinion; secondly, fair and accurate presentation of news; and, thirdly, the economic viability of the publication if the merger does not proceed.

The Committee also considered that print media mergers or acquisitions which were likely to raise community concerns should be subject to mandatory notification. The report contains further details on this matter.

In chapter 8 the Committee addresses the question of editorial independence. While it considers that charters of editorial independence offer something which may be desirable, the Committee has concluded that newspaper proprietors should not be required by legislation to sign charters of editorial independence. Rather, the Committee has concluded that the AJA code of ethics provided a practical framework for editorial independence. It believes that proprietors and editors should join with journalists in agreeing to adopt the code as the overriding principles governing the performance of their duties and that consideration should be given to having that code incorporated in contracts of employment in the future.

The report also contains a proposal for restructuring the Australian Press Council. It believes that there is a perception that the current structure is not working, particularly since the AJA terminated its involvement in 1987. Further details are contained in the report.

On cross-media ownership, the Committee has determined that both print and electronic media have the power to influence public opinion. Cross-media ownership rules which limit common ownership of television, radio and newspapers have been very effective in breaking up the conglomerates which existed before 1987.

At the moment national newspapers are not included and a majority of the Committee members are not proposing that they be included. Some members of the Committee argued strongly that a zero or 5 per cent limit should apply to cross-media ownership but, in the final analysis, the Committee agreed that the emphasis should be placed on whether or not control was being exercised, as proposed in the draft Broadcasting Services Bill. The Committee strongly supports the retention of the cross-media ownership rules, including those which apply to radio. However, the Government may need to review this matter as new technology expands the number of radio services available.

On the subject of foreign investment, the Committee considered that it is contradictory to seek increased diversity of newspaper ownership on the one hand whilst, at the same time, seeking to prohibit any foreign investment in Australian newspapers. Such a ban is not practical. The Committee recommended that the FIRB continue to examine all foreign investment proposals in the print media. The Committee also recommended that, subject to normal national interest requirements, proposals of up to 20 per cent foreign control should be approved.

The Committee recognises that the present 20 per cent limit on foreign ownership is an arbitrary figure consistent with the arbitrary figure for television. However, it is of concern to some members of the Committee that that has become a benchmark figure. The best reason for using such a figure is that it acts as a guideline for prospective investors but alerts them to the important policy considerations of this issue. The 20 per cent limit should be viewed in this context.

Proposals involving higher levels of foreign control should be approved only if the Government believes that a strong case has been made that it is in the national interest or that other arguments apply.

Finally, given the importance of the print media, the Committee considers that the Treasurer should always publish reasons for accepting or rejecting proposals for foreign investment in the print media.
I hope these wide-ranging recommendations have the support of every member of this side of the House and that they will be speedily implemented by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Deputy Chairman of the Select Committee on the Print Media, I have to give the Chairman of the Committee a word of congratulations. This was a very difficult political and, indeed, physical task to complete in the very short timeframe which was reluctantly extended by the Government. From our point of view, the Committee has produced a report that will add greatly to the level of debate about the media industry and particularly the print industry in this country.

PARA.TAB: I do not intend to speak for a long period of time because other Committee members also want to contribute, but I think that there are some remarks that need to be made. I would like to put on record, on behalf of the coalition members, the thanks that need to be extended to the Committee staff. The honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) has already done so and I join him in those remarks.

This report required a great deal of economic analysis. There was a massive number of submissions and the Committee thanks all those people who made submissions. The task required work above and beyond the normal demands on staff. Of the many reports I have been involved in, this was certainly the most challenging for staff, and indeed members, in its complexity and in the breadth of the issues that the Committee had to deal with.

I think it would be fair to say that I am a person possessed of a generous spirit. I do not want to enter into discussion of some of the remarks that were made by the Chairman about the polemic nature of the dissenting report other than to say that I guess that in respect of this industry, like no other, the differences of opinion within the community were brought to bear in this Committee. How Committee members respectively deal with these differences of opinion is a matter for their own particular judgment. It reflects not on the personalities of the people involved; it reflects on the sharpness of focus that one has to bring to bear in assessing these issues. It is a matter of how best we deal with what we have jointly identified as a potential problem, and that is that increasing concentration in print media undermines the plurality of opinions that need to be seen in a functioning democracy, which all of us in the place take pride in working with and for.

With that point, I think we can dismiss some of the more pointed remarks that I am sure will be made today and try to concentrate on what the broad issue was. The issue was how one addresses, in a competition policy sense, the question of ensuring that there is going to be a diversity of opinion through the mechanism of the print media and how one ensures that those who own the print media, when they move into other media, do not use that position—and it is only potential—to direct the formation of opinion in a way that would not be in the long term interest of the development of our democracy.

This debate about how to do this is really brought together in this report, but it is an ongoing debate. It has been going for some considerable time. The first report that dealt with this was the report of the 1989 inquiry into mergers, takeovers and monopolies. It made a recommendation that there should be no mandatory notification of an intent to merge and that the test, the dominance test to which the Chairman referred, ought to stay where it is.

We had a more recent report that went in another direction. If one looks at the Trade Practices Commission's recent bulletin, one will see an interesting article by the Deputy Chairman of the Commission, Professor Johns, in which he responds to Dr Pengilley, a former TPC member who took a contrary view. The immediate past Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission, Professor Baxt, took a different view. I want to make the point that this issue is still being debated. In evidence to the Committee we got various views, from sources ranging from Attorney-General's to Treasury. The Business Council of Australia has a view that the test ought to stay as it is. On that central issue which the Chairman has identified, chapter 7, there are still many and varied views. The Opposition puts its view in the dissenting report, which my colleague the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), the shadow Minister for this area, will detail.

If I may go back to the broader issue, there was clearly a cocktail of interests that had to be addressed. That in itself, at the time the Committee was established, was all to the fore and generated great community interest. Of course, the Committee was established to deal in part with the factional difficulties of the ALP that grew out of the national convention in Hobart. At the time the Committee was established back in August 1991, the Hansard recorded the Opposition's view: that we felt that this was the wrong inquiry for the wrong reasons at the wrong time.

That is not to say that it was not necessary that the issues be dealt with; it was. Back in 1989 I, as a member of the Parliament, raised with the then Attorney, Mr Lionel Bowen, and the subsequent Attorney, Mr Duffy, the issue of the Commonwealth's role in the print media. We finally got to this report but we were driven by the necessity for this report because of the dilemmas that the ALP faced within its factional make-up at the time prior to the change of prime ministership. I think that is the fundamental concern that we expressed in the dissent.

But if we step beyond that and go to the centrality of the issues—and of course we have a different view about the question of competition test—the whole debate about Fairfax was subject to great discussion by this Committee. We had before us some of the big men of Australian politics and Australian business. They were obviously flexible in their views. To see a former Prime Minister stating in evidence that decisions he had made whilst Prime Minister were something that he now regretted was, of course, of interest, but it shows the fluid position of this area of policy and the difficulties which we as a Parliament have to grapple with.

But whether we should have this inquiry right at the time of the Fairfax bid—the biggest business battle for a considerable number of years in this country—was something that, of course, this Committee could not decide. We were put in the position—right or wrong, I think it is regrettable that we were in that position—of being involved in a matter that really was not within our province. Out of that grew a lot of criticism of the Parliament. There are clearly some lessons there for the Parliament about how it addresses these types of complex issues, and many have made the point that additional specialist counsel and so on would be required. But we were dealing, to term a phrase, with the gentlemen cannibals of the business world circling a prize asset. We had to accept that there would be intensities of views and that, of course, spilled over into the debates that raged around the Committee in the course of its deliberations.

I would just like to pick up on a couple of points we make in our dissenting report. The first of these relates to the matter of cross-ownership rules. I have the strong personal view that the cross-ownership rules are an adjunct to competition policy. One would hope that over time they are not necessary as we get greater competition within this particular industry. But they are an adjunct to competition policy, in my view they are necessary, and that is why we support the continuation of the cross-media ownership rules in their generality, seeing it as it is—as a temporary necessity—given that ultimately competition policy ought to be dealt with in the general sense reaching over all industries in the Trade Practices Commission area. But we specifically believe that in the radio industry there is no longer a need for cross-ownership rules; they ought not to apply. That is the proposal in the Broadcasting Services Bill that is now in circulation. Indeed, the Chairman of the Committee says that, in recognising the dramatic changes in technology, one has to assess more carefully the requirement that cross-media ownership rules continue to apply in radio.

The recent decisions in Spain from the WAR conference about digital audio broadcasting will accelerate the Parliament's necessity to step away from the cross-media ownership rules in the radio area. That is the position we take. On the question of foreign investment, which is a more difficult area for the Government than it is for us, we are quite clear. We do not believe that percentage limits are meaningful at all. We should deal with each application individually and the underlying test ought to be that, where any proposal manifestly leads to a greater increase in market concentration and a decrease in competition, it should not enjoy support.

We certainly agree that the decisions of the FIRB, the Foreign Investment Review Board, ought to be made public. Indeed, the furore that took place over the decisions of the Government recently in the Fairfax battle to change from one position to another indicates clearly that to have some consistency of approach the publication of decisions by a Treasurer of the time would be—certainly in our view—a necessity. There is the temptation to allow political whim to prevail, and that, of course, does not make for good government or consistent government. When a country such as ours needs to accept that foreign investment is a feature of economic life, there needs to be some certainty for people who are contemplating investment. We reject the proposal that is in the recommendation of the majority. It is interesting, though, to recognise that that is a more flexible position from the Government and it will be interesting to see the consequences in this particular industry of its decision.

It is my understanding that in Western Australia the recently floated West Australian newspaper has well above 20 per cent of accumulated foreign ownership. As to the suggestion that the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics could have an ongoing role, we simply reject that possibility. We do not believe that there ought to be an ongoing print media inquiry—occasional research by all means. We go back to the 1989 report which I was involved in where we recommended that the Bureau of Statistics gather up a line of data. Certainly we accept that, but I do not believe that the BTCE should be put in the position of conducting a rolling media inquiry.

As I mentioned, chapter 7, the centrality of the report about improving competition and diversity, will be addressed. I have addressed that already in the broad and I still believe that those who rely on the heart of Professor Michael Porter's analysis need to look a little more deeply at the Australian context before embracing this. If one goes back to the mergers and monopolies report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs chaired by Senator Cooney, it is interesting to note that at page 69 the Committee recommends that there should be discrete legislation—that is, legislation separate from the Trade Practices Commission, to deal with the broader issues. The current proposal goes halfway; it is a halfway solution. It does not go quite as far as what the Cooney Committee recommends. So there again we have an example of the great diversity of views on how this particular matter might be addressed.

The print media inquiry will continue to be the subject of intense debate, which can only be healthy in a community such as ours. This report, with its catchy title—to which someone should claim credit, but it is not I—News & Fair Facts : The Australian Print Media Industry, will be one that many will go back to for a long time. I do not believe the Government would be wise to proceed to immediate legislation to give voice to the majority recommendations. I think that would be a backward step. It ought to listen more carefully to the great variety of views that are there. We ought to assess over time the impacts on this industry. We ought to recognise that this report came at a time that was difficult for the industry and for many in this place; it came at a time where the intensity of political debate overshadowed the importance of the issues, and this is reflected in the dissenting report. That may well be regretted by some, but it was certainly part of a scene with which we dealt.

I say to my Labor Party colleagues: the fact that the Committee was extended from nine members originally to 12 was not directly to accommodate my colleague from the National Party, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), but to accommodate members from the different factions. That was regrettable but, understandably, necessary when a party is driven by factions. But let not that be the issue upon which we differ now. Let us try to differ on the issues and, in that way, we will be giving justice to what is a monumental report in terms of the data it collected from a very interested and informed industry. I would imagine that this report is being pored over by many of those upstairs with great interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) is a very likeable man and we work together well on the Select Committee on the Print Media. Therefore, I was surprised and disappointed by what I perceived as being a very partisan and unnecessarily abusive minority report. Without wanting to return that in kind, I will just make a couple of comments on the points he raised.

PARA.TAB: What stands out about his comments and about the dissenting report is the fact that they are quite internally inconsistent. The first point I wish to make is that the Opposition was critical of the establishment of the Committee. Yet when I moved a motion in this House only a year ago calling for a royal commission on print media concentration, the Opposition speakers in that debate supported the idea of an inquiry but not of a royal commission. They recognised the damage of media concentration and the value of having an inquiry into that issue. For members of the Opposition to say that it was not a timely inquiry and that it was directed by factional issues, which in itself is quite inaccurate, is inconsistent and appears to be simply expedient. It appears to be aimed at mollifying media proprietors who might otherwise be antagonistic. It is also inconsistent to oppose the central recommendations. Members of the Opposition claim to be concerned with increasing competition, and I think that they are genuinely concerned.

The central recommendation of this report is aimed at increasing competition in print media and there is no doubt at all that the dominance test has failed to do that. Given that it has failed to do that, it was obviously necessary to change it. The proposal for change that was made was judged by many people—including Mr Malcolm Fraser, a former Liberal Prime Minister—to be an appropriate approach. The majority of the evidence we received supported the reintroduction of a substantial lessening of competition test.

The proposals are inconsistent on that point. There was also division within Opposition ranks in terms of the evidence that Malcolm Fraser gave on the whole range of subjects we were discussing. Mr Fraser recommended divestiture, for example. He recommended opposing all foreign investment. The tone of the Opposition's dissenting report is quite disappointing.

I now intend to be more positive. I believe this was a timely committee, a profoundly important committee and an entirely appropriate committee for this Parliament to set up. Parliament has to be concerned with the structure of our society and the fact that we have, in Australia, a higher level of ownership concentration than any other Western country has, or has ever had. This must be a cause of great concern to anyone interested in the quality of our democracy.

There is no doubt in my mind that the evidence we received showed that that high level of concentration had led to a reduction in the diversity of views that were available to the Australian people. The Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), has very effectively summarised both the analysis and the recommendations of the Committee. I will not repeat those.

I would like to compliment the Chairman on the quality of his work. Clearly, people may not have always expected us to have identical views, but by working hard and discussing the matters vigorously and openly we did come to an agreed conclusion. That is a significant achievement in itself.

The importance of coming to an agreement is that we have prepared a report which, in our judgment, can be implemented by the Government in full and immediately. It is a moderate and carefully prepared report at every point. In the judgment of all the Government members of the Committee, it can be fully implemented this year. We look forward to that happening.

I will not repeat the recommendations which have been well summarised by the Chairman, except to outline a couple of points that he perhaps did not have time to deal with fully because of the time available to him. We dealt with the Australian Press Council and we recommended that the Press Council be restructured so that publishers and journalists are represented equally. Together they would choose a third person who would be a member of the public. There would also be a neutral chairperson. We also recommended that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) convene a meeting to get that process under way.

I would like to conclude by congratulating the staff of the Committee. We had a remarkably effective staff, considering we were obviously working under pressure of time. The staff worked very hard and have great ability. The quality of the report owes a great deal to their effectiveness. I thank them and the other members of the Committee. It was a very interesting committee in which to be involved and I think the recommendations are so important that they should be immediately implemented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The print media inquiry report contains a useful collection of facts and a useful description of the various regulatory laws that govern ownership and foreign investment in print, television and radio in Australia. I think it will prove to be a handy reference volume in the future for those who want to understand how the media is regulated in Australia and for those who want to get some empirical data on the current state of ownership of the print media.

PARA.TAB: However, it should be stressed that one will not find any original research in the report of the Select Committee on the Print Media. I do not think anyone would claim that this inquiry and this report have discovered something that was not known before. It has not set out to break any new ground and the views that it has encompassed are principally a collation of the views of others—and that is useful. I make that point at the start.

I do not think it is the fault of the Committee that it was not able to engage in original research. It was put on a tight leash with a short time frame and was constituted in a way which was not conducive to inquisitorial examination of evidence and of finding out facts that people who came before it did not want to be known. If it had been intended to elicit from those involved in the media in Australia facts that they did not want to voluntarily disclose, it would have been necessary to set up some other kind of inquiry—either a royal commission or an inquiry—with counsel assisting, who would be in a position to examine and cross-examine, and with an independent royal commissioner who would be able to enforce answers to questions.

It is true that parliamentary committees have wide-ranging powers. They can subpoena, put witnesses on oath and, if need be, if those answers are inaccurate, refer matters as contempts of parliament. But the Committee was not operated so as to exercise those inquisitorial powers in full. As a result, one of the episodes that the Committee will be best remembered for is the live television appearance of Mr Kerry Packer. Whether that elicited any new information is a matter for debate. Most people would suggest that it did not find out anything that was not already known. It also displayed a weakness that bedevilled the activities of the Committee throughout, which was that the Committee had no coherent and unified view on the questions; there were differences between Government and Opposition members; and there were differences between Government members. When the Committee was confronted with that situation, it proved unable to acquit itself as well as we might have hoped.

I cannot help feeling that putting the Committee on a tight leash and operating it without using the full coercive powers of a parliamentary committee was intentional and secured what came out, which was more or less a collation of what was already known, rather than uncovering new facts, particularly new facts that principal parties did not want to voluntarily disclose.

It has been said—and I would agree—that the principal recommendation to come out of this particular report is the recommendation which appears in chapter seven. I took a particular interest in what was in chapter seven. That part of the dissenting report on chapter seven—in which I played a part in writing—has my wholehearted approval. But it is of disappointment to me that, after a full-blown inquiry into the Australian print media and after hearing all of these witnesses and taking all of these views, the principal recommendation that actually came out of the report was an old argument that has been reworked from several other parliamentary committees.

It is the old argument about what the test under section 50 of the Trade Practices Act should be. That test was introduced in 1977. After a full examination of it in 1986, Lionel Bowen, the then Attorney-General, announced in this Parliament that he did not think it needed to be changed. He said that in this House on 19 March 1986. He said:

The Government is firmly committed to the encouragement of efficient Australian industry. . . . It has been decided that the existing `dominance' test in section 50 should remain essentially unchanged.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the 1986 review. We then had the Griffiths review, a review of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. It reported in May 1989 that section 50 of the Trade Practices Act should not be changed. At that point that was the position of the Labor Government and indeed of people from all factions who were on that Committee. I think there was one dissent, but even some members of the Left on the Griffiths Committee endorsed that particular report. After two years of no doubt industrious studying of the Griffiths report, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) finally came into this place in August 1991 to respond to the report of May 1989. The Attorney-General said:
Like the Committee, it is not convinced that there is sufficient justification for reverting to the `substantial lessening of competition' test . . .

That was the Government's position as late as August 1991. So we had the recommendations of Bowen in 1986, Griffiths in 1989 and Duffy in 1991: three inquiries, and three recommendations not to change the existing section 50 merger test. Since then we have had the Cooney Committee, which has come to another conclusion. I am led to believe the Martin Committee went through it and came to another conclusion. Now we have the Print Media Committee, which has, by a majority, worked through it and come to a conclusion which involves altering section 50.

PARA.TAB: It is of some disappointment to me that, after all of the hearings and all of the evidence, the principal recommendation that came down is an old argument which has been reworked through various parliamentary committees. In this case it was reworked very hard by the Trade Practices Commission. It will not surprise anybody that as a result of this recommendation the Trade Practices Commission would not only extend its jurisdiction on mergers but would also take on a new element. This is one of the matters that concerns me very deeply, and it is referred to in the dissenting report. Not only would the Trade Practices Commission presumably have a wider field of inquiry under a new test, but on an authorisation application it would be directing itself to issues of an entirely new character. As recommended by the majority, it would direct itself to the likely impact of mergers on free expression of opinion and fair and accurate presentation of news.

Whether news is fair and accurately presented is a highly contentious issue. People with different political views invariably have different opinions. It is a highly contentious area. The majority of the Committee has recommended that a body which is appointed by government, the Trade Practices Commission, on a merger application investigate the outcome for the fair and accurate presentation of news. The first point I make is that, by reason of the qualifications of those on it, they are not qualified to inquire into those matters. Secondly, if they do start inquiring into highly contentious questions like that, the Trade Practices Commission itself runs the risk of being politicised and of people taking hostile political views on its deliberations. I believe that that will hamper the important work of the Trade Practices Commission in other areas, namely, areas concerning competition.

It will also subject the Trade Practices Commission to all sorts of posturing and lobbying, as we know goes on whenever there is a media merger. Again, I believe this will threaten the independence, high standing and credibility which it needs to have when it is considering general competition issues. During the conduct of this inquiry and as a result of the sale of the Fairfax empire that was going on at the time, we saw some of the most naked lobbying activity by political interests that has ever been seen in this country. It was lobbying not just members of the Committee—the Committee was small fry—but Prime Ministers and Ministers, journalists and other proprietors. We saw the worst face of lobbying in full operation. It will be regrettable if the Trade Practices Commission is subject to that.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member for Higgins will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Why did he tell Parliament yesterday that by 2 December last year Treasury had not analysed Fightback's expenditure or revenue measures when, in actual fact, the Government had received two Treasury minutes, one on revenue on 27 November and the second, being a 170-page analysis of expenditure, on 26 November, one week beforehand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's pursuit of this issue must be becoming exceedingly tedious to the Parliament. It certainly totally lacks any substance. Of course, those opposite think they are on to something; but, as has already been proven, there is nothing in it. The Treasury document which excited their interest is an analysis of their package which shows that the employment outcome would not be two million jobs, but none—no jobs at all. If you want to embrace that Treasury document with the interest rate reductions that it shows, you should embrace the employment outcome. Let us see them grab that one—two million jobs become zero; no job growth at all.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister is deliberately refusing to answer the question. I ask you to direct him to answer the question that has been put to him.
—Order! The Minister was asked a question about two documents and I understand that the Minister is addressing the question of those documents.
—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: frivolous points of order which only interrupt the answerer's flow are highly disorderly, I put to you.
—In terms of the precise question asked of me, the facts of the situation are that what I said remains absolutely true. There was certainly some indication, some papers came to us, before 2 December.
—170 pages.
—Order!
—But they were not complete documents. If you bothered to look at them, you might see how they are incomplete.
—You do not appear to have looked at them very well. You must have had sunglasses on or something.
—Blinkers.
—Blinkers, more likely. Document 27 of 26 November, which is the first indication we had from Finance of the costings of the Opposition's package says:

ANSWER.PARA: was prepared by the Department of Finance, who have asked we advise—
this is a note from Treasury to the Treasurer's office—

that the attachment provides a list of preliminary costings and supporting information. There are still a numbers of gaps and qualifications so that, at this stage, it is an early draft provided for your information only and not for any wider distribution.

PARA.TAB: In particular there needs to be a further review of:

ANSWER.PARA: .the savings attributed to those programs for which the Forward Estimates are significantly different from the Budget Estimates—
and also from other material. On the next page, it says:

In the limited time available the Department of Finance has been able to cost the majority of the outlays measures contained in the package. Outstanding costings will be forwarded by Friday and as they become available.

Then follows a summary of all this material. It shows the various departments and Opposition's costings for three years and Finance's costings for three years. There are stars against some of them. The explanation for the stars, at the bottom of the page, is:
Costings for total portfolio not yet complete.
Included amongst them was Social Security, a very big item. At the bottom of the page it has:
In year 1, $1,363m of the Opposition's costings were yet to be costed; in year 2, $1,184m; in year 3, $485m. All of those were yet to be costed. So what we had—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is irrelevant; you had the advice.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo!
—If motor mouth over there would just shut up and listen, he might learn something.
—Order! The Minister will answer the question.

—What we had here were preliminary costings; far from complete costings. Obviously, there is no way that Treasury would have been working on the basis of such costings which were yet to be completed and were not finally given to us in complete form until 9 December. Document 25 of 27 November referred to by the Opposition, which is on the revenue side, only deals with modelling of indirect charges. We had some revenue figures there, but the purpose of that document was to look at the impact of indirect charges being changed, that is, the introduction of the GST and the abolition of various taxes. So, it had revenue effects for that, but it left out a host of revenue items, such as personal income tax proposals, including the tax bracket creep analysis, company tax changes, capital gains tax, superannuation fund, fringe benefits tax, et cetera. It was far from a complete revenue costing.

PARA.TAB: There was absolutely no basis upon which there could be an analysis by Treasury at that stage, before 2 December, which included full knowledge of the costings both on the revenue side and on the outlay side.

What I said to this House about that in the personal explanation yesterday remains absolutely 100 per cent true, and there is absolutely nothing to retract or apologise for. The apologies should all be forthcoming from the other side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the Government's intentions in regard to tariffs and the development of competitive manufacturing industry in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, in historic changes in 1988 and 1990, announced and presided over a phased reduction in tariff protection in Australia, that is, reducing the border protection which produced the industrial museum the Liberal Party created for us in the 1950s and 1960s, to produce an outwardly looking, import competitive, modern industrial society.

PARA.TAB: That was in evidence at the Southern Pacific Tyre factory on the outskirts of the Wills electorate when I visited Melbourne this morning.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—We saw a company which is the eleventh largest tyre company in the world, produces 26,000 tyres a day, employs 5,300 people and has sales in excess of $1 billion. We found that with new investment in recent years—in the last twelve months—with an absolute world state-of-the-art plant, this business is now producing tyres for domestic consumption and exports which are very competitive, but competitive at the rates of tariff which will obtain under the Government's tariff reductions of 15 per cent by 1997 for passenger cars and 5 per cent for truck tyres. The company was making the point that if the Liberal Party's policy of zero tariffs for passenger car tyres and truck tyres were to obtain, then the business would not exist—a business involving 5,300 people and 26,000 tyres a day. It would be under an enormous threat of imports with zero tariff rates—not the Government's 15 per cent for passenger car tyres or 5 per cent for truck tyres, but the zero which would obtain under the Opposition policies.

PARA.TAB: We see in today's Australian, under the headline `Libs pressure McLachlan to justify tariff cuts', that there is a nasty argument going on with the honourable member for Barker and his Party about tariff cuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is McLachlan?
—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory!
—The article says:

ANSWER.PARA: One senior Opposition figure said last night that resistance to the tariff wind-back was "white hot" among manufacturers and Coalition leaders were battling to hold their ground in meetings with business.

The concerns mark the first sign of Opposition disgruntlement over the implementation of the Coalition's Fightback package. Mr McLachlan, in particular, has been privately criticised within the Coalition for his failure to spell out details of the reform agenda and its benefits to manufacturers.

The Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, also faced hostile questioning on the protection issue from Associated Retailers—which includes textile and clothing employers—when he addressed the group in Melbourne last week.
The article mentions a view within the Opposition's structural reform task force. It says:

The Opposition spokesman on industry. . . is facing intense pressure from within the Liberal Party to justify the elimination of protection by the year 2000 by producing a more detailed micro-economic reform timetable.
In other words, the split is on over there.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—The Opposition has the zero tariff proposal and it is finding now that people in business who are prepared to be competitive, prepared to put the investments in, and want to produce a competitive product and can, cannot with a zero tariff. A tariff below the Government's 15 and 5 per cent in this industry would put that industry at risk.

PARA.TAB: I had a question yesterday from the honourable member for McEwen about a computer producer and 40 jobs.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—She ought to consider the 5,300 jobs which exist at Southern Pacific Tyres.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—And what happened when that industry and that company were ripped to pieces by imports coming from the Opposition's zero tariff policies. The Opposition might explain to business some of the other goodies in the Fightback package, such as the zero tariff, and have the honourable member for Barker tell us how they are going to maintain the employment of people in the electorate of Wills, many of whom work in the Southern Pacific Tyre factory.
—So you have changed your minds on tariffs, have you?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo.
—And tell us how this manic ideological obsession with zero tariffs will preserve their jobs.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Given the Prime Minister's well-known interest in and defence of the truth, did the Prime Minister explain to the workers at Southern Pacific Tyres this morning on his visit that the competitiveness of that firm would be greatly improved by the abolition of payroll tax, wholesale sales tax, petrol excise and the rebate of GST on tyres sold for business use under the coalition's Fightback package?
—No, but they did tell me about the loss of competitiveness with a 15 per cent GST on their product. They made that very clear. They all knew what that was about.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Members on both sides will cease interjecting.
—Every motorist in Australia knows that the 15 per cent GST will apply to tyres. They know what zero tariffs mean.

PARA.TAB: Mr Costello interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the honourable member for Higgins interjects again I will name him.

—If you think the employees in the plant are going to regard as a deal a tax on their food, their clothing and their services to remove payroll tax and to remove the excise on petrol, you can think again. They have produced a competitive business. They are standing up against tyre manufacturers around the world, but they cannot at a zero tariff rate. So the hundreds of them who work in the Wills electorate know for sure that the honourable member for Barker's enunciation of the Fightback policy of the Leader of the Opposition would put them out of a job. They worked that out very smartly.
—Can the Treasurer inform the House of the implications of introducing a consumption tax in Australia? What are the Government's intentions in the matter?
—The Government has no intention of introducing a consumption tax because of the—

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members on my left will cease interjecting. The House will come to order.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister might resume his seat. The House will come to order.

PARA.TAB: Mr Smith interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable member for Bass interjects again, I will name him. The House will come to order.

PARA.TAB: Dr Bob Woods interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Lowe! As honourable members on both sides should be aware, and as the honourable member for Kooyong who was interjecting before would most certainly be aware, there have been frequent occurrences in this House in the past when the Prime Minister has decided to answer a question which has been asked of a Minister. I call the Prime Minister.
—My eagerness ran away with me. I will defer to the Treasurer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This had better be good. I thank the honourable member for his question. There has been a great deal of debate in recent times about the consequences of the introduction of a consumption tax in Australia. Much has been made of various modelling exercises which have tried to generate the circumstances and the changes which might occur in Australia as a result of a massive tax shift, involving some $40 billion worth of government money, from one area to another. Of course, these models are only ever as good as the assumptions that are built into them.

PARA.TAB: We notice that the Opposition likes some models which come up with some of its preferred answers and it dislikes others. For instance, the Opposition dislikes the model which says that four out of five taxpayers will be worse off as a result of such an introduction.

We do not have to rely just on theoretical modelling exercises. There are some real life examples of where taxes of this kind have been introduced into economies not that dissimilar to ours. When the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was asked in Hobart last year how similar his proposal was to, say, the introduction of the VAT in Britain, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Well, the closer model would be the New Zealand one. They quite frankly have done a very good job. I've been over there to have a look.
I am not sure, when the Deputy Leader flew to New Zealand and back, whether he noticed that more people were flying out of New Zealand than there were flying into New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: Mr Connolly interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Bradfield!

—I hope he did take close account of what has happened in New Zealand as a result of the introduction of a consumption tax—that is, its model—which it introduced on 1 October 1986. In the year to September 1986, inflation in New Zealand was running at 11.1 per cent. In the year to December 1986 it had risen to 18 per cent; by March it had risen to 18.3 per cent; by June it had risen to 19 per cent and a year later it had subsided slightly to just under 17 per cent. In order to combat that inflationary surge which occurred as a result of the introduction of that new tax, the New Zealand Government had to resort to very tight levels of monetary policy to the point where by June 1987 the 90-day bill rate had reached 19.2 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the Opposition is quick to point out that inflation is not at that level in New Zealand now. Indeed it is not; but let us look at what has happened to the New Zealand economy in the intervening period.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Australian economy?
—The New Zealanders would love to have our record, I can tell you that.
—Order! The honourable member for Moore!

—Out of the 17 quarters since the introduction of the GST, the New Zealand economy has actually shrunk in 11 of them. Why did it shrink? It shrunk basically because there had to be paralysingly high levels of interest rates in order to combat the inflationary surge which came from the introduction of that particular income tax.

PARA.TAB: But let us not rely just on that. Let us look at what an accountant, much beloved of the Opposition, had to say about the introduction of the GST in New Zealand. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The aim of these combined efforts was to ensure the introduction of GST affected all taxpayers in a manner that was tax neutral. Subsequent studies have shown that the introduction of GST and related income transfer measures has not improved the position of low income households in New Zealand. The combination of direct tax and benefits changes has worsened the relative position of low to middle income households which have also borne an increased burden from the introduction of GST.

One does not have to rely on Treasury models. One can look at the real life economic and social laboratory just across the Tasman to see what the consequences may well be in Australia of the introduction of such a tax. That, I might remind the House, was with a GST of 10 per cent, subsequently raised to 12 1/2 per cent, whereas, of course, the Opposition wants to have a tax of 15 per cent.

The whole industry would disappear—even those parts of the industry which could survive now against imports, the ones with a technological advantage or in broadloom work or with a high technological capacity.
