—I direct my question to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. How successful has Medicare been in restricting increases in medical costs faced by Australians who need hospital care? What would be the impact of alternative proposals seeking to increase the number of private patients in public hospitals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, Medicare has been important in maintaining universal access to health care services for all Australians. Critical to its success has been the effective control on fees charged by doctors. The guarantee of free hospital care and the fact that almost two-thirds of all services are bulkbilled has ensured that out-of-pocket costs for average Australians are kept to a minimum.

PARA.TAB: Proof of this lies in the fact that 76 per cent of all services are billed on or below the Medicare benefit schedule with only 3 per cent of services at or above the AMA schedule. Further, public patients receive 56 per cent of all bed days in public hospitals.

It is important when one goes to this question to remind the House again what the fundamentals are in the Opposition's policy. There are four fundamentals that the electors of Wills certainly need to be reminded about. The first is that the Opposition would abolish bulkbilling for all but pensioners. There would be no bulkbilling for people unless they are a pensioner or card holder. Secondly, the Opposition would reduce the rebate, that is, for those who pay the bills the rebate would come back from 85 per cent to 75 per cent of the schedule fee. Thirdly, the Opposition has said that there must be compulsory co-payments. There is no choice about it; if people are in the situation where they are not bulkbilled and are not pensioners, there will be a compulsory co-payment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that what you supported, Brian?
—The honourable member for Lowe will cease interjecting.

—The fourth element of the Opposition's policy means that fees would be charged not according to the medical benefits schedule, but effectively at the level of the AMA schedule, which is 30 per cent above the medical schedule.
—Rubbish!
—I warn the honourable member for Lowe.

—So, under the Opposition's policy, patients would be lured into private insurance but would still pay significant up-front costs. What we are talking about is not the continuation of Medicare but a fundamentally different situation. That is why it is important to take time to explain that. That is why it is important to remember those four assumptions when one sets out to explain the Opposition's policy.

PARA.TAB: Let us take an example of a couple in Wills with an income of around $28,000 who have taken out basic insurance cover. The cost of the basic insurance cover would be $800. In terms of the Opposition policy they would receive a tax credit of $200—a net cost of $600. If, for example, in that family situation the husband suffers chest pains and breathlessness, we are not talking about a situation where there is free access via bulkbilling, via hospital insurance in terms of Medicare; we are talking about a series of stages in which there is a particular charge on top of whatever insurance has been paid for in terms of the illustration I have given.
Mr Costello interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Higgins will cease interjecting.

—For a GP consultation that person is up for an additional $13. When the GP requires that person to have crucial tests, such as an ECG, chest X-ray and blood test, that person has out-of-pocket costs of perhaps $112. When that person goes back to review those tests with the GP, he is up for another $13. When there is the diagnosis of a heart problem and that person is off to see the consultant physician for an initial consultation, another ECG, an exercise ECG and angiogram, that person is up for another $424.

PARA.TAB: By this stage that person must be concerned about the cost, but clearly he has little choice. He goes back to the specialist and pays another $31. He is sent on to the cardiothoracic surgeon and will pay $33 for a consultation. In regard to his admission to a public hospital for a blood test, anaesthetics and direct surgery, we are talking about costs of the order of $885. In all, that person will be up for $1,500 in out-of-pocket costs.

What we are talking about here is not Medicare; we are talking about an American-type situation in which people who have security and are out of work and suffer loss of income are faced with the possibility of massive costs on top of the levy which they have paid and on top of basic level private insurance which they might have.

The reason why Medicare is a universal health care system is that it is popular with the Australian electorate. Medicare has provided for certainty and it has provided for security. It creates a situation in which people who experience that kind of catastrophe are not faced with a series of charges that mount and create the possibility of a family being overwhelmed by those charges. Medicare does not create that situation; it provides very great security. Therefore, it is important that when we go back over these issues, we recall that there are fundamental differences in what the Opposition is proposing. It is not proposing some variation of Medicare. It is proposing a situation in which the costs currently borne by the public sector and borne fairly in terms of community rating and taxation would effectively be shifted onto the individual.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development. Can the Minister inform the House of the results of his consultations last week with the major players in the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations? What prospects does he see for a successful conclusion to the round?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I can remember when the National Party took a lot of interest in agricultural trade. I said in Brussels that it is now high noon for the Uruguay Round, but there is still a danger that it may turn out to be as exciting as the Midday Show.

PARA.TAB: Ostensibly, the objective of all major participants is still to complete the Uruguay Round negotiations by April, but the continuing failure of the EC and some other countries to accept the agriculture package put forward by GATT Director-General, Arthur Dunkel, has stalled progress.

It is particularly worrying that some countries are using this stand-off as a pretext for tabling draft schedules of commitments which depart significantly from the requirements set out in the Dunkel framework. Last week I met with Arthur Dunkel in Geneva; in Brussels and Bonn I had discussions with Mr Delors, President of the EC, Franz Andriessen, Vice President, Mr MacSharry, the Agricultural Commissioner, and German Government representatives. I am sure the Treasurer will be interested that the Belgian Government put up its VAT again by another half a per cent. It is 19-19.5 per cent now. But back to the question: the EC leaders recognise the significance for world economic growth of an early and successful conclusion to the negotiations. They all indicated a determination to reach a conclusion to the Round with political agreement in April. This encouraged me.

In Washington I met with United States trade representative, Carla Hills, Agriculture Secretary, Ed Madigan, and people in the White House, including Clayton Yeutter, and they reaffirmed the very high priority being given by the United States to an early, successful conclusion of the Round.

I was especially encouraged by their view that the issue of protectionism has diminished in the presidential election debates and that a successful conclusion to the Round would be a political plus for President Bush. Also last week the Prime Minister wrote to President Bush and German Chancellor Kohl, stressing the need for commitment to a successful conclusion to the Round at the highest level, and again highlighting the damage that will be done to the world trading system if this is not achieved.

It is heartening again that, following their meeting last week, both President Bush and Chancellor Kohl made a public political commitment to a successful conclusion to the Round. But I must again point out that there are still very difficult technical and political problems to be overcome before the deadlock over agriculture is broken.

Overall, my discussions and the events of last week indicate that the political will is firming up on both sides of the Atlantic for a successful conclusion to the Round. The real test is and continues to be the EC's commitment and whether that will come during the coming weeks. That is really the high noon. It is crucial that the EC find a more flexible approach to agriculture in order that the negotiations can be concluded, and in this Germany has an important role. The Dunkel package contains substantial gains in important areas other than agriculture. These are recognised by the German Government, especially in the light of the pressures it is experiencing from reunification.

So, for this reason, Germany has a central role in ensuring that the totality of the Dunkel package is not sacrificed on the altar of narrow, sectoral interests in the EC. Naturally, it is a matter of great interest to us and great concern to Australia that, if the present stalling of negotiations continues, the prospects for a successful conclusion to the Round within the present timetable will be seriously diminished.

I would like to end by saying that I have also met with Cairns Group ambassadors in Geneva and I am in regular contact with other Cairns Group Ministers to assess appropriate Cairns Group reaction to the state of negotiations. I reassure honourable members who are interested in agricultural trade, particularly on my side of the House, that, as leader of the Cairns Group, Australia will maintain the pressure on all parties concerned and through every channel so that an acceptable outcome can be achieved.

Is it a fact that the Government's own statistics show that the unemployment rate among migrants who have arrived in Australia over the last two years is more than 31 per cent? Is it also a fact that among recent migrants with non-English speaking backgrounds and low levels of skill the unemployment rate is over 40 per cent? Will the Prime Minister now commit to an immediate, substantial reduction in the migration program and to its restructuring to more effectively serve the national interest and the interests of the migrants? If not, why not?
—Are you saying migrants should be sent home if they are unemployed?
—Order! The Leader of the House will cease interjecting.

—The Minister is simply reminding the House of the view of the Liberal candidate for Wills that migrants should be sent home if they cannot find a job. That is the Opposition's policy and the people of Wills should understand it.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. My question related to the Government's policy on immigration and we are interested to hear what it is.

—I know you are embarrassed by him, and he is only hanging on by his fingernails as the candidate. I understand that. The migration program has served Australia well. It has made Australia a stronger, larger, more interesting society than it could ever possibly have been without it. It is a long term policy. As does any long term policy, particularly one which has so many connotations about it, it has varied in number as the years have gone by. It went up to a very high level when Billy Snedden was Minister for Immigration in the 1970s. It came down to about 70,000 in the early 1980s and rose to about 140,000 by the late 1980s, particularly when skills were in demand.

PARA.TAB: Dr Hewson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to hear the answer or not?
—Yes, we do.

—Well, just shut up for a while. Family reunion was an important component. The program has come back since that time to a figure for this year of 111,000, but with a net migration of under 100,000 because 30,000 people left Australia in this current year.

PARA.TAB: I have said, and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has said, that there is currently a review in the normal course of the annual review and consultations under that review, and the findings of that review will be presented to the Cabinet at the appropriate time in April. That is when the Cabinet will give the issue due and appropriate consideration, in the usual time frame, as we normally do, taking all factors into account. The Leader of the Opposition is not motivated by any economic or social disadvantage question here. After all, he believes that if you are unemployed after nine months you are out on your own. That is the extent of his concern about the unemployed. Whether it is an unemployed migrant or an unemployed Australian, he or she is out after nine months.

The other thing is the spending of $750m on TAFE which the Government is prepared to undertake to, amongst other things, improve the access to and the opportunity for courses for migrants, particularly in basic skills, English literacy and basic business skills, which we find thousands of migrants across the country taking. I saw a stack of them in my own electorate just a week ago at the Bankstown TAFE. There was a heap of them there learning English literacy—in the very courses the Opposition says the teaching of is irresponsible because we should not spend the money.

TALK.START.PARA: —We never said that.
—Order! The honourable member for Dundas will cease interjecting.
—I warn the honourable member for Dundas.

—You say that the $750m spent on TAFE was irresponsible, that the One Nation component for TAFE was irresponsible, and that you would not develop TAFE as the third tier of education in Australia, give migrants the opportunities of English language training and business skills training and let them get into the work force. Nor have we heard from the Opposition, when it talks about an intake of 50,000, what the components of the 50,000 will be. When the Opposition talks to the States, it will find them urging an increase in the migration program because they wish to meet the skills areas which are still a problem in certain sectors of the economy.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition will not say what it implies for family reunion. It will not categorise the figure. Perhaps the Leader of the Opposition can tell us which of the 50,000 figure is concessional, which is family reunion, which proportions go to skills in demand and which to business migration. If he wants to be hairy-chested about this issue, let him quantify this afternoon what proportions of the 50,000 he believes ought to be the intake for next year will be in these categories.
Mr Nugent interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Let him tell the people in Wills that there will be no more family reunion for migrants in Wills—

PARA.TAB: Mr Nugent interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Aston will cease interjecting.

—Alternatively, let him say that there will be either skills in demand or business migration instead. What the Leader of the Opposition is about, when there is appropriate concern in the electorate about the migration program at this time, is scoring in the cheapest, lousiest way—
—You are fundamentally divided right down the middle.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—He has tried to score in the cheapest, most unstatesmanlike way on this subject, as he has all of the way through. When I pinned the Opposition in January, Opposition members cried like stuck pigs over this issue. They will cry more when the Government undertakes its review and announces its policy. We do not mind staring you down on any policy; this policy in particular. No jingoism on your part will disguise the social malevolence which motivates you.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: One Nation Package: Science and Technology

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Technology. What initiatives are contained in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement which will benefit Australian science? How will these fit into the Government's long term strategy to link Australian science with national objectives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The One Nation statement has demonstrated yet again the Government's commitment to science and technology as essential components of a competitive and advanced nation. One Nation ensures that we develop Australian ideas for the benefit of Australians. This Government is interested in science at the sharp end. We wish to address that part of the science system where most attention is needed; that area which takes Australian ideas and develops them into products and processes which produce national benefits.

PARA.TAB: This country has a strong science base. We have a surplus of great ideas. We have to link these ideas to the market so that they do not wither on the vine and they do not have to be taken overseas to be developed. Of course, the improved business environment which will arise out of One Nation will, of itself, help to improve the research, development and innovation focus of business enterprises. In addition to this, the statement contains two important initiatives which are directed at better developing Australian ideas. These are: the creation of the Australian Technology Group and the pooled development funds.

I will give some details of the first of these initiatives which has sparked the most interest. The ATG will take technology developed by Australian researchers to the stage at which its commercial potential can be exploited by industry. It will then identify research capabilities and outputs with commercial potential, secure the protection of intellectual property, develop research outputs to the stage where they become of interest to investors, and market the technology. It will also be able to provide some of the funding required to establish the technical quality and commercial viability of intellectual property.

I expect the ATG to be fully operational by the end of the year. I will be appointing a steering group or interim board in the future and the preparation of a detailed business plan will follow the appointment of a chief executive. I have written to more than 80 higher education institutions and technology transfer companies outlining this initiative and seeking their views. I must report that the response has been overwhelmingly positive. I will give a couple of examples. Professor David Craig, President of the Australian Academy of Science, said:

ANSWER.PARA: I welcome the formation of the Australian Technology Group as a new means of promoting commercial development of Australian inventions and know-how.
Professor Frank Larkins, Deputy Vice-Chancellor of Melbourne University, said:
There is a good case for an ATG to play an important role in the commercialisation of public sector research.
Professor Chris Fell, Deputy Vice-Chancellor of the University of New South Wales, said:
I was very pleased to learn. . . of the Government's initiative to establish an Australian Technology Group. . . The objectivity provided by the ATG will assist greatly.
The ATG will ensure that we get the best results for the taxpayers' substantial investment in science, technology and innovation. That is part of the proud tradition of this Government.

PARA.TAB: Commonwealth support for science and technology is at an all-time high at $2.7 billion—29 per cent greater than when we came to office. Industrial R&D has more than doubled in the same period. This financial year has seen a 4.3 per cent increase in science funding through the Budget, a further $10m boost for CSIRO and $20m to help develop a magnesium metal industry in Australia in the electorate of the honourable member for Hinkler.

I am pleased to say that the Government's support for a strong and effective science and technology system will continue through the development of a White Paper on science and technology to be tabled in conjunction with this year's Budget. The White Paper will canvass a number of themes, and I am looking forward to the full support of the Opposition in its preparation. The Opposition spokesman on science has recently been an enthusiastic advocate of Government science policies. For example, he recently launched a report showing that the Government's policy to persuade more girls to study science has been an outstanding success. He has also endorsed the Government's policy on the structure and direction of our premier science agency. I am sure, therefore, that his criticism of the initiatives in One Nation has been an aberration. His attraction to the Government's science policy is utterly understandable. He knows that Fightback offers nothing for science. He knows that it offers nothing, but it takes much.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, this is a gross abuse of Question Time. I ask that you rule that it is a ministerial statement and give the Opposition an opportunity to respond.
—The Minister is answering the question.

PARA.TAB: Dr Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for Goldstein.

—Fightback takes $60m from key science and technology organisations. It takes $39m from energy research. It will take at least $40m from CSIRO through the operation of the GST and the increased deficiency dividend. It will take untold millions from university researchers and government research agencies. The Opposition has continually dodged any opportunity—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. There has been open defiance of Standing Orders, not just today but for some days to come.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been until now, and for many more days to come. You people are just—
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—I have a point of order.
—The House will come to order. The honourable member for Gippsland.
—My point of order is that I would ask the Minister to table the document he is reading from, and then sit down and spare us this nonsensical rubbish.
—There is no point of order.

—I thought for a moment the Opposition spokesman was going to take the opportunity, which he has been offered many times in the past, to deny that government research agencies and universities would be subject to the GST. In fact, he has refused that opportunity. Opposition policy in this area amounts to a declaration of war on Australian scientists. The Opposition sees science as a sideshow, an interesting game being played by absent minded professors in laboratories. In fact, today's scientists are as much at home in the boardroom as they are in the laboratory. They want their work to continue to contribute to national wealth. They will continue to enjoy both material and moral support from this Government.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have a question to you. I refer you to standing order 142, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: Questions may be put to a Minister relating to public affairs with which he is officially connected, to proceedings pending in the House, or to any matter of administration for which he is responsible.

I refer you to a situation in which a government has specifically rejected a particular initiative, either its own or one of another political party. In the light of standing order 142, which uses the words `he is officially connected' and `for which he is responsible', is it therefore in order for Ministers to be asked questions inviting them to comment upon a matter or policy which his or her government has already announced that it does not already operate and, more importantly, has no intention of introducing?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I and other Speakers have said in the past, occupants of the chair are loath to give advisory rulings to members. If the honourable member for O'Connor has a point of order he wishes to raise at any particular time during the proceedings, he can do so.
—Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—During Question Time today the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made two references to alleged recommendations of mine to him as Treasurer concerning the appointment of Mr Bernie Fraser to various positions. He firstly—incorrectly—claimed that I had recommended to him when he was Treasurer that he appoint Mr Fraser as Secretary to the Treasury.

PARA.TAB: The sequence of events was that Mr Stone resigned as Secretary to the Treasury in or about September of 1984. The then Treasurer appointed Mr Fraser. In a subsequent conversation with the Treasurer I indicated to him that I agreed with that appointment, which I did, and I made it publicly clear later on that I did agree with it.It makes no sense to suggest that the appointment was made on my recommendation; no one can tell me the Treasurer rang me and asked me who I would recommend. He was charitable then, but not that charitable.
The second observation is that any suggestion of his which I took him to make during Question Time that I had recommended the appointment of Mr Fraser as Governor of the Reserve Bank—

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not say that.
—He did say that. He changed his story later on. The fact is that I made—

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This was a point of personal misrepresentation, and the honourable member for Bennelong has not indicated where he was misrepresented in this matter. There was no such statement made by the Prime Minister at any point of time, and there are witnesses right around the House to point that out. The suggestion was made that the former Leader of the Opposition recommended to the Prime Minister that he appoint Mr Fraser to the governorship of the Reserve Bank. Therefore, he is erecting a straw man, not making a point of personal misrepresentation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—On the first point of order, the honourable member for Bennelong is in order. He has corrected the record. I am listening carefully to his second point to ensure that he does not introduce new material in his personal explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not seeking to introduce new material. I heard what the Prime Minister said—and I will be interested to hear the tape of the proceedings; if my hearing was defective then I do not have a point of personal explanation. I quite freely acknowledge that. I checked my understanding of what had been said with a number of my colleagues, and I rose because of a belief on my part that the Prime Minister had claimed that I had recommended the appointment of Mr Fraser as Governor of the Reserve Bank. It was a matter of public record at the time that I opposed the appointment of Mr Fraser as Governor of the Reserve Bank—
—All right; you have finished your personal explanation.
—It is on that point—
—Order! You have finished your personal explanation.

—I have not. Do not get the bad habits of your boss on this. You are a very well-respected man on this side of the House and I am not going to be browbeaten by you or any other representatives of the New South Wales Right.
—You have finished your personal explanation.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the Standing Orders are quite clear-cut. The job of members of the House of Representatives is to help the Chair, not hector it. I regard the last set of remarks of the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations as offensive to the Chair, and I ask that you seek their withdrawal.
—With respect to the reference to the Speaker, the honourable member for Bennelong is out of order and should withdraw that reflection upon the Speaker.
—I withdraw it.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Prime Minister claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes. I claim to have been misrepresented by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who claimed that I said that he recommended to me that Mr Fraser be appointed Governor of the Reserve Bank. I never said that and he never recommended it, but he did say to me that he would have appointed Mr Fraser as Secretary to the Treasury. I subsequently appointed him and he congratulated me on the appointment. He was professionally chosen from the Public Service, so how dare the honourable member attack him as Governor.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Prime Minister is now doing the very thing that the Leader of the House enjoined you to prevent us from doing. He is just debating the issue and scoring a political point, and it should not be allowed in personal explanations.
—I believe that the Prime Minister has concluded his personal explanation. There is no further point of order.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
The total failure of the Government to recognise the importance of small business in the Australian economy by the creation of jobs.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the whole of its history this Government has failed small business in Australia. The Australian Labor Party—and it is quite understandable because it constitutes this Government—does not like small business in this nation, does not understand small business in this nation, and in fact has never participated in small business in Australia. One of the reasons for this is that it cannot control small business, it cannot stand over small business, it cannot manipulate small business and it cannot unionise small business. It therefore has no control over small business, which is a freethinking, hardworking group of individuals who simply want this Government off their backs so that they can get on with operating their businesses free of government interference.

PARA.TAB: I can clearly demonstrate this. Nothing has been clearer than the Government's recent statement. After two years it has presented a statement called One Nation. Two years after the release of the Beddall report on small business the Government has released a statement entitled One Nation which is meant to promote jobs, but there is not one mention of small business, one of the major contributors to employment and employment growth. There is virtually no recognition of small business in this One Nation statement. The statement is about one job and one job only, and we know whose job.

The Australian Labor Party has been running a war with small business for years. I am pleased to see that the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) is at the table, because he staked his reputation on the introduction of his report in 1990. Some two years later the Government has introduced what it calls a job statement, One Nation, but there is no mention of the role that small business can play in the creation of jobs in this country. The opportunities for the creation of jobs in the small business area are immense.

I want to go over some of the history of what has happened in small business in recent years. I refer to the report recently handed down by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), which indicates that bankruptcies to the end of June 1991 increased by 53 per cent. During the 1990-91 financial year there were 13,091 individual bankruptcies. Of those bankruptcies 32.1 per cent were business bankruptcies—a staggering figure in this climate. We see a Government that could not even include small business in its One Nation statement. It referred, of course, to the economic conditions. These economic conditions were outlined in the report tabled by the Beddall Committee, which described the economic conditions as the major cause of these bankruptcies.

Let us have a look at them. Interest rates for small business were up to 24 per cent—24 per cent for small businesses struggling to survive. And who put the interest rates up? The man who said we had to have the recession. How on earth could a small business survive with interest rates at 24 per cent? The other areas of cost imposed on small business during that time included increases in government taxes and charges, overhead expenses, credit restrictions and competition and price cutting. We all know about that, but how could small business compete with interest rates at 24 per cent?

The ABS survey in May 1991 showed that small businesses—businesses with fewer than 100 employees—make up more than 50 per cent of the private sector work force in this nation. More than 50 per cent of people were—and I say `were'—employed in the work force in small business. One has only to go along Sydney Road in Wills now to find out what has happened to small business in Australia. If one drives down Sydney Road one can see the shops that are closed, the shops which have been forced out of the business environment by 24 per cent interest rates from the man who was the Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), now the Prime Minister of this nation. These are jobs and job opportunities lost.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology expressed its concerns about the failure rate of small business back in January 1990. The Minister at the table produced the Beddall report—which probably should be called the `meddle report' because it does nothing but meddle in the operations of small business in this country—which put up 66 recommendations. Of those recommendations 43 have been partially implemented or not implemented at all. I will refer the Minister to some of them; I am sure he is familiar with them.

If the Minister looks at recommendations 11 to 26, he will see that these have been only partially implemented. Over the 12 months beginning December 1991 the ABS was commissioned to undertake a study of the Government paperwork burden. Paperwork! That is what small business wants out of its hair. Some of these recommendations have been partially implemented; some the Government has not bothered to implement at all. Recommendation 15 on page 14 has been only partly implemented. Once again it says that a case study program will be set up—a further study. Turning to page 15, recommendation 16 is that there be a study by the Administrative Review Council. What will it produce? More paperwork! It will mean more paperwork for small businesses, which will prevent them from getting on and making a living and surviving, and providing jobs for some of our one million unemployed young Australians. There are tremendous growth opportunities in small business.

On page 21 of that report recommendations 22 and 23 once again have been only partially implemented. They refer to standardised rental leases for commercial properties. They call for a further consultant to investigate and to produce more paper, more red tape, more restrictions and more regulations for small business. In recommendation 25 it is proposed that a comprehensive market research program be done. There will be more paper produced, interfering with the activities of small businesses and the opportunity to get on and make a dollar and to employ people in this nation.
The Minister described this report as his blueprint. I want to quote from a tape entitled Business Essentials, produced by Michael Schildberger in 1990. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Report is my blueprint and I'd hope over the term of this Parliament to implement the vast majority, if not all, of its recommendations.

We can see that the Minister has not achieved that. I think his performance in this area has been pathetic, and I think this stems from his lack of knowledge of what the business community is all about.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to see a report, in the Australian Small Business Review not long after the Minister was appointed, which described the Minister's background. It said that he had worked for the Commonwealth Bank for 12 years, finishing up in a lending capacity. People in the lending industry are the people who small businesses have to deal with at the moment. They are making life difficult for small business, and this is coupled with the high interest rates imposed on small business by the Prime Minister when he was Treasurer.

I think the Minister suffers from a lack of understanding of what small business is all about. His Labor back bench colleagues do not have confidence in him. There are honourable members opposite who know they can do better. We have only to look at some of them. There is the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton); he knows he can do better. There is the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) who is not in the House at the moment. There is the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price). The honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) knows he can do better. He knows that he wants the job; he has got his eye on it. The honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) knows that he can do better in the job than the Minister. Even the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) thinks he can do the job better.

Seven of the report's recommendations relate to wholesale sales tax. Let us have a look at them. They were issues that the Minister identified in his report, from recommendation 27 through to recommendation 33—all relating to problems being experienced with the wholesale sales tax. Why does the Minister not follow the lead we have set under the Fightback package? He should have a good read of it. He should abolish wholesale sales tax, abolish petrol taxes and abolish payroll tax, which is the single most important issue working against small business and the creation of employment. Why does the Minister not abolish it? He should pick up the Fightback! brochure and read it. He should read all of the policies we have set out to encourage small business to expand and to create employment opportunities for the one million people that the Government has put out of work.

The Minister has really squibbed it on a number of issues, including eight major issues. If I had adequate time I would run through them. The Minister knows the eight issues he has walked away from. Those issues are staring him in the face. They are issues that he knows are important but he has not got the power in Cabinet. He has not got the backing from his Party. He has no support on the back bench. He has no support in Caucus. He cannot get those recommendations through. He could not even get a statement on small business incorporated into the One Nation package.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a disgrace.

—That is a disgraceful effort. In the One Nation document there is page after page after page of deliberate omission of small business, which is one of the most important employment generating activities in the whole of the Australian business community. There is no recognition of small business and no recognition of jobs. I thought it might have been just the Minister, but I know that the Prime Minister has no sympathy for and no understanding of small business. He has never worked in the business sector and does not understand what the business sector does. He does not understand how freethinking, enterprising, hardworking small business people run their businesses, create wealth for this nation and create employment opportunities for our young people. The ALP has absolutely no regard for small business at all. It has no understanding of it. It cannot unionise small business; it has no control over it; it is not able to manipulate it.

PARA.TAB: I refer the Minister again to the Fightback package, because we have spelt out our policies. We know what is required by small business; we are going to move into the small business community. Those in the small business community are welcoming us with open arms with our Fightback package because they know that we have the recipe for their success, to put them back on economic ground which is solid and secure for them, their families and their employees and their families.

We are going to abolish the wholesale sales tax. That is an issue that those opposite have been ducking for over two years. By reducing petroleum taxes we are going to make it cheaper for people to get to work. We will reduce the petrol excise and make it beneficial for people to get to their place of employment. We are going to abolish payroll tax. If the Minister talks to anyone in his State or in Victoria or in any other State, he will find that payroll tax is detrimental to increased employment of people within small business.

The lump sum superannuation tax will be abolished; the training guarantee levy will be abolished; customs duty will be abolished; and the coal export duty will be abolished. They are massive changes to improve the lot of small business people in this country.

The Minister has failed small business in Australia. He has failed to create thousands of jobs in the private sector; he has failed to implement his report; and he has failed to reduce the one million unemployment queue. I believe that the Minister should resign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —If this were not a serious topic it would be quite amusing to have this charade that we have just had taken on here. What is very interesting and what we have to ask ourselves is: why was the shadow Minister for small business, the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser), not in the chamber when one of his backbenchers delivered a speech on this matter of public importance. The shadow Minister is rightly—
—You don't know who it is.

—He was not here during the introduction. Nobody in the country knows who he is; that is the problem. But what is interesting is that, when this very important subject about small business was brought into the House, it was not the shadow Minister who brought the matter of public importance to the House; he was not here when his backbencher got up to speak. The shadow Minister has not spoken in this House and has not had a matter raised in this House for 12 months. The last time he raised a matter of public importance was in February 1991. That was the last time he thought small business was important.

PARA.TAB: I do not know where the copy of the One Nation statement came from that the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) had, because in the One Nation statement there is the agenda item set by the small business community.

What is really significant about the way this Government has treated small business—unlike the Opposition—is the way that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of this country has been available to small business. On 10 April 1991 the Prime Minister, then Treasurer, met with the small business community—not for half an hour but for 2 1/2 hours. That meeting was the most significant that that community had ever had. If those opposite talk to people from the small business coalition those people will tell those opposite that it was the most important meeting they have ever had.
Mr Ronaldson interjecting—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Order! The honourable member for Ballarat!

TALK.START.PARA: —What was even more—
—I warn the honourable member for Ballarat.

—Even more significant is that, when we were putting forward the proposal for the economic statement which brought forward One Nation, the Prime Minister made specific reference of his specific intent to talk to and to consult with the small business community.
—He was taken screaming to them. He reluctantly met them, and you know it.
—Order! The honourable member for Forrest!
—He met here in Canberra with the small business community. The truth of the matter is that the first group contacted was the small business community.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If those opposite do not believe this assertion, they should talk to John Martin from the Confederation of Australian Industry—he is the coordinator of the small business coalition—and check the facts, because the facts are wrong in the way those opposite have portrayed them.
—They are wrong in the way you have portrayed them.
—Order! The honourable member for Corinella!

—All that those opposite have to do is to check the facts. They can talk to John Martin. They probably do not even know who John Martin is or where the Confederation of Australian Industry is. It is just typical. Those opposite do not know who is in small business. They go along to the Liberal Party branch meetings and say, `Let's have a little razz and talk about motherhood small business'. They do not do anything for it.
—Wait until you live it like I do.
—Order! The honourable member for Corinella!
—I have lived it.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Corinella.

—What is more important is that this Government has taken small business seriously. It is the first government in history to do so. It is the only government to do it. Those opposite talked about the recommendations from the House of Representatives committee. Sixty of the 66 recommendations have been wholly or partly implemented. It is the most comprehensive implementation of a parliamentary committee report that this Parliament has ever seen. Those opposite who belong to parliamentary committees know that the most difficult thing is to get any recommendations implemented, let alone 60 out of 66.
—Particularly when you are in government.
—Order! The honourable member for Dundas!
—There were no committees when you were in government.
—We gave detailed responses.
—The honourable member for Dundas will cease interjecting.

—I want to move on to what was in the One Nation statement for small business because obviously the honourable member for Bendigo needs to be educated, and at the same time maybe we can educate some more of the coalition members.The One Nation package included an increase in funding from $4m to $12m for the export access program. This program is specifically targeted to help small business gain entry into the export market. What is unique about this program is that it is a Government program administered not by the Government but by the Australian Chamber of Manufactures. Perhaps some of those Opposition members from Victoria should talk to members of their State division of the

SPEECH.PARA: Chamber of Manufactures and see what they think about export access. Funding for this Government initiative has been trebled in the One Nation statement.

PARA.TAB: Small business brought to the attention of the Prime Minister the issue of the 18 July due date for income tax. That was deferred until 18 December as a result of those representations.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were the ones who introduced it.

—We were responding to the small business community. Furthermore, after listening to the concerns of the small business community about the superannuation guarantee levy, the Government responded to that issue. I now refer to the pool development funds, which I think are one of the most innovative things any government has ever done for small business. Honourable members opposite probably do not even know what they are, so I will explain.

PARA.TAB: The pool development funds are aimed at enabling small businesses to grow. The problem that small businesses have always had in this country is that the only way they could grow was through debt. Through the pool development funds, small businesses can now grow through equity. The last thing a small business needs when it is in a growth phase is more debt. The pool development funds will allow growth through equity. They are specifically a small to medium size business initiative and apply only to companies whose capital is $30m or less. It is a specific and directed initiative. When the Opposition was in government it never did anything for small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Small business made profits then.

—Small business is much more profitable under this Government. I turn now to an issue which is considered a panacea by the Opposition—the abolition of payroll tax. Payroll tax is held up as one great example of what the Fightback package will do for small business. The Opposition has got it wrong, because 95 per cent of small businesses pay no payroll tax. What the Opposition is actually going to do is take away a competitive advantage of small business and turn it into a disadvantage.

PARA.TAB: Small business's biggest competitive disadvantage is big business. Big business pays payroll tax. The local corner store or a shop which is trying to sell, for example, shoes has to compete against Coles-Myer.

TALK.START.PARA: —It goes through to the consumer.
—Order! The honourable member for Moore!

—The only competitive advantage that such a corner store has is that it does not pay payroll tax. Coles Myer will get the benefit of the Opposition's abolition of payroll tax, not the local corner store. If honourable member's opposite talk to small business people they will find that 95 per cent do not pay payroll tax.
—You don't understand the system.
—Order! The honourable member for Moore will cease interjecting.
—Honourable members should check their figures because they have got it wrong, wrong, wrong. This Government has done an enormous amount for small business.
—Damage.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Moore.

—I will just talk about what will happen should the coalition come to office. The coalition is talking about how it will bring in a goods and services tax. Many Ministers have talked about the difficulties and problems associated with business and the GST. I will talk specifically about the problems of small business. The honourable member for Bendigo referred in his speech to the fact that the Opposition would get rid of the wholesale sales tax. He said that this would be terrific for small business. However, there are 930,000 reasons why we should not abolish the wholesale sales tax and replace it with a GST. Currently there are about 70,000 wholesale sales tax collection points. Under the coalition's so-called Fightback package, there will be over one million collection points. Guess who will collect it? Small business will. What does that do to those small businesses? As has been pointed out, it puts an enormous burden on small business administration.

PARA.TAB: If honourable members opposite do not believe that, they should check the situation in countries where a GST has been introduced. Let us take the example of the United Kingdom. What is the burden on small business there in collecting the VAT—a sister tax to the GST? Some 2 per cent of turnover of small business goes in cost of administration. For big business—the mate of honourable members opposite—that percentage is 0.003 of turnover. In New Zealand 25 per cent of the GST goes in the cost of collecting it. The New Zealand Government collects, I think, about $5 billion. However, it costs $1.25 billion to collect it. Government does not pay that; small business does. That is what honourable members opposite are offering small businesses in Australia—a tax that will drive them into the wall.

Honourable members opposite have lately been citing the example of Canada. The Independent Business Association of Canada, the largest small business representative body in Canada, surveyed its members. It got over 25,000 responses. What did those respondents say? After 12 months of a Canadian GST, 71 per cent of those respondents said that the GST has had a negative impact on their business; it has forced business out. What is happening in Canada—maybe we are a bit luckier in Australia—is that Canadians are shopping in the United States. People here probably think that it is great that we do not have a common border. The GST is the biggest and most onerous burden ever put on small business. It will drive small business to the wall. It is the one issue that will drive small business to vote for the Labor Party.

Honourable members opposite may think when they go to their local Liberal Party branch meetings and talk to people who purport to be small business people that they represent small business. However, I suggest that honourable members opposite get out and talk to the real people involved in small business, as I do. Talk to the people who represent them. Talk to the business people on the shop floor, as I do in every State in this country. They will tell honourable members opposite they do not support a GST.

What small people are concerned about, as was revealed in the report that was mentioned before, is the complexity of the GST. We are addressing those issues. They did not want to throw out the baby with the bath water. However, they want a system that is efficient and able to be administered. A GST would drive them to the wall.

In many other issues Opposition members have missed the boat. However, probably the way in which they have most missed the boat is that they have never really talked to the small business community. When I became Minister it became obvious to me that there was no real mechanism for talking to the small business community. The small business community in Australia comprises 800,000 individuals. It has never been a joiner. We have heard from Peter Boyle of ASBA in Victoria on many occasions. ASBA has 7,000 members, so it is not really representative. I have often said to Peter Boyle that he should recruit as many people as he can so at least his organisation can be representative.

What we did as a government and what I did as Minister was to ask how we can create a better mechanism. We established an organisation called the Small Business Forum, comprising 35 industry associations ranging from the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Chamber of Commerce, the Chamber of Manufactures, ASBA, COSBOA and the Professional Women's Association. All of those organisations meet with me twice a year and set an agenda. They found it so useful that they themselves formed another organisation called the Small Business Coalition. That Small Business Coalition has the driving agenda for small business. It is the one mechanism that government has in order to talk to the small business community. It truly represents the broad breadth of the small business community in Australia.

What the Opposition has never really understood about small business is that we need to treat it as an industry. It has common problems. What we really have to do is look at what the industry is. Small business is 96 per cent of all business in Australia; it is 50 per cent of private sector employment; it is 40 per cent of GDP. If we treat it as an industry, we can attack the common problems—lack of management skills and lack of capital.

When the Australian Chamber of Commerce did its own survey of its membership it found that lack of management skills was the prime reason for small business failure. It is not necessarily the case that if someone is a good tradesman he can become a good business operator. Small business people need management skills. It is particularly important that we face these issues and that we face them across the whole area of small business.

It was interesting to hear the honourable member for Bendigo say that small business did not welcome the economic statement. He may think that is the truth. However, the Motor Trades Association of Australia is a reasonably representative body of small business. It represents service station owners, motor car dealerships—people in all the motor trades. What did that association say in a press release about the economic statement which it issued on 26 February 1992? It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The measures for reform of depreciation rates will be especially welcomed. . .
The capital gains tax exemption on Goodwill will be increased from 20 per cent to 50 per cent.

In regard to the deferral of company tax, the MTAA said that it was a good statement for small business. I would like to come back to that very specific issue because the deferral of capital gains tax roll-over is one that I have pursued hardest of all the issues that I have pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —You got it from Fightback.

—No, they got it from me. What the Opposition has done in Fightback is give a capital gains tax roll-over to big business, not to small business. The honourable member does not even know what is in his own package. If the honourable member reads Fightback! he will see that what it talks about is an asset.

PARA.TAB: So if BHP sells a Caterpillar D9 dozer for $4m and rolls it over BHP, not the small business operator, pays the capital gains tax. Our plan is specifically about small business. It is the option that small business put forward. The most important part is that this Government listens to small business.

Small businesses do not even know who the shadow Minister is. Those opposite should ask him about that because he never even talks to them, and they think he is irrelevant to the real issues of small business. If honourable members opposite do not believe that, they should go out and talk to small business as broadly as I do—but not at the local Liberal Party branch meeting, because that does not count. I am talking about the real people in small business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for this opportunity to speak on small business. As I have advised the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) by way of interjection, until it comes to a time when he is living small business on a daily basis he will never understand what people at the coalface have to do to make sure that his taxes are paid, his payroll taxes are paid and all the imposts he has on small business are paid.

PARA.TAB: I have learned from the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) that this Minister came from the banking system, where he was a lending officer. I put it to this Parliament that he has been having a lend of the Australian people since he took the job as Minister for Small Business. In fact, he should be called the Minister for small business destruction, because that is what it is his Party's custom to do. I notice that the Economic Plan for the 1990s put out by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) states under the heading `Investing in small business' that under One Nation the Government is `getting the banks off the back of small business'. Who put them on the backs of small business? It was this Labor Government. It was mentioned by one of this Government's Ministers during Question Time that in New Zealand bank bill rates are at some 19 per cent. Was it not this Government that recently had bank bill rates on small business in Australia at some 18 per cent? It just took New Zealand a while to catch up.
As far as payroll tax goes, the Government is patently mistaken, because it takes only a few more than 20 people to get a small business into the payroll tax scales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not any more.

—That is the case in Victoria; come down and have a look. None of the Government Ministers ever come to Victoria. I cannot understand why not. The Economic Plan also mentions `improving capital availability'. Government members know that the banks have been trampling all over small business in Australia, especially Victoria. The Economic Plan states that the Government is `providing increased relief from capital gains tax'. The Government took that straight from the Fightback package. It states that the Government is `deferring company tax'. The Government introduced the prepayment of company tax; it is taking it off small businesses after it only recently introduced it. The Minister is saying, `What a great guy I am; what a terrific guy I am'. He puts the impost on them and then he takes it off, saying, `Gee, I am terrific. I am really good'. Does the Minister think that the small business community believes him?

PARA.TAB: Yesterday the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) said in this place that 75 per cent of the jobs in Australia are in small business. A few figures have been mentioned today: the honourable member for Bendigo said 50 per cent—

TALK.START.PARA: —He would be right.
—Yes, he would be right. The honourable member for Shortland said 75 per cent, and the Minister did not even mention it because he does not know how many people or how many jobs should be created.

PARA.TAB: As far as payroll tax goes, I know that when small businesses get close to the barrier with the number of people who are employed—honourable members on this side of the House know about this because they talk to the small business people in their electorates who employ the 75 per cent with jobs—they say, `We will not employ any more because it will take us into the area where we are paying another impost'; that is, payroll tax. They stop it right there.

How can one expect small business in Australia to survive under the Government's regime of interest rates over 18 per cent? The Minister should look at me because this is what his regime has done—18 per cent for nearly 18 months, and he expected small businesses to survive! We could not survive. When we started paying the banks, what happened if we dropped over our overdraft limit? Remember that when the Liberal Party was in power we paid less but now under Labor we pay a bit more; we pay a bit over the prime rate. It was the Labor Government which did that. Small business pays over the prime rate now, and it pays an extra little levy if it goes over its overdraft for a day of 5 per cent on the whole amount. That is where the honourable member for Bendigo gets his 24 per cent figure. No wonder we cannot employ people.

We have to paint the picture of what is happening in Australia at the moment. I refer to the speech made by the honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey) yesterday when she said that, whatever the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) postures about, he cannot hide the fact that `officially we have 920,000 Australians unemployed; that 1 1/2 million Australians cannot get a job or are working fewer hours than they would like'. If the Minister would like 50 examples, he should come to Dandenong in my electorate of Corinella and have a look at the people who are working one, two or three days a week where two years ago they had a full time job and were looking for overtime. The honourable member continued:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . hidden figures are 262,000 families which have the chief breadwinner unemployed; and that 218,000 children are living in a family where no-one has a job.
That is what this Government has done to Australia; it is disgusting. In today's Herald-Sun an article headed `Long term jobless won't change—study' states:

PARA.TAB: The Australian National University study found about 275,000 people unemployed for more than 12 months were unlikely to find jobs in the "medium term".

SPEECH.PARA: That is, if unemployment stays around 8.5 per cent. But if we have unemployment at 11.5 per cent, where we are headed under the present regime, the number of long term unemployed in Australia will rise to 425,000. It is a sad tragedy.

PARA.TAB: I will just go back to the Government's Economic Plan for the 1990s. The process that the Government has tried to inflict on the Australian people is so old. It says, `Tourism takes off', yet a major hotel in Brisbane worth around $100,000 sold for $17m. A major institutional investor said, `I am getting out of tourism under this system. We cannot take it'. That is small business—it sold for $17m. That goes right across Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Penalty rates, too.

—Penalty rates are killing tourism; they are part of this Government. Not only does this plan contain old, rehashed ideas and have a picture of the honourable member for Fraser on the back but it also shows a 20-year old photo of the Prime Minister. All the policies that have been there for 10 years are represented by that photograph. The Government is trying to inflict the same misery on the Australian people that the Whitlam Government did and every other Labor government has done.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at what the Victorian Government has done. What it loves is debt. But what debt does is drive up interest rates. When interest rates are driven up what happens to small businesses? They put off people; they get smaller; and the spiral gets to the point where they go out of business, as was mentioned by the honourable member for Bendigo, and end up losing everything.

I say to Government members that they would never have had to turn around and fire someone in their own business and say to that person, a family breadwinner, `I am sorry, I haven't got a job for you tomorrow. We are not turning the figures'. That breadwinner then has to go home to the household and say, `I have lost my job'. There is no-one on the Government side of the House who has ever understood the process of having to put people off. Not until those opposite have been through that and have understood the pain and misery of having to put someone off because they are not doing the trade through the recession we had to have will they find out what it is like. They will have that pain in their guts that no-one can understand. They will understand what it is like to have to kowtow to the bank just to get that little extra money to survive through the next week.

What this Labor Government has done has been horrific for our community, especially in Victoria. It has tried to wash away all the problems. The Prime Minister has described the Opposition Fightback package as `sterile accountancy'. But Terry Vine puts it beautifully by saying, `I have heard his own efforts'—that is, the Prime Minister's—`labelled as creative accountancy'. The Government is putting the Australian community on Bankcard, and small business will be the losers.

Small business has the greatest opportunity to employ people across Australia. As the honourable member for Shortland pointed out yesterday, 75 per cent of businesses are involved in the small business area. I can list a number which are no longer there, including a pub at Upper Beaconsfield that closed down last week because it could not make ends meet. A pub could not make ends meet! It cited payroll tax and business charges as the reasons. I have a list of 130 business that we canvassed in the last month and the problems they cited, including: Bradford Insulation, payroll tax; Country Park Holdings, payroll tax—is this not amazing?; HDT Special Vehicles—we know the tax such businesses pay under this Government—payroll tax; and Heka and Co. (Citroen), payroll tax and government taxes.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I could go on. One of the major things all of these businesses said was that they felt utterly betrayed and neglected by government. We heard the phrase, `Politicians do not know what is happening'. They said, `Russell, thanks for coming'. The Managing Director of Bilcon Engineering, Stella Axarlis, said, `Congratulations on your Fightback package. I will be pleased to take this to my employees and show the benefits for this company'.

Our package will provide benefits for those employees and this company so that it can survive and grow. We will provide incentives, reduce taxes and provide opportunities for the 40 per cent to 50 per cent of young people around my electorate of Corinella who need this help. The honourable member for Holt, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), knows of the tragedy of unemployment in our area. Government members should be ashamed of themselves. I do not know how they can stand anywhere and purport to support small business. They have walked away from small business. They should not even bother to stand up to discuss it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a fascinating matter of public importance. It is fascinating because of, firstly, the absence of the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) and, secondly, the fact that the MPI is being led by two oncers—two Victorian members, the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) and the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Broadbent)—who will not be back. The honourable member for Bendigo might not have been sitting in his seat, but he will not have any seat for much longer after that contribution from his side of the House.

PARA.TAB: The contribution from both honourable members started off in very similar vein to an MPI we had on this issue about 13 months ago, led by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Forrest, who has now been relegated to silence on this issue. That debate about 13 months ago was all about how hopeless the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) supposedly was.

Fortunately for the Opposition, I have only 10 minutes within which to speak, so I cannot read out all the quotes I would like to about the Minister for Small Business, so I will give those opposite just two. The first one today for their edification—I hope everyone is listening—is from the Small Business Coalition at its meeting with the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), on Wednesday, 13 November 1991. At paragraph 1.2 it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The meeting with the former Treasurer, the Honourable Paul Keating, in April 1991 represented a major step for the small business sector.
In the next paragraph it says:

In this regard the SBC acknowledges the role and energy of small business Minister David Beddall in genuinely seeking to harness the participation of the sector he represents. The SBC considers David Beddall has, in a very short time, capitalised and cajoled action on a series of collaborative initiatives involving industry and Commonwealth and State governments in a range of interdisciplinary areas.
Then there was a presentation by the Small Business Coalition to the Federal Government earlier this year, on Thursday, 6 February. On that occasion it said:

We believe that your interest in us is the result of the establishment of the Beddall Committee in 1988, the Committee's very fine report and the subsequent appointment of Mr Beddall to the first Ministry of small business. We are pleased that this process is continuing, most recently with the Government's response to the Committee report. Mr Beddall deserves a great deal of credit for the status we now have.
I am sorry to ruin the speeches of the oncers; I am sorry I had to do that to them; but I am even more sorry that I do not have more than 10 minutes in which to read more quotes.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that the GST package is all about a Thatcherite English solution: abolish the middle class with all the small business people in it—the newsagents, the publicans, the chemists and so forth—and divide it between the rich and the poor. I say this to honourable members opposite: the first Hewson Minister for small business will be the last Hewson Minister for small business because, by the time those opposite have finished one term of government, there will be no small business left in this country.

What I find equally amazing is the scurrilous misquoting of the One Nation statement by the honourable member for Bendigo. He said that One Nation did not mention small business. Then when he got a couple of sighs from the Minister and me, he very quickly ameliorated that remark and mumbled something else. Just for the edification of the honourable member for Bendigo, I think he should get out the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and look at page 9 and page 10, and page 19 and page 21. When he has finished that, he should get out the statement and look at pages 71, 74, 75, 77 and 93. When he has finished that, he ought to look at what the Australian Hotels Association said recently. It said that, as an organisation of mainly small business operators, working in the tourist industry, it would seem that the disadvantages of a consumption tax are certain, and what is not certain is any of the benefits. It went on to conclude, `. . . then it is difficult to see why such a tax reform is necessary'.

When those oncers opposite have finished looking at this, they ought to look at the last round of bankruptcies. The provisional data showed that the number of bankruptcies fell by 13.2 per cent, not seasonally adjusted, in the December quarter, the first decline since the December quarter of 1989. The fact of the matter is that this Government has not only got its act together on small business, but it is politically putting a big hole in what those opposite have wrongfully described in the past and thought of as their own natural constituency.

In the time remaining to me, I just want to draw the attention of small business to two very stressful points for small business that are on their way in the Hewson GST package. Under the Fightback plan, all small businesses in Australia would effectively become agents for the Australian Taxation Office, completing consumption tax collection sheets after hours when the business is closed or on weekends. As we know, most small business people basically work seven days a week. Those opposite want to have them work the equivalent of eight days a week—unpaid on the eighth for the Tax Office. The shopkeepers of Kogarah and Rockdale in my electorate would become unpaid clerks for the Tax Office during their personal time—or their GST imposed quiet periods, I say to the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello). The Minister for Small Business, who is sitting at the table, has already cited the Canadian Federation of Independent Business Studies. I bet those opposite will not circulate that information to their branch members.

The second thing I want to warn the small business community about is this other absolutely amazing impost on small business being proposed by the Opposition; that is, each fortnight the approximately 500,000 registered unemployed and getting the dole would have to obtain from business people two written certificates certifying that they were seeking work on their premises. That is a national total of about 26 million certifications a year.

The Department of Employment, Education and Training has estimated that a six-minute interview would multiply to about 1,824 person years per annum provided by the employers—that is, principally the small business community—at a cost of $72m each year. In my electorate, for instance—and for that matter, Mr Deputy Speaker, in yours next door—that means any people running a business within a few miles of the Hurstville or Rockdale CES office would be extending their volunteer service for the Tax Office to include CES duties as well.

It is no wonder that the Opposition runs about the country pledging a smaller, leaner, meaner Public Service because the Opposition will have the small business community doing the jobs of public servants—unpaid, after hours and on weekends.

If that is not enough, I invite those opposite to consider the cost of their GST solution. In New Zealand—the Opposition's laboratory—the cost to the business sector of collecting the GST has been more than one-quarter—that is, 25 per cent—of the total revenue collected. Our Government has estimated an additional 600 public servants would be needed. In Canada and New Zealand, the tax office staff went up by one-third—and those opposite, supposedly, want to get bureaucrats off the back of small business! That is their catchcry. What a joke!
I think it is worth while quoting the experience of Canada yet again. For a small business with an annual turnover of less than $100,000, the compliance cost was 9 per cent of turnover.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey) should put that in her local paper. For a large business with an annual turnover of more than $5m—the real mates of the Liberal Party in Victoria in particular—the compliance cost was but 0.18 per cent of turnover. Which party is the party of small business and which is the party of big business? Which party wants to put the impost on small business in paperwork? Which party wants to put the impost on small business in terms of cost, and who wants to take it off big business in terms of an existing tax?

PARA.TAB: The Minister at the table has already described the inarticulate folly of the Opposition's solution in regard to payroll tax. It is no solution for small business. It is no solution at all—and those opposite know it. I want to put to those opposite that they should have a good hard look at the One Nation statement, at the changes to the capital gains tax, at what we have done about getting the banks off the back of small business by changing the tax legislation—an idea that those opposite are still grappling to come to grips with.

Those opposite should have a look at the guaranteed prescribed minimum on the superannuation levy; have a look at the triple funding for the export access program; and have a look at the depreciation of asset changes in the One Nation statement. All will have a material effect on small business—not BHP, CSR or their mates in the Melbourne Club, small business. (Time expired)
