DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: Refurbishment and fit-out of Juliana House, Phillip, ACT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Refurbishment and fit-out of Juliana House, Phillip, ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: Juliana House is a Commonwealth owned office building constructed in 1969 and consists of a basement, nine office levels and a rooftop plant room. It provides approximately 6,700 square metres of accommodation.

PARA.TAB: The building is located in the Woden Town Centre adjacent to a number of other Commonwealth owned office buildings. It is in need of major refurbishment, including the upgrading of air-conditioning, lighting, lift, electrical and fire services to bring them up to the standards required of modern office accommodation and current building regulations.

An extensive examination of the options for the future use of Juliana House, including a possible sale, demonstrated that a refurbishment was the most cost effective course of action. The refurbishment has been designed to protect the Commonwealth's investment in the building and to maintain its income earning capacity. The Government approved the design and commencement in 1991-92 of the refurbishment and fit-out of Juliana House at a limit of cost estimate of $8.27m, subject to normal Public Works Committee processes. Subsequently, approval was obtained to increase project funding to $8.78m at February 1992 prices to allow for the inclusion of additional works associated with improving lift response times in the overall lift upgrade.

Following refurbishment and fit-out, the building will be occupied by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, which is consolidating its accommodation holdings in the Woden Town Centre. The Department will pay a market rent for the premises and the cost of the fit-out will be incorporated in the rental.

The Department of Health, Housing and Community Services is currently dispersed in a number of locations in the Woden-Weston Creek area, including some privately leased space which is below acceptable standards. In addition to maximising the operational efficiency of the Department by consolidating its accommodation in the Government precinct in Woden, relocation to Juliana House will enable the privately leased accommodation to be surrendered, resulting in savings in the order of $1.9m per annum in the private rent bill. The project is estimated to take approximately 15 months to complete and will cost $8.78m at February 1992 current prices. I table the supporting drawings and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In agreeing to this motion I will just make one observation. The way the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) has presented this reference to the Public Works Committee, it almost sounds like a fait accompli. In one section, the Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government approved the design and commencement in 1991-92 of the refurbishment and fit-out of Juliana House at a limit of cost estimate of $8.27m, subject to the normal Public Works Committee processes.

It would almost appear that the work has already been done. Perhaps the tenders have not yet been let—just about everything else has. The Government ought to show due regard to the processes of the Parliament in particular and the very important role that the Public Works Committee plays in assuring that government expenditure on public works is properly accounted for and duly administered.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Works Committee: Christmas Island rebuilding program

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Christmas Island rebuilding program.

SPEECH.PARA: The alignment of conditions on Christmas Island with mainland standards is part of a broader government policy aimed at the integration of Australia's Indian Ocean territories within Australia. This policy was formally expressed in 1983 when the Government decided that the objectives of the Government's policies be that the Indian Ocean territories be made permanent Australian territories and be integrated with Australia. Amongst the many changes required to bring this into effect is the introduction of mainland laws.

PARA.TAB: Negotiations are now proceeding with the Western Australian Government to administer Western Australian laws in their territories on an agency basis with effect from 1 July 1992. The aged and deteriorated existing infrastructure of the island was built to meet the needs of a mining operation and the consequent needs of the mine workers and their families. It has served the present population of approximately 1,500 people. However, this infrastructure is generally not built or maintained to current mainland Australian standards. Where the infrastructure was of an adequate standard, substantial repair and maintenance are now required.

The building program will provide for substantial new infrastructure for the island. The Government has already committed $37m over the next five years for the most urgent of these works, subject to the endorsement of the Public Works Committee. These include a new and upgraded sewerage system and water supply, a new hospital, a new police station, extensions to the school and upgraded housing. Extensions to other works are included in the overall building program, which is preferred as a whole to the Public Works Committee. Possible funding for those other works will be considered by the Government following the Committee's report. The fuel facilities on the island are to be upgraded under a commercial agreement outside the building program.

The estimated cost of the whole of the works to be referred to the Public Works Committee is $132m at January 1992 prices. The program is proposed to be carried on in two stages over a 10-year period, with the first stage planned to commence in 1992-93. Various urgent works in the areas of communications, sewerage, and water supply are now being implemented, using funds available from the current financial year. These works are consistent with the rebuilding program. I table the supporting drawings and commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no doubt the Public Works Committee will take great interest in this whole project, which is not insignificant. By the time the project reaches completion it will no doubt cost considerably more than the $132m estimated for the next 10-year period at 1992 prices. This is quite a generous public works program for the population of Christmas Island—some 1,500 people. I am not saying that it is not needed. It works out at approximately $100,000 per resident, which is not insignificant, and no doubt would be of considerable interest to residents in other parts of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I have a couple of other interesting comments to make: firstly, the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) notes that negotiations are proceeding with the Western Australian Government to administer Western Australian laws in territories such as Christmas Island. I find that rather curious, considering that the Government made a considered decision to put Christmas Island in the electorate of the Northern Territory. I just make that observation. If it is seen that the Western Australian Government is the most appropriate to administer those laws, I question whether Christmas Island has been put in the electorate of the Northern Territory for political purposes.
Mr Beddall interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is for the purposes of political considerations, I would suspect. Added to that, of course, is this rather large expenditure. I am not saying it is not needed, but it is rather large. One wonders whether there might not be another interest there. It is also interesting to note who is the Administrator of Christmas Island at present, but I will not go into that at the moment. I will leave my comments there at this stage, but no doubt the Public Works Committee will look at this with due diligence.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY REFORM AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 24 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill represents an important element of the Government's construction industry reform strategy. This is an essential element of the Government's micro-economic reform agenda.

PARA.TAB: The reform and development of the construction industry is vital to the national economy. The construction industry is one of this country's largest industries. It has an annual expenditure in excess of $40 billion, employs more than 500,000 people and accounts for over 60 per cent of Australia's gross fixed capital expenditure. The Government's reform strategy is directed at substantial improvements in productivity and efficiency in the industry. Because of the links the construction industry has with other key sectors—particularly mining, transport and tourism—reforms achieved in the construction industry will flow on through the economy generally.

The purpose of the Bill is to establish the Construction Industry Development Agency, which will be the catalyst for change and development in the industry. The Construction Industry Development Council will also be established to be a broad-based national consultative and advisory forum for the industry. The construction industry reform strategy was launched by the then Prime Minister on 3 December 1991. Its objective is to develop a reliable and internationally competitive industry through real and tangible improvements in performance standards. The reform strategy specifically addresses the significant and intractable problems that have impeded the development of this industry to date.

The strategy is broadly based, covering workplace reform, industry development and building regulation. The strategy is unique and innovative. It is the first time such a comprehensive national approach has been attempted for the industry in this country. The development of the strategy has been undertaken in consultation with the major parties, in line with this Government's cooperative approach to industrial relations and industry development. In this process it has become apparent that the industry considers that a strong and active role by government is an essential prerequisite to achieving substantial reforms in the industry.

The Government has responded by approving a comprehensive industry reform and development strategy. It has also agreed to commit funding of $10.8m over the next 3 1/2 years to facilitate the implementation of the strategy. However, the Government believes the industry itself must make a fundamental contribution to the reform process. Accordingly, the Government has sought at the outset a genuine commitment on behalf of the parties to the achievement of reform.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of this commitment, the industry is being asked to contribute to funding for the strategy through financial and resource contributions. This could include possibly making experienced staff available to the Agency on secondment.

PARA.TAB: A significant indication of commitment to the strategy has been the signing of the in-principle reform and development agreement by the major industry parties. The in-principle agreement commits the parties to improve the performance of the industry to world-class practices and standards. It identifies specific areas where improved efficiency and productivity can be achieved. This is to be pursued primarily through the development of performance standards, improved contractual arrangements and related improvements in project management. Priority is given to the need for improvements in training and skill levels for managers, professional staff and workers, and to the enhancement of the industry's export performance.

The agreement also commits the parties to rationalisation of industry bodies and industry awards. It contains specific measures to resolve restrictive practices and the incidence of lost time on sites. It also gives priority to implementation of award restructuring; in particular, the adoption of the proposed new classification structure and associated skill related career paths and training.

It is very significant that all major national industry bodies have signed the agreement, including the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, the MTIA-National Construction Council, the Master Builders Construction and Housing Association of Australia, the Building Owners and Managers Association of Australia and the Building Industry Specialist Contractors Organisation of Australia. Every major national industry trade union, along with the ACTU, has also signed the agreement. In addition, the governments of Victoria, South Australia, the Australian Capital Territory and Western Australia have signed the agreement. It is likely that other governments will sign the agreement shortly.

In an industry that has been characterised by counterproductive conflict and internal dissension, this strategy represents an unparalleled approach to reform. All major stakeholders are committed to its success. It is on the basis of this ambitious and comprehensive strategy, together with the overwhelming support of all key sectors of the industry, that the Government now proposes to proceed with this legislation.

The main function of the Agency will be to promote and implement the reform strategy. The Agency is to have primary responsibility for ensuring that the parties adhere to the commitments contained in the in-principle agreement. The Agency will also be responsible for developing an industry code of practice, which is to be the basis for encouraging best practice standards in the industry. The Government has decided that it will commence to apply a code of practice for major Commonwealth public works construction projects from 1 July 1992.

The code of practice will contain arrangements for ratings systems for those companies seeking to participate in major construction projects. This will involve the development and implementation of a range of performance standards covering such important areas as quality assurance, research and export performance, financial performance, time performance, safety record and labour relations. The aim of this code will be to enhance performance standards and delivery through a transparent and objective process. In carrying out its responsibilities it will be essential for the Agency to liaise closely with the key national industry and union bodies and with State and Territory governments. The proposed Construction Industry Development Council will provide one suitable forum for such consultation.

The Government believes that reform must, and can, be achieved within the next two to three years. It therefore considers that the Agency should be established for a strictly limited period only. This will ensure that the momentum for change is maintained. Accordingly, the Bill provides that the Agency is to cease operations by 1 July 1995. Because of the urgency to press ahead with these reforms, the Agency has been established on an interim basis pending the enactment of this legislation.

It is essential to the success of the strategy that the Agency is strongly supported by the industry itself and is able to attract experienced and skilled people from the industry. The Bill therefore constitutes a board of the Agency that will enable people from the industry who have a proven record and enjoy a high reputation in the industry to be appointed to it. It is not intended to establish the board in a manner that simply represents existing industry bodies.

Mr Ern Macdonald, former Chair of Civil and Civic, has been appointed as the Chief Executive Officer of the interim Agency. The Bill permits the Agency to employ staff or engage or second people from the industry to undertake specific projects. The Bill also establishes the Construction Industry Development Council. The Council will constitute an ongoing forum for the industry to consider ways of improving its performance and standards.

The Bill provides that the Council will be chaired jointly by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and me, the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs, thereby giving Council members direct access to the key Commonwealth Ministers responsible for the reform strategy.

The Council will advise the Government on issues affecting the industry and will liaise with the Development Agency, other industry organisations and State and Territory governments. The Council's membership will include representatives from all major national industry bodies and unions. To reflect their key role, each State and Territory government is to be represented on the Council.

The Government is confident that the high level of support that has been demonstrated by all sections of the industry for the reform strategy will provide a sound basis for these two new bodies to make significant and durable contributions to the development of this vital industry. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

Resolution reported; report adopted.
Motion (by Mr Duncan)—by leave—agreed to:

That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the order of the day, committee and delegation reports, for the resumption of debate on the report of the Select Committee on the Print Media, being called on forthwith.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Select Committee on the Print Media

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before lunch I was addressing the report of the Select Committee on the Print Media and I was putting to the House that it is not enterprising that, after an inquiry into the print media with all of the time, effort and witnesses, the Committee should come up with a proposal which was not in any way original. It is a proposal that has been hawked around a lot of committees recently. The majority of members on the Committee swallowed it almost with relief, I believe, because it gave them something to report on; some recommendations to make.

PARA.TAB: This illustrates the way in which committees can almost assume a life of their own. The thinking seems to be, `We have a committee to inquire into something, so we had better come up with a recommendation. Here is a proposition that's been around an awful lot of committees recently; let's grab it'.

The Committee was uncritical in its appraisal of the proposals to change the merger test. It does not say how this would work in practice. It cannot say what a changed test would allow in terms of something that is currently prohibited; nor can it say what a changed test would prohibit in terms of something that is currently allowed.

Many claims have been made as to the magical healing properties of a change to the merger test in the Trade Practices Act. Unfortunately, this change to the Trade Practices Act is now put forward as a cure to any malady that might be investigated from time to time by any committee. It has almost assumed magical proportions. It would be nice to believe that it has all of the healing properties that have been put forward on its behalf, but I am afraid I cannot believe that. I particularly cannot believe the proposition that is put forward by the majority of Committee members in this report that somehow changing the merger test will lead to more competitors in the print media.

In Australia today we have two substantial owners in the print media: News Corporation and the House of Fairfax. Changing the section 50 merger test will do nothing to introduce a third competitor; nor will it do anything to break up those two houses. How could it possibly lead to the introduction of more competitors in the media in Australia? The important thing that is needed to get competitors into the print industry in Australia is ease of entry, particularly entry of people who have experience in the news industry. Therefore, I cannot believe that the Committee's recommendations to restrict foreign ownership will promote more competitors in the industry.

I am concerned about few owners and few proprietors in the print industry. It is the power of a proprietor to influence what appears in print that creates the sensitivity. But the problem we should concern ourselves with is the problem of corrupt news reporting. It is not just proprietors who can corrupt news reporting; journalists have an enormous capacity to do the same. I believe that the best protection against the corruption of news reporting is afforded by having independent bodies, separate from government and not susceptible to government influence, police that particular area.

If the real problem we are concerned about is news bias and the concentration of political power brought about by a small number of owners in the print industry, we should not be setting competition policy to deal with that problem. It is a bit like using a hammer to put in a screw. Merger and competition policy looks at products and pricing. Political power and political influence is a very different question. It is a question that should not become the province and the domain of the merger test, nor of the Trade Practices Commission. It should be the province and the domain of very independent, non-governmental bodies to whom complaints can be made and by whom independent investigations can be conducted. It is for that reason that I dissent from the recommendations in chapter 7. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) is persuasive in his arguments. Indeed, he put these views before the Select Committee on the Print Media. But one should understand that the Liberals are not monolithic on this issue. I recently sat on the inquiry of the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration into banking, at which a number of prominent members of the Opposition agreed unanimously that, in that particular inquiry, there should be a change to the merger test in order to lessen competition substantially. Indeed, prominent shadow spokesmen were amongst the Liberals who were unanimous in their acquiescence in that recommendation of the banking inquiry.

PARA.TAB: If one looks at the structure of banking in Australia, one will see that there are four large banks. It is very clear that a merger of two of those banks would not result in a breach of the dominance test, but certainly could be construed as a substantial lessening of competition. It was the view of the Committee that there was value in the change, which is one of the recommendations in respect of the print media. The two significant differences within the recommendations are the requirement for mandatory pre-notification and the substantial lessening of competition requirement.

I do not wish to dwell on that issue any further, but the great problem in determining these issues is defining the market. I think when one comes to making these determinations, invariably one will find that they will have very subjective elements and that there is a great division of opinion on this issue. I do not stand here very confidently, knowing that my position on this issue is exactly in accord with that of former Prime Minister Fraser. But that is the case. It was the former Prime Minister who came before the Committee saying that it was a disaster that the then Liberal Government had chosen to change the merger test to a dominance test. He believed it should not have made that decision.

Of course, the media are very influential. They have the opportunity to scrutinise everything that happens in this place: the way in which government is structured and the way in which it operates in this country. I think the electronic media, in particular, are very influential. It is my view that in many ways they are very dangerous, with their focus on looking for good pictures, the 10-second grab that seems to be essential for a news story, and indeed their focus on the flashy rather than the factual.

For instance, last night we saw an example of the way in which the electronic media operate in this country. We saw the obligatory phone-in poll. It is an indictment of the way in which Channel 9 operated that program that some credibility was given to the phone-in. It has absolutely no statistical legitimacy. I am sure that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who is a reasonable man, would agree that this sort of reporting and any credibility which is given to such polls is absurd.

It might be all right to decide which was the best catch in the World Cup cricket series, but when it comes to important political issues and economic debate in this country it is totally unacceptable. I am very glad that Channel 9's program last night rated very badly. Perhaps that will be a salutary lesson to it. What we look for from the print media is greater depth in reporting of political events, greater insight and, indeed, a greater diversity of opinion. Very often the print media are the agenda setters. I refer to page 22 of the overview where it was concluded by all members of the Committee from both sides:

SPEECH.PARA: All Members agreed that concentration of ownership is potentially harmful to plurality of opinion and increases the potential risk that news may be distorted.

It was the view of all members of the Committee that that was the case. Some of the events involving the Committee pointed up difficulties that do exist. I raised the issue during the Committee hearings of the evidence that was given by West Australian newspapers. It was reported in the West Australian newspaper—in Western Australia we only have access to one daily newspaper and so an unsavoury position, I would suggest, obtains there—generally along the terms `Bond never interfered', `Newspaper chief stands up and suggests what is happening', but the report did not reflect the questioning or the events that took place in the inquiry. I think this highlights the difficulty that exists, particularly in a place like Western Australia where we only have one daily newspaper, for there to be accurate consideration by the newspaper of its own management. Indeed, if we look at the ownership of the West Australian newspaper by Mr Holmes a Court and Mr Bond and the way in which the newspaper became burdened with debt over the period that they were in control, then we should be concerned at events that took place in the management of the newspaper.

PARA.TAB: I am hopeful that, in the interim report on the investigation into the Bond Corporation holdings and related companies, some of these events will come to light. It is interesting to note, for instance, that Mr Mitchell and Mr Oates were mentioned as Bond principals. They were involved in many of the dealings which occurred through the Bond Corporation. During their time as Bond executives they were on the board of the West Australian newspaper for a very short period. Their role as board members—one for only a couple of weeks—would make an interesting task for an investigative journalist to pursue. I wish to raise that particular issue because that was one of the things that was mentioned during the inquiry.

I would also like to take up the issue of the dissenting report that some of my colleagues pursued. We spent many hours refashioning the words of the report, debating the evidence and submissions and trying to find a form of words which was acceptable to other members of the Committee. On many occasions we felt that we had come to some sort of agreement, but it was pointless to waste so much time if Opposition members always intended to produce a dissenting report. There was the suggestion by members of the Opposition that the requirement or the activity of the Committee in pursuing some of the Fairfax bidders and questioning them was a sideshow. That is absurd. What was occurring in the Fairfax bid was entirely germane to the Committee's activities. The machinations and the arguments that were put forward by the bidders, and the close up view that we were able to get because of our access to those bidders, was something that was important to members of the Committee. It allowed us to focus on some of the issues which were within the bounds of the report. It is absurd to suggest that members of the Opposition in any way dissented from that process. When the decision was made to pursue some of the Fairfax bidders, there was a unanimous decision made by the Committee to do so.

I would like to mention very briefly the fact that there was a dissenting report to the dissenting report, which was made by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), the father of the House, who will be speaking after me. His proposal that cross-media ownership rules were unnecessary is one that I must object to most strongly. I understand the local flavour with which the right honourable member for New England approaches this issue, but it is the case that if those cross-media ownerships did not exist, it is possible that we could have Mr Packer or Mr Murdoch not only owning a substantial number of newspapers and magazines in this country, but also electronic media, radio, tape—the lot. Then the issue of concentration of media ownership would be very quickly focused in the minds of Australians.

I wanted to talk particularly about foreign ownership. It has long been my view that when we talk about foreign ownership there is a certain xenophobia amongst members of parliament, and that has often been the case amongst members on this side of the House. It seems to me that if one looks at Australian media owners over the last decade, one sees figures such as Alan Bond, Christopher Skase, Robert Holmes a Court and Warwick Fairfax Jr—hardly a tale of expert management or proficient management of media enterprises in this country. The suggestion that Australian owners are intrinsically good and that all foreign owners are aberrant in some way is something that I would reject. It is my view that we need to have good management and sound economic management of newspapers, and that is the most important and critical thing for the health of the newspaper industry in this country. The suggestion that only Australians can provide that sort of management is something that I would reject. I was pleased when the Committee determined to add paragraph 9.90, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recognises that the present 20 per cent limit on foreign ownership is an arbitrary figure. While it is consistent with other arbitrarily determined limits (as for television) it is of concern to some Members of the Committee that it has become a bench mark figure. The best reason for using such a figure is to act as a guideline for prospective investors which alerts them to the important public policy considerations in this industry. The 20 per cent limit should be viewed in this context.

If it is viewed in this context, as a guideline rather than a benchmark, then it spells out for prospective investors that there is concern about the public policy implications, about national sovereignty, and about Australian ownership in sensitive and influential industries. But we understand also that it is important that these industries be economically viable and supported by owners who show, and have shown, that they have the expertise to manage them. In that circumstance we should not be xenophobic about foreign ownership and we should be flexible in the way in which we approach foreign ownership considerations.

PARA.TAB: A number of other issues were raised in the report, but time does not allow me to pursue them. I would like to say that it is clear that the print media has an important and critical role to play in preserving our democracy. We are all interested in the accuracy of reporting and diversity of opinion in the print media. The opportunity to serve on this Committee was something that I found very worthwhile and has enlightened me in many ways. I thank my colleagues and the staff of the Committee for the way in which they worked so very hard. I hope that the Government will act quickly to pursue some of the recommendations made by the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The preservation of a critical media and the opportunities within the media to express honestly and without passion, or perhaps I should say in dispassion, the views and attitudes of the community go beyond doubt and competition, as the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) and others discussed in the presentation of the print media report, and are matters that are widely accepted in this House. Of course, all of us as politicians have a particular interest in the media. We are inevitably those who hope that our views might be properly and fairly expressed through the media, and we rely very much on the media in interpreting those views to the wider public and to the audience which is our electorate. The creation of a parliamentary committee, and the manner of the creation of this report, has a number of fallacies. It is those and some of the background that I want to address in the few moments that I have, as they relate to the Committee and to its conclusions in the paper headed News & Fair Facts.

PARA.TAB: The first is that, while we all want to preserve competition, it is how to achieve it and the ways by which competition is effected that seem to me to be matters that really have not necessarily been resolved by the report. While I acknowledge and my colleagues assert that there is quite excellent documentary evidence and material included in the report, I do not think we constitute a committee just to come to a conclusion. Part of my trouble in the very difficult field that was the charge of the committee was that it is only part of the media. There was an expectation, almost because of the Fairfax collapse—and the offer of the Fairfax Group by the receivers at the time generated a feeling that there needed to be a legislative response—that resulted in the attitude that the majority of the members of the Committee adopted.

My concern, really, is that it is going to be extraordinarily difficult for us to protect and preserve competition in the print media. We need to understand it is not just a matter of ownership that affects that competition, and I refer those who are interested to evidence given by Mr Greg Taylor, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the John Fairfax Group and Managing Director of David Syme and Co. Ltd, which is referred to at page 119 of the report in paragraph 5.20. He refers to the fact that in most major American cities now there is basically one newspaper in the market, and he goes on to explain that. This view was echoed by Professor Peter Swan, a consultant to News Ltd, whose evidence is referred to at paragraph 5.21. He said that in the United States the number of cities with more than one competing paper and more than one newspaper is virtually zero. There are certainly fewer than 15. In other words, we are looking at a changing economic environment within which there is a consolidation of ownership.
Further to that, it was also interesting to hear the evidence that was tendered to the Committee by Dr Brown. At page 97, paragraph 4.31, his evidence is referred to. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I think Sydney and Melbourne are well served by the individual papers there which are competitive to some extent. . .
He went on to say:

The competition in Australia, curiously, is most vigorous between The Australian and The Financial Review, The Sydney Morning Herald and The Age in a kind of national way; elsewhere it is pretty limited.

We have these economic forces which are leading to a consolidation of the media. We have got any amount of evidence saying progressively around the world, and certainly in the English speaking world, there is a consolidation of ownership of newspapers, and in markets much larger than Australia there is very little competition. So we get to the point where in order to preserve competition we are told that we have to change legislatively a number of pieces of existing legislation to try to protect and preserve competition policy.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned with the ways in which that competition policy is now directed and also with the way in which through the Broadcasting Tribunal there seems to be a great deal of influence in one section, which to me is more intrusive than necessarily beneficial. To give an illustration, if there is a problem in the presentation of fair views with Australia's interest in mind, no-one can properly assert that that is necessarily always the product of views expressed on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Yet the ABC is not subject to the ABT. The ABC is able to produce programs which offend our neighbours; the ABC produces views which both sides of the House assert are prejudicial to their own particular point of view—and the ABC, like the SBS, is outside the control of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

If we are looking at competition policy in the media, there are two fields of control—restrictive trade practices and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Sure, we are going to have changes as a result of the draft broadcasting legislation, subject to the new Minister whose views seem to be subjective rather than objective in this field. But given that there is going to be control, let us not run mad by saying, `The only way by which you are going to control diversity is by looking at ownership'. That is the first thing I wanted to say.

In the minority report which I signed with my colleagues, we have identified our concerns in a number of particular areas. We are concerned about conclusions that have been reached by the Committee majority in respect of: foreign investment; the research role of the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics; in particular, chapter 7 of the report, which deals with improving competition and diversity and in respect of which the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) spoke a moment ago; and, of course, changing the market dominance test in section 50 of the Trade Practices Act.One of the reasons why I adhere to that is that, like the honourable member for Higgins and other colleagues, I fail to be convinced that the changes the Government recommendations propose are going to change the market forces which in my view very much determine the consolidation of ownership which we have seen not only in the print media here but around the world.

The area where I have dissented from them, of course, is that I can see no benefit at all in cross-media ownership rules. As I have stated in my particular part of the report, at page 353, where I dissent from the others, in my view there is little doubt that the changes made to the cross-media ownership laws in 1987 really had no major effect on the changes in ownership of the media in Australia. They were far more the product of factors that related to the decision by Mr Kerry Packer with respect to the sale of his interests in Channel 9, to decisions taken by Mr Warwick Fairfax and the Fairfax Group, to commercial decisions taken by Mr Rupert Murdoch with respect to the News Ltd group and to decisions that also related to the ownership takeovers of the Channel 10 and Channel 7 networks.

If we look back, I cannot see that the cross-media rules have in any way benefited the competition field and it was for that reason that I made a dissenting report. At a time when television aggregation has placed such enormous pressure on commercial television stations, I have said not only do I agree with my colleagues that there should not be cross-media ownership with respect to broadcasting but I can see no advantage in it with respect to either television or print media. The historical antecedents show that the print media essentially was the genesis of the development of broadcasting in much of Australia and that the proprietors of those two media ultimately became the genesis of television. I can see that through that source we might be able to get some return to viability amongst the media generally, which might enable viability certainly of television stations that have been very seriously affected by the enormous capital cost of aggregation.

There is one other area that concerns me. I was delighted that in the report there was unanimity that we should not legislate to apply the charters that have been set up by various journalist organisations. There is an Age charter, there is an AJA charter, an AJA code of ethics, about which a good deal of evidence was given in the course of the presentation of evidence to us. The reason is that, in my view, if there is a threat in this field, it is not just, as I have said, in the ownership of the print media but also to a degree in the role and attitude taken by journalists themselves. In the course of the hearing of evidence I received a number of submissions privately, apart from those that were before the Committee. One came from a Mr Adrian Lynch who, together with his brother, expressed concern about attitudes taken by the Australian Journalists Association. As we all know, the Journalist, the journal of the Australian Journalists Association, promoted the charter and suggested that legislation should put an obligation on proprietors.

Yet, interestingly, the AJA itself apparently does not follow the same charter. I was interested to read in the Sydney Morning Herald of Tuesday 15 October 1991 that there are accusations of censorship of journalists by members of the AJA in the preparation of a magazine called Freelance. This is regarding the Media Alliance. I gather that Freelance, which was published by AJA freelance members, had a different point of view from other members on the Media Alliance. The AJA itself sought to do anything but allow the freedom to its editor that it seeks for others. I think this is part of the trouble. Indeed, as the submission put to me said, the AJA itself regularly censors copy critical of the union's leadership and that leadership's decisions; it suppresses the publication of AJA journals that might contain critical but not defamatory copy; and while advocating press freedoms and editorial charters it does not grant those freedoms and charters to the often voluntary AJA correspondents and editors.

The point at issue is really the extent to which we can for the future establish competition within the Australian media, and competition that allows diversity throughout an extraordinarily far-flung nation. Of course, there is a great deal of information in the report which relates to the different characters and nature of the media, and in that respect the report is a very valuable document.

I am concerned, not unnaturally, that in rural and regional Australia the same concentration of ownership is occurring but, as I have suggested, cross-media ownership, which would allow each of the forms of media to be owned by individual proprietors, would be far better than allowing the concentration of ownership that is now occurring within particular sections of the media. In other words, a city owned country newspaper, a city owned country television station, a city owned country broadcasting station or, for that matter, an eastern State owned Western Australian newspaper or other media outlet, or an eastern State or main State ownership of, say, a Tasmanian media outlet, generates enormous problems in those communities. They are not immediately apparent, but there is a separate point of view, a point of view which needs to be protected and preserved with an opportunity provided for continued expression.

It is for that reason that I have come to differ from my colleagues with respect to cross-media ownership, but I certainly agree with them in respect of the other elements of the dissenting report. I commend the staff of the Committee. I think they put an inordinate amount of work into a report which is fairly unique in Australia.

It is extraordinarily important that from time to time there be an analysis in different areas of policy, and I think this report contributes to that end. As I have suggested, however, I do not see the solutions in the interventionary processes recommended in the majority report. Indeed, I regret that it is felt necessary, as a result of the considerations that we had, to find some new solution.

As I and others have remarked, the genesis of the reference lay in concerns about the ultimate ownership of the Fairfax Group. As we now debate this issue the Fairfax Group is about to issue shares to the public. There is no doubt that under its new owner and new proprietor it would seem to be preserving that independence that we all sought. So the Committee's establishment and its recommendations have no bearing on the Fairfax outcome.

As I have remarked, in the United States and indeed around Australia there has been significant consolidation of media ownership in the past. That is a product of market forces, and I cannot see that anything in this report will prevent by legislative action the actions that flow from predominantly market forces.

For that reason I support my colleagues in dissenting from the major recommendations but say, like they do, that I trust that in changes that flow around Australia we will preserve competition and a reasonable opportunity for the private and public expression of views, whatever they might be, as long as they do not in any way offend Australia's national interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to speak to the report of the Select Committee on the Print Media. At the outset, I want to congratulate my colleague the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) on chairing the Committee in the manner that he has and on ensuring that the report that has come forward, despite some of the suggestions from our colleagues opposite, was able to achieve the wholehearted support of those of us on this side. Many of us have had a variety of views about media issues but, in the final analysis, we have been able to reach positions which I think are constructive and sensible and which lend themselves to early implementation by the Government.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt, as other speakers have said, that the diversity of views and the right of people in the community to have a range of information provided are fundamental to a healthy democracy. I recall speaking in the debate on a private member's motion that the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) put forward about 15 months ago seeking a royal commission into media ownership. At that stage we were seeking that royal commission not because of the Fairfax issues but because of the broader community concerns about levels of media concentration and the need for parliaments and governments to take that issue very seriously. The response to that in setting up the Select Committee has, I believe, been a very useful exercise. The report that is being presented today reflects just how valuable that has been.

The key things that are contained in the report, as other speakers have said, relate to the changing of the test as far as mergers and takeovers are concerned—moving from the dominance test introduced by the Fraser Government in 1977, by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who was Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs at that time, to a tougher test. I believe very strongly that the substantial lessening of competition test that is recommended by the majority in the report is a tougher test.

A lot has been said about this, but it is certainly true that we can accept much of the evidence that was given by the Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission to the inquiry about what the effect of a tougher test under section 50 of the Trade Practices Act would be. I think it has the desired effect of addressing the concern about levels of media concentration and the potential for that to reach the levels of higher concentration that exist today. That being the case, I think it is right that the Government be asked to act to ensure that the test that has to be faced by any future mergers is a stronger test that takes full account of many of the things that the existing section 50 provides for, but as well as that adds a number of points that we have recommended in our conclusion in that regard relating to free expression of opinion, fair and accurate presentation of news, the economic viability of the publication, et cetera.

I think they are important additional facets to have to consider, because all of us have an interest in this issue. We take an interest in relation to Fairfax; we take an interest generally into the amount of concentration of media ownership in the print media, be it in national dailies or in suburban newspapers and the like. It is reasonable to suggest that the test that is applied, and the way that it is applied in the newspaper area, should be treated as a special category if the test is not going to be changed for other areas of industry.

We recommended in the banking inquiry last year that the test in relation to banking for mergers and takeovers should be toughened as well. On that particular occasion, the Opposition was prepared to support it unanimously; there was no dissent from anyone in the Committee at that particular time from the recommendation for a tougher test. One has to ask the question: why would there be a reason to have a more stringent attitude to banking than the Opposition proposes to the print media? Surely the print media would be regarded as just as important and just as significant to the protection of democratic ideals, and if the matter was to be taken to its logical conclusion, one would have consistency in the approach that was adopted. It is regrettable that that has not been the case. Nevertheless, it is certainly my view that the majority report, which recommends the substantial lessening of competition, will be a more healthy outcome and it is one that certainly recommends itself to the Government to implement without delay.

As well as that, in the report we focused on the restructuring of the Press Council. Having listened to the evidence throughout the inquiry, I think that there is no doubt that there is a genuine basis to be urging a strengthening and restructuring of the Press Council so that it can more effectively address many of the complaints that arise about the print media industry. Clearly, the Press Council has to be adequately funded to do that job and, clearly, it has to have the accountability that goes with that. It needs to have equal representation, as is outlined in the report, from the public publishers and the AJA, and it needs to be seen as a body that people who have complaints about the print media can go to and as one that will ensure that those matters are effectively considered and also ensure that the rationale and the reasoning behind decisions are adequately published in the media. That is something that I think we can all thoroughly support.

The other matters relating to cross-media ownership have been canvassed in the debate to date. I do not wish to traverse those issues too greatly other than to say that, in the area of radio, the Committee has recommended that the rules that are in place in that area should not be left standing still in the face of changing technology and development. That is something again which lends itself to the Government for serious consideration in the context of the Broadcasting Services Bill.

Foreign ownership is an issue that was addressed throughout the Fairfax question. The provisions contained in paragraph 9.90 give a sensible and rational way to approach levels of foreign ownership in the media. Clearly, it is important and desirable to encourage the maximum Australian participation and ownership of our media. Our culture, our desires and our national identity are all interrelated to both ownership and control of our media. In that sense it is desirable that we maximise Australian ownership in an area such as our print media industry.

It is a significant industry in itself and we need to try to maximise those concerns about Australian content and Australian ownership. The 20 per cent rule is one that we need to take account of in the context of other rules relating to the print media. We cannot be totally blinkered and black and white in the approach that we take to foreign ownership; we have to judge cases on their merits. The recommendation contained in the report enables future decisions about levels of foreign ownership in our media to be addressed in a sensible and more effective basis than perhaps has occurred on some occasions in the past.

As to the other provisions in the report, we have addressed issues relating to small magazines and, indeed, the magazine area generally. I think the recommendations we have made reflect the differences in terms of the types of media we have. Some people suggested in the course of the inquiry that we lump magazines into one category, and that people could not be participants in that as well as other forms of the media. It is not a view that I have endorsed at any point, and I am pleased the Committee has come to the conclusions it has in that area. Nevertheless, it will clearly be reasonable as time goes on for the Parliament to continue to take an interest in questions relating to technology, advertising revenue and all those sorts of issues.

I think one of the most significant recommendations in the report is the fact we are saying that the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics should develop a more effective data and information base in relation to our media industry. One of the things we noticed in starting out on this process was that there was very little information readily available in the community on issues that we debate frequently relating to the media; for example, the role of the media, levels of ownership, and the impacts of that set out in an informed and statistical way.

With those things in mind, I think the recommendation at the outset of the report, that there be regular collection and publication of information on the characteristics and performance of the Australian print media industry by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, et cetera, is important. It is clear that, as has been said in the debate, some of our colleagues on the opposite side do not necessarily see those concerns in quite the way we do. We have argued that there should be healthy competition in our media. We have argued that there should be informed and diverse debate in our media. How do we ensure that happens? Clearly, we ensure it happens by first being able to analyse where the industry is at at any given time and what the trends are in the development of the industry, and by having a capacity, having used that information, to then make informed decisions about the relationship between the print media and our other media, and about levels of concentration of ownership, et cetera.

We have attempted to do those things in this report. As I said at the outset, I think it is a report that lends itself in a practical way to the Government for implementation. There are matters within it that individual players in the media can take issue with, but our role as a parliamentary committee has been to look at those issues across the board and reflect the best environment for the future of our media industry in terms of its relationship to the people of Australia and our democratic processes. I think we have done that effectively, and I certainly believe that the approach we have taken, which encourages competition through the substantial lessening of competition test, is far better than reliance on the dominance test, which the Opposition has—

TALK.START.PARA: —Free enterprise.

—The free enterprise that our colleagues in the Opposition have supported but unfortunately are not able to be part of implementing because they will not allow the rules to be put in that enable a competitive environment and more competition in our media. It is a matter of regret that we have that in the report. The Opposition would have been far better to follow its free enterprise ideals and to support a substantial lessening of competition. There is no doubt in my view that that would have been a more effective way for this issue to be addressed in the coming decade.

PARA.TAB: No-one can predict what will happen as far as individual media players are concerned. People would have said 10 years ago, before the introduction of the cross-media rules, `We have these arrangements here; major empires in the media have interests in radio, television and newspapers', yet today we see that a vastly different set of circumstances has arisen in the space of a very short period. Those who say the changes we recommend in the report before us today do not go far enough should judge our report in the context of time. Although we can be sure that we have a number of major media players today, there is no guarantee the same people will be around five years from now in the same form and in the same organisations any more than there was before the cross-media rules were introduced.

For all those reasons, I am pleased to be associated with this report. As I said at the outset, I pay tribute to my colleague the honourable member for Dobell for the manner in which he conducted the inquiry. It has not been an easy exercise from the outset. I think it is one that the Committee has handled constructively and in a very able manner. That has been a tribute to the Chairman's efforts. It has also been a tribute to the cooperation which has existed throughout the Committee. Except for a couple of things in the minority report that I have referred to which would be better not there, we accept that there has been an amount of a spirit of cooperation throughout.

I would also like to pay tribute to the staff, who have played an excellent part in preparing the report. With the limited time frame for the report, the work was always done under pressure. Certainly on my observation, our staff deserve congratulations for their efforts. I say finally that the key recommendations of the report are worthy of adoption by the Government at the earliest possible time. I thoroughly recommend it to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Prosser) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 24 March, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was, shall we say, part heard on this matter until 10.30 last night when the House commenced the adjournment debate. The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is an omnibus Bill, a seemingly simple measure amending three pieces of legislation, namely, the Judges' Pensions Act 1968, the Defence Force Discipline Appeals Act 1955 and the Family Law Act 1975. I dealt with matters that pertained to the Judges' Pensions Act, and was critical of the Government, justifiably, for the threat to judicial independence by the sloppy way in which it continues the method of determining remuneration and the fall behind, in real and other terms, of judges.

PARA.TAB: The Defence Force Discipline Appeals Act is a simple matter of resolving authority in a Minister and not the Governor-General. The last matter involves minor amendments to the Family Law Act. I advise the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), who will be following me, that it is not my intention to detain the House a great deal longer on this piece of legislation. I know both of us have been waiting a fair period to wind up the debate on this matter.

The Bill represents fairly minor amendments to the Family Law Act. Section 112AA is amended so that the definition of `order under this Act' will provide that a subpoena issued under the rules of the court is an order under the Family Law Act. This amendment will make clear that the sanctions available to the Family Court for dealing with breaches of its orders will be available when a person fails to comply with a subpoena. The Bill will repeal section 116A and section 116B of the Act which provide for payments to States and Territories for financial assistance in family law matters.

These sections have been made redundant by new legal aid funding arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories. The legal aid bodies are now funded by grants under section 96 of the Constitution. Paragraph 123(1)(u) is amended to increase the maximum penalty which can be imposed for a breach of the family law rules to a sum of $5,000. The rules impose penalties for failure to comply with the summons or a garnishee order and for making false or misleading statements to the court.

The coalition supports these minor amendments to the Family Law Act. But I take this opportunity in dealing with amendments to the Family Law Act to make a couple of observations on Government behaviour in regard to the family law legislation—both the Family Law Regulations (Amendment) 1991 and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Regulations (Amendment) 1991 which, in another place, the coalition and the Australian Democrats successfully opposed just a few weeks ago.

As the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) is aware, the regulations were part of a set of four regulations made by the Government on 12 December 1991 and due to come into effect on 1 April 1992. Most of us in this place are used to April Fools' Day jokes, but this was a rather cruel version of it, with the Government seeking to impose additional burdens on those people who are forced to face processes under either the Family Law Act or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal—with further imposts being dumped on them by this Government—but now not to be so dumped because of the actions taken in the Senate by us and the Australian Democrats.

The regulations provided for a new setting down fee of $500 to be payable in proceedings in the Federal Court, the Family Court and the High Court, and $200 in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. As I have said, the coalition joined with the Democrats to disallow the regulations in relation to the Family Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. At a time when the Government is espousing the need to reduce the cost of justice, the coalition believes that it is hypocritical to introduce a range of fees in the Family Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which is nothing more than a tax on people who seek access to the courts to resolve their disputes.

The costs associated with legal services and litigation today have become so high that many Australians are now effectively denied the opportunity of seeking the redress of wrongdoings. Access to justice has, frankly, become limited to the two extremes of the very wealthy, who can privately fund litigation, and the very poor who can qualify for legal aid assistance.

These remarks have been passed by me time and again, but it is a shocking state of affairs in a nation such as ours that normally law abiding citizens have, in practical terms, very limited access to the law to redress wrongs or to correct manifest injustices. It is not entirely the fault of the Government. Rather than simply talking about its concerns about the cost, the Government should, in fact, be taking steps to ensure that the court procedures are such that excessive delays and other elements that are placed in the way of litigants are removed. However, the legal profession itself has a profound duty to examine itself and to ensure that the present process, which is becoming virtually an outrage for so many people faced with the prospect of litigation—either of their own determination or when brought against them—and is almost crippling in its effect, is not allowed to go on forever.

This is a country which is overwhelmingly of middle income and low income people. Unless people are paupers, they cannot get access to legal aid. So much opportunity for the redress of wrongs is denied to average persons—those who are part of that vast bulk of people in the middle in this nation. That in itself is a manifest injustice. It is something which, as I have said, the profession and governments, in terms of streamlining the processes of justice, have a profound duty to tackle.

This matter is being examined by a Senate committee inquiring into the cost of justice. In my own case, as deputy chairman of a committee examining the Family Law Act, we are looking at the cost of some litigation. Some of the evidence is displeasing, to put it mildly. However, it would be a contempt of the committee if in fact I were to reveal some of that material at this stage. The committee has to report by August and at some point will be directing its attention to the question of costs.

I say in passing that one matter, which is not before the committee, illustrates what I am saying. There is a very well known firm of solicitors in Sydney which was acting for a woman in a family law matter. She received an order for, as I recall it, $580,000 from her husband. An amount of $580,000 was due to the divorcing wife from the divorcing husband. The firm charged her $500,000. It is almost unbelievable that someone can receive an order of $580,000 and be forced to pay legal fees of $500,000.

When this matter was taken on appeal and also got some publicity, the firm properly took action. The partner responsible is no longer a partner of that said firm. But I cite that as an extreme example of what has transpired in our country over the last year. In fact, in the latter part of last year this matter received extensive publicity in some Sydney newspapers. It is an example of the burden placed on someone who had battled through to a successful outcome but then was faced with the horrendous costs.

As I have said, as the deputy chairman of the joint parliamentary inquiry into the operation of the family law and as a former practitioner in that field, I am well aware of the cases that come before the Family Court and the cost of such litigation. Few are as extreme as the example that I gave. Parties to family law disputes are not necessarily there by choice. In many instances they are compelled to seek a legal resolution of conflicts arising out of a marriage breakdown which so tragically involves access and custody of children. The Government had proposed to burden these people, at this most traumatic time of their lives, with an extra $500 fee that none would have been able to avoid and which, for most people, would have been just another burden.

The Law Council of Australia expressed very serious reservations in relation to the impact of the fees. The coalition and the Law Council were particularly concerned that significant hardship could result from the imposition of the new fees in the Family Court. For example, a fee would have been payable for applications by a party to remove a violent and abusive spouse from the matrimonial home or to gain proper access to a child when access was being refused by a vindictive custodial parent. There are dozens of examples of where the imposition of the proposed new fees would simply have been unfair and, most certainly, inappropriate.

Surprisingly, the Government did not appear to share our concerns. The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), who, frankly, has been extraordinarily vocal in his misrepresentations of the coalition's Fightback package, was strangely silent on this issue. The Minister has accused the coalition of completely undermining efforts to reduce the cost of justice, but has seemed to ignore the impact on the cost of justice of new and increased court fees—as did the Attorney-General.

We were also concerned about the imposition of a setting down fee in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Given the nature of the AAT and often smaller claims involved, it seemed absurd to charge a setting down fee even at the reduced rate of $200 and even with the proviso that it is refundable to successful applicants. The fact remains that if one is dealt with capriciously by a government department, one would not have been able to proceed with one's AAT hearing unless one could come up with this initial $200 fee to have one's case set down—which, of course, was on top of the $300 filing fee. Those were some of the reasons why we moved with the Democrats to have those provisions knocked out in so far as the fees would impact in the Family Court and in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The coalition does not oppose the passage of the Bill. It deals, as I say, with relatively minor amendments. However, as a coalition, we are concerned at what is unquestionably an erratic and irresponsible approach to the cost of justice. We believe it is of paramount importance to the swift, cost-effective administration of justice that the whole federal system of justice be managed on sound, cost-disciplined administrative principles. However, in the case of the Family Court and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal regulations, the fees further put access to the courts, to justice and to liberty beyond the reach of ordinary citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 is an omnibus Bill. I am pleased that we have bipartisan support for it. The shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), has covered very broadly the three amendments in the Bill. The Bill makes amendments of a minor policy nature to legislation within the Attorney-General's portfolio and also makes some minor technical amendments to legislation.

PARA.TAB: The first amendment is one to the Judges' Pensions Act 1968 to remove the current limitation that a pension payable to the surviving spouse of a judge or retired judge ceases to be payable upon remarriage. Provision is also made for the reinstatement, in certain circumstances, of a pension which has ceased to be payable on remarriage. The second amendment is to section 12 of the Defence Force Discipline Appeals Act 1955 to provide that the Minister, rather than the Governor-General, may approve leave of absence for members of the Defence Force Discipline Appeal Tribunal.

The third makes a number of minor amendments to the Family Law Act 1975. Firstly, it amends the definition of `order under this Act' in section 112AA for the purposes of part XIIIA to provide that a subpoena under the rules of court is an order under the Family Law Act; secondly, it repeals sections 116A and 116B, which are redundant as legal aid bodies are now funded by grants under section 96 of the Constitution; and, thirdly, it amends subsection 123(1)(u) to increase the maximum penalty which can be imposed for a breach of the family law rules to the sum of $5,000.

With regard to financial impact, the amendments to the Judges' Pensions Act 1968 are expected to have only a minor revenue impact, as pensions which would have ceased to be payable will now be payable. It is expected that the number of additional pensions payable will be very small. The other amendments will have no financial impact.

I would like to take up only one point, a difficult one, made by the shadow Attorney-General. I acknowledge his genuineness in making his comments. I refer to the way in which remuneration for judges is set. It is extremely difficult in these times because things are tough for everybody out there. I acknowledge the need to make sure that we have sensible and fair remuneration for people who hold such a high, important and responsible position in our society.

I would also like to make the observation, however, that the Australian Council of Trade Unions has shown not only discipline but also responsibility over the last nine years in that we have actually seen a reduction of some 8 per cent, in real terms, in the salaries of working men and women in this country. On that basis, we have to compare that with the level of remuneration of judges, and even if their remuneration has dropped behind, we have to take cognisance of the remuneration that working men and women in the community receive.

If the proposition put forward by the shadow Attorney-General that we do have an independent tribunal is taken into account, I have to say that I am not dramatically opposed to that, but I think the outcome would be dependent upon who and how many people make up that tribunal. I would suggest that, if we do have such a tribunal, Archbishop Hollingworth and representatives of Australian pensioners should necessarily be on such a tribunal. That would certainly give a broader based perspective to the needs of this country and probably a better grass roots understanding of what society is about. We need to ensure that judges have a fair remuneration, but, I would stress, so should fitters and turners; so should people who work in sawmills; and, indeed, so should the Public Service. It is, of course, always going to be the case with regard to law that there will be need to be changes.

As I did last night in the adjournment debate, I would like to congratulate the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) on the work he is doing, in conjunction with the six State governments, with regard to changing the law which at present is such that Joe Budd is imprisoned in Boggo Road gaol. I would hope that never again would a journalist be imprisoned under the same circumstances. I close with those remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I want to thank all those who have contributed to this relatively brief debate, particularly the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) for his erudite and insightful comments. I only want to respond to one particular matter. Yesterday evening in the debate, the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), said that when provisions prohibiting the payment of a pension to a surviving spouse of a politician or public servant who had remarried were repealed, those surviving spouses had their pension automatically restored. That is not the case; that is not correct.

PARA.TAB: When similar amendments were made in respect of surviving spouses of members of parliament and public servants who had remarried, the restoration of the pension was subject to the surviving spouse showing necessitous circumstances or that the restoration of the pension was otherwise justified. I just wanted to make that point to the House so that the incorrect statement made by the shadow Attorney-General could be corrected for the record. Apart from that, I would like to thank everybody who took part in the debate and commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Duncan) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 5) 1991-92[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1991-92APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1991-92APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1991-92]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 24 March, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. M.J.R. MacKellar)—I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1991-92 concurrently with the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1991-92, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1991-92 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1991-92. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addition to the Appropriation Bill (No. 3), the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, the Government has blundered its way into this cognate debate with Appropriation Bill (No. 5)—a Bill that is totally without precedent and reflects the incompetence with which the Government manages its budgetary process in this Parliament. Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1991-92 seeks funding of $87m for labour market reform assistance to job seekers and industry; $50m for residential fee relief for older people; and $66m for child-care fee relief.

PARA.TAB: With the exception of those funds sought for child-care, these items are already included in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4), which we are supposedly debating cognately, and to which the Government has now moved a series of amendments to delete the items that are now to be included in Appropriation Bill (No. 5). We are told that this additional Appropriation Bill is necessary because the Government will run out of money in these areas before the passage of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4). Accordingly, the Government is seeking to rush through Appropriation Bill (No. 5), ahead of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4), having deleted the expenditures to which I just referred from the other two Bills, the original Appropriation Bills.

This is a totally unprecedented state of affairs in this Parliament, given that it is usual for such shortfalls in funds to be met from the Advance to the Minister for Finance. The Advance to the Minister for Finance is designed to act as a contingency fund and is catered for in the relevant provisions in the Appropriation and Supply Bills. Traditionally, any unforeseen and urgent expenditures not catered for in the Appropriation Bills are met from the Advance to the Minister for Finance. Where the advance is used to supply funds to a government department, the department is required to seek parliamentary approval for those funds in the next Appropriation Bill.

When those Bills are subsequently enacted the amount is then credited back to the Advance to the Minister for Finance. That is the way it is supposed to work; that is the way it has worked in this Parliament since the year dot. Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) are usually the final opportunity a department has to make such a transaction. Any transactions made after the passage of these two Bills are normally charged against the advance and referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for scrutiny.

We need to ask the Government why it has not followed this procedure and instead deemed it necessary to pass an additional Appropriation Bill. The Government's action strongly suggests that there is a funding crisis of some sort in the Advance to the Minister for Finance. If there are no funds available in the Advance to the Minister for Finance, we need to know what the situation is with the advance because it strongly suggests that the funds are being used for other purposes which are yet to be subjected to parliamentary scrutiny.
