We also need to ask what relationship, if any, this funding shortfall has to the Government's unique payment of a one-off $317m in family allowance payments on 2 April, just ahead—I do not think by coincidence—of the Wills by-election on 11 April.

Although funds have been appropriated for the purpose in the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 that was passed in the last sitting fortnight, the coincidence of timing does suggest that the Advance to the Minister for Finance may have been plundered to pay for this pre-by-election bribe from the Government. In any event, we are witness to what can only be described as gross financial mismanagement in the Government's conduct of the Commonwealth's budgetary process. The annual passage of the Commonwealth's budgetary legislation is meant to proceed through this Parliament in an orderly and timely manner. To this end, there are a number of measures made available to the Government to cater for additional appropriations that may be necessary from time to time in the event of unforeseen circumstances. The Advance to the Minister for Finance is the most important instrument in this regard and normally obviates the need for any additional Appropriation Bills.

In this case we are asked to pass an additional Appropriation Bill without the benefit of knowing what has been happening with the Advance to the Minister for Finance. The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) has claimed that Appropriation Bill (No. 5) is necessitated by delays in the passage of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4). But every honourable member and every senator in this Parliament knows that those two Bills have only just been introduced into this House and that the normal practice is to debate them over the next few sitting weeks. As yet there have been no delays to speak of and there are to be no unexpected delays. So we have yet to hear a truthful explanation from the Government.

At best, the Government has been incompetent in not ensuring that the Advance to the Minister for Finance is able to meet the ongoing expenditures of the Government. This additional Appropriation Bill is undoubtedly further evidence of the continuing deterioration in the Commonwealth's finances. Commonwealth budgeting, once again, is exposed for the sham that it is.

The Government's finances have been devastated by the recession `we had to have'. According to the most recent statement of Commonwealth Government financial transactions issued by the Minister for Finance, the cumulative budget deficit for the year to date in January was $11.229 billion. This compares with a figure of $2.994 billion for the same period last year. This is a variation of $8.234 billion which is clearly not entirely attributable to irregularities in government outlays and receipts.

It is little wonder that the Government finds itself running out of money in particular programs. The Government's original Budget deficit forecast contained in the 1991-92 Budget was $4.732 billion, a change for the worse on the outcome for the previous year, 1990-91, of $6.628 billion and giving rise to a net public sector borrowing requirement equal to 4.3 per cent of gross domestic product. This forecast in the most recent Government Budget was to prove wildly optimistic, as we have come to expect from this Government.

Prior to the economic statement the Government issued a revised budget deficit forecast for 1991-92 of $6.3 billion. The ante goes up each day and each month, it seems. That was then quickly revised to a budget deficit forecast of $6.8 billion to reflect the new measures contained in the Government's `One Nation, One Job' statement. Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4), together with the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), seek additional appropriations totalling $1.117 billion. Allowing for savings in the appropriations made by Appropriation Act (No. 1) and Appropriation Act (No. 2) last year, these Bills represent a net increase of $971m in payments to be financed from annual appropriations this financial year. This is an increase of 2.8 per cent on the amounts made available in the 1991-92 Budget, or 2.5 per cent discounting for the additional expenditure contained in the `One Job' economic statement.

These appropriations are designed to meet increases in ongoing government expenditure not provided for in the original Appropriation Bills, as well as to fund some of the spending contained in the `One Job' statement. The `One Job' statement contains increased outlays and tax cuts worth $0.5 billion dollars in 1991-92; $1.8 billion in 1992-93; $1.6 billion in 1993-94; $5.1 billion in 1994-95; and $7.6 billion in 1995-96.

The first thing that needs to be said about this new spending and revenue to be forgone is that it is totally unfunded. It is all new Commonwealth debt. The measures contained in the statement will, in aggregate, increase the public deficit for 1991-92 by $0.5 billion to $6.8 billion on the basis of the Government's own figures. The Government then projects the deficit to increase to $8 billion in 1992-93. These projections are clearly overly optimistic and beyond 1992-93 totally unbelievable, given that they are based on wildly hopeful economic and productivity growth forecasts.

But even if we believe these crystal ball projections for the Budget deficit, the Government is forcing on Australia a massive public sector financing task in the years ahead. On the basis of its own figures, the Government will need to finance cumulative Budget deficits of at least $18 billion between 1991-92 and 1995-96.

In the period to 30 June 1994 we are looking at a financing task totalling $19.4 billion. This is on the Government's own figures. The `One Job' statement will thus see the Government issuing new debt of around $20 billion to pay for this unfunded spending spree. This is on top of the approximately $35 billion in Commonwealth debt currently on issue. The projected increases represent nearly a 60 per cent escalation in the value of Commonwealth government securities on issue at the present time.

For a statement that promises to deliver 500,000 new jobs over and above the 300,000 destroyed by the Government's recession, this entails unfunded spending of $40,000 per job, plus interest, making it perhaps the most expensive job creation scheme in the history of the Commonwealth. The impact of this new debt will be to place upward pressure on interest rates and the exchange rate, with all that entails for the Australian economy, over the life of this `One Job' statement.

To the extent that the Government has understated the total cost of the statement and the subsequent financing tasks that it will generate, these problems will be even more severe. We already know that the Budget deficit to December 1991 amounted to $7.5 billion—although this is partly attributable to the pattern of outlays and revenue collections—which means that the result cannot be extrapolated to give a Budget outcome for the remainder of this financial year. But we do have private sector forecasts that are suggesting a $9 billion Budget deficit for 1991-92, even before allowing for the fiscal impact of the new measures contained in the `One Job' statement.

We are thus faced with the immediate and medium term prospect of a huge blow-out in public sector debt, with adverse consequences for interest rates and the exchange rate under the `One Job' statement. The private sector will find itself competing for funds with the Commonwealth and the rest of the public sector, undermining the productive investment by the private sector that we need to ensure a sustainable recovery over the longer term. This compares most unfavourably with the anticipated reduction in public sector debt of $13 billion under the coalition's Fightback package.

It should be noted that the `One Job' statement contains a significant number of worthwhile spending initiatives by the Federal Government—measures which the coalition could perhaps be expected to support. Indeed, most of the worthwhile measures in the economic statement—the `One Job' statement—are lifted straight from the pages of the coalition's Fightback manual. However, we cannot uncritically condone a spending and tax package that is totally unfunded, as is the `One Job' statement.

Perhaps the biggest contrast between Fightback and the `One Job' statement is the way in which Fightback has been fully funded down to the last dollar. The coalition would have rightly been subjected to enormous criticism if it had produced a package containing unfunded spending or unfunded tax cuts. Yet, by some peculiar double standard, the Government thinks it can get away with a totally unfunded package. In fact, the Government damns its `One Job' statement out of its own mouth when it makes allegations about funding holes in the expenditure side of Fightback, while at the same time presiding over its own totally unfunded package. The Government simply cannot have it both ways.

It is interesting that while the Government looks for funding holes in Fightback, on the basis of the Government's own growth projections, the coalition could implement both the Fightback and the `One Job' economic package out of its fiscal surplus without increasing public sector debt. That gives an indication as to how conservative and fiscally responsible the coalition's Fightback package really is, especially when one considers that we have made no allowance for any possible incentive effects the Fightback package may have on the level of economic activity.

The `One Job' statement contains just over $1 billion in new infrastructure spending. The most important point to be made about this proposed new infrastructure spending is that it will not make up for the deliberate run-down in capital outlays by this Commonwealth Government since 1983-84, which has been one of the principal contributors to the Budget surpluses that the Government was able to deliver briefly up until the 1990-91 financial year. The surplus was, of course, built principally on increases in revenue collections, particularly PAYE tax receipts—the great tax grab of the 1980s.

While there was some restraint in outlays, this fell almost entirely on grants to the States, asset sales and capital spending. There was very little restraint in Commonwealth recurrent consumption spending. This occurred despite widespread recognition of the deterioration in the quantity and quality of Australia's national infrastructure over recent years.

The run-down in this country's national infrastructure has had adverse consequences for our economic well-being. Economically viable infrastructure spending is the only area of government spending that can be productive. It is an important input into the production processes and the production capacity of the private sector, serving to enhance the value of national output.

Government spending for consumption purposes, by contrast, does little or nothing to enhance national output. The run-down in Commonwealth capital spending is one of the reasons that private expenditure for investment purposes and the profitability of private capital has suffered so heavily under this Government.

The Government's approach to fiscal policy since 1983 has been to favour consumption spending at the expense of public sector investment—that was one of the ways in which the Government delivered its much vaunted but short-lived surpluses. Now the Government turns around and announces a massive increase in capital works spending and expects to take credit for all the ensuing benefits that have been postponed by its neglect of the national infrastructure over the past nine years.

Public sector investment has often been neglected by government because it is easier to cut back on capital expenditure than to cut back on public consumption spending, for obvious political reasons. However, people are becoming increasingly conscious of the appalling state of the country's roads and other elements of the national infrastructure and the effects this is having on economic activity. Clearly, the Government now thinks there are votes in increasing public sector investment; votes which can be easily had because this new spending is not to be paid for by cuts in government consumption spending or by increased taxes under the Government's `One Job' statement.

But it would be surprising if people did not blame the current Government for the present state of our national infrastructure and take a very dim view indeed of any attempt by the Government to claim credit for improvements subsequent to the increased spending which is envisaged in the `One Job' statement. They certainly will not be impressed by the higher interest rates and higher exchange rate that the Government's unfunded spending will force upon them in the medium term.

From a macro-economic point of view, much of the capital spending and the fiscal stimulus contained in this statement is poorly timed. For any fiscal stimulus to be effective in supporting possible economic recovery it must be well planned and put in place early to contribute to any upswing.

It is widely recognised that governments should seek to smooth public capital and consumption expenditure over time, so as not exacerbate the peaks and troughs of economic cycles. This can be done only through the adoption of fiscal rules similar to the rules often advocated in relation to the conduct of monetary policy.

It is obvious that the Government has missed the boat entirely when it comes to making a contribution to recovery from the recession through the fiscal stimulus contained in its `One Job' statement. Any such fiscal stimulus needs to take place during the slide into, not the climb out of, recession. Scandalously, at the time the slide into recession was taking place, the Government was busy denying that any such recession was imminent, let alone doing something about it—for example, by way of the infrastructure spending which was warranted at that time. Instead, the Government claimed that we were meant to be heading towards a `slowdown' or a `soft landing'—quaint terms which I am sure are remembered by many people in this country. The Government got it dreadfully wrong then and it is now about to compound that mistake by applying fiscal stimulus too late in the economic cycle.

The spending comes at the end of the most protracted recession in 60 years. We have had six quarters of negative growth, but it is only now, when there are some tentative signs of a weak recovery, that the Government slams down on the fiscal accelerator. It would be surprising if the new spending contained in the `One Job' statement did serve to stimulate overall economic activity to a significant extent in the foreseeable future. Instead, it will be more likely to serve to crowd out private sector investment during the crucial phases of the prospective economic recovery by forcing up interest rates.

The fiscal stimulus may temporarily accelerate economic growth before monetary policy needs to be tightened and growth slowed due to the foreign debt constraint, thereby putting us back on the boom-bust cycle so beloved of this Government. The role traditionally played by this Government's mishandling of monetary policy is now to be taken over by the mismanagement of fiscal policy. Having totally abused one instrument of policy, which gave us record high interest rates and the worst recession in 60 years, the Government is going to have a fiddle with another policy instrument that is equally useless, if not extremely dangerous, when used in a discretionary manner. Economists now recognise that such discretionary use of policy instruments requires extremely accurate economic forecasting—forecasting which may be beyond what is currently achievable by the economics profession.

The associated economic modelling must also exhibit a high degree of independence from the setting of economic policy for its integrity to be maintained; yet the `One Job' statement is built around an extremely limited model, constructed especially for the purposes of the very same statement, which clearly embodies a large number of imported and dubious assumptions. It is little wonder that the growth and other forecasts contained in the Government's scenario have been the subject of such heavy criticism. The integrity of this statement as a macro-economic policy instrument is entirely dependent on this modelling exercise; yet, by all accounts, this model—to use an expression of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—is not worth a bean, let alone a row of beans.

Again, the contrast with the approach taken by the coalition in Fightback could not be more stark. We did not build a model specifically to give us the desired results. We ran our package through an existing and highly-regarded model used not just by the coalition but by no less an authority than the Treasury itself. The results of this exercise are well known, as are the results generated by running the Government's `One Nation, One Job' statement through the same model, demonstrating the Government's package to be a disaster for Australia.

The Government's modelling of its `One Job' economic statement includes the crucial assumption of unprecedented productivity gains—gains far in excess of anything we have ever before seen achieved in Australia. Between 1985-86 and 1988-89 gross product per hour worked in Australia increased by a miserable one per cent compound per annum. Somehow the Government thinks it can put this experience behind it and deliver a massive productivity growth over the next few years.

The `One Job' statement is almost entirely devoid of any new micro-economic reform initiatives that just might deliver such unprecedented productivity growth, so we can be forgiven for asking just where this increased productivity will come from. We know that it will not be coming from the labour market, in which the Government is held hostage by the ACTU to an even greater extent than it is in other policy areas. It will not be coming from any of the host of other areas of potential structural reform totally neglected by this `One Job' statement—areas that have been identified for some time now as crucial micro-economic reform initiatives. We also have the curious double standard whereby the Government has used one set of inflation and growth forecasts for its `One Job' economic statement and an entirely different set for its analysis of the coalition's Fightback package. Mr Des Moore said of the `One Job' statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The assumptions on which these projections are based are so implausible as to suggest that they have been constructed by starting with a desired result and then producing projections to fit. It is of serious concern that a government should seemingly attempt to deceive the electorate in such a way.

In the end, it is important that the increasingly arcane battle of models does not distract attention from the substance of the policies contained in each of the statements. Clearly, Fightback is the more comprehensive of the two packages. It is this commitment to comprehensive economic reform—not mere tinkering—that puts the Fightback package ahead of the `One Job' statement. Moreover, the Fightback package is not dependent on the realisation of a bogus economic scenario to deliver its promised benefits.

PARA.TAB: It is entirely appropriate that this House roundly criticises the Government for the failure of its `One Job' statement. The Government has had nine long years to get things right. In that time we have had dozens of economic statements, mini-Budgets and full Budgets. We have had three such statements in the last 12 months, not including the last Budget. Whenever things are going wrong, it seems to be a case of, `Let's have another statement'. We never see the results of it. We never see a reduction in the nearly one million people actually out of work and the nearly two million people either out of work or seriously underemployed.

We have had three statements in the last 12 months, not one of which has come to terms with the major problem of unemployment in this country. There was the March 1991 industry policy statement, the November 1991 jobs statement—that was a misnomer if ever there was one—and now we have the `One Job' statement. I would think that after all this time the Government would have learned the lesson that half-measures and incomplete policy statements cannot by their very nature deliver what is required to return this country to prosperity.

What is needed is a commitment to comprehensive economic reform. The coalition's Fightback package contains that commitment. The Government's `One Job' statement, regrettably, does not. It is extremely doubtful that it can save the one job it was intended to preserve—that is, the Prime Minister's. That would be the most positive outcome of the Government's contemptuously misnamed economic statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Appropriation Bills cognately. The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), in his second reading speech, adequately covered the appropriations of a broad range of departments. I believe that today in

SPEECH.PARA: the debate on the censure motion he not only blew holes in the Opposition's arguments about models—and we have heard about several models from the other side of the House—but clearly indicated the substances on this side of the House.

PARA.TAB: There are several areas in the appropriations that I would like to discuss, particularly rural matters such as the rural adjustment scheme, funding and support, the extra appropriations in regard to RAS of some $33.9m, and a $25m increase in funding for the black spots road program—all of which I think are very important.

I would also like to cover some of the points made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). There will certainly be a comparison over time of the policies contained in the Government's One Nation statement and the Opposition's policies. The Opposition says that it is about reform. Reform means actually improving things. The Opposition's Fightback package is actually going back in time; going back to the Opposition's future. I think it is important to recognise—I have said this before in the House and I will say it again—that the One Nation statement and the Fightback package indicate the clear divisions in philosophy between the Government and the Opposition more clearly now than at any other time since the early part of this century.

I would like to go into that matter in detail. The One Nation statement is about recovery. We are not about talking down the economy; we are not about talking down confidence. It is disappointing that, from time to time—almost every day—we hear in the House the Opposition talking down the economy, talking down investment, and looking at and promoting negative aspects of the Australian economy. I do not think that is healthy, I do not think it is Australian; I think it is un-Australian. It is certainly not beneficial to this nation. There are many positive aspects we can talk about.

The One Nation statement is about providing infrastructure for transportation—particularly for rail and for ports—in order to improve our export potential. Of course, we can be very proud of the money that will be going into TAFE and into education. In the last few weeks I have had the privilege of opening extensions to two private schools in my electorate. These schools will benefit significantly from the something like $1.3 billion which has been allocated to non-government schools in 1992. Of course, another $1.3 billion approximately has been allocated to government schools. The Federal Government has allocated something like $2.6 billion to education this year.

Education is the key to equality; it is the way in which we can open the doors to give people better opportunities. It is disappointing that the Opposition does not have a priority in education or training. Under the Opposition's Fightback package, only the wealthy will have access to a university education and the opportunity to progress and reach for the stars.

There are some other broad differences between the two packages. There is a broad difference with regard to industrial relations. We heard the previous speaker criticise the industrial relations policy of the Government. I think we can be very proud of our industrial relations policy. We have brought Australians together and, as a consequence of consultation, we have seen the Australian Council of Trade Unions adopt a responsible manner and play a very responsible role in bargaining and arguing for improved conditions for the men and women whom it represents.

I think it is fair to say that the working men and women of this country have made a massive contribution to improving our competitiveness. We have seen a reduction of some 8 per cent in unit labour costs since Labor came to power. That is a massive contribution. We have seen inflation go down to 3 per cent, which improves the competitiveness of our mining sector and our exports.

It is always interesting to note that those on the other side of the House—particularly those in the National Party of Australia—complain about the dollar and say that it should be lower. The dollar has traded lower under Labor than it ever did under the Opposition parties when in government. The National Party fails to recognise that we floated the dollar. This improved our competitiveness and improved our export potential. I think that is something it has forgotten.

One of the things I would like to focus on in regard to the effect of revenue and taxation is the consumption tax, or the tax of 15 per cent, that would be levied on people across Australia, particularly those in provincial, rural and farming areas such as my electorate. In 1990 when we were involved in the embargo against Iraq and the military action which took place, we saw a massive rise in fuel prices, we saw grain prices drop, we saw drought towards the end of 1990. We saw the massive effect of all of this, as well as the consequences of surplus, on the rural sector—sugar, wheat, grains and the wool industry. We saw the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), in particular, and his fellow Party members running around Australia trying to regain some of the support they had lost through the corruption issues in Queensland by crying sympathy—nothing else; just sympathy—and saying that rural Australia was in crisis and that the Government was to blame.

I think it is important to recognise what the National Party now has to offer rural Australia. It offers a consumption tax of 15 per cent, which will mean that more than 60 per cent of all farming families will be between $4 and $22 per week worse off. In other words, the Leader of the National Party will tax 60 per cent of those farmers he said he felt for and cared for by between $4 and $22 per week. I do not think that indicates much compassion at all.

It is interesting that, while 60 per cent of farmers will be worse off, the Leader of the National Party will get a tax cut of $150 per week. After bracket creep, he will receive a benefit of $68 per week—not just him, but all people on that level of income. I think that highlights the fact that the consumption tax will not benefit the rural community.

Last night during a debate on the coarse grains legislation the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), rightfully pointed out that the average grain producer will have a net income of $30,000 this year. What will the Fightback package do for him? He will have to pay 15 per cent on all of the basic necessities of life. He will be worse off; he will not benefit one iota.

We then move to an issue which is at the real heart of rural Australia. One of the most important issues, and one which was raised and debated during the last election, is that of roads and road funding. I think it is important to look at what the Opposition has to offer in regard to roads. The National Party Leader has run around Queensland, in particular, saying that the Opposition will abolish excise. But what will replace excise? Page 58 of Fightback! states:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the longer term, responsibility for road funding will be transferred to the National Road Transport Commission and roads will be funded through user charges as proposed in the current negotiations. . .

In other words, excise will be abolished and road user charges will replace road funding. I well remember approximately two years ago when the Butcher report—the ISC report—was presented containing the recommendation for road user charges in conjunction with excise for the maintenance of roads. There was a hue and cry from rural groups, local government associations and road transport associations to the effect that using road user charges in conjunction with excise would break the rural community.

PARA.TAB: So what does the National Party propose to do? It proposes to fund all roads by road user charges only. If part road user charges in conjunction with excise will be a massive impost on the rural community and on the beef industry in particular—some producers have to travel hundreds of kilometres from the Gulf to a railhead or a particular city—what will total road user charges do to the rural communities? So far, the Queensland Local Government Association—which is run by a National Party stooge—has not said anything. But when this starts to bite and when farmers start to realise they will have to pay thousands of dollars on their own vehicles, and when the transport associations realise they will have to pay thousands of dollars in order to fund roads, there will be a hue and cry. If there is not and if the charges do not run into thousands of dollars, that means only one thing: the roads will fall apart, crumble and disappear. One of those two things will occur.

This year the Federal Government will be spending $1.65 billion directly on roads. That is not counting untied grants that go to roads from States and local authorities. Those dollars will have to come out of road user charges if the Opposition is going to maintain the same level of funding for roads. I have publicly challenged the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party, who has gone dead quiet on this issue, to state what level of road user charges will be imposed in order to maintain roads. What has happened? He has disappeared. He has not said a word. The best way to get the Leader of the National Party to go quietly is either to mention the Fitzgerald inquiry or to mention road user charges—he disappears straight away.

One of the other aspects of Fightback which I totally oppose, and which is absolutely crazy, is the idea to privatise port authorities and promote competition within them. I say here and now that I have the best port authority in Australia in Gladstone. The Gladstone Port Authority, which handles 5 per cent of Australia's exports—30 million tonnes of shipping a year—is the best port authority in Australia. The amount of money that authority puts into the city of Gladstone is incredible. It is a massive and wonderful corporate organisation for the city and for central Queensland. I totally oppose the proposition of the Opposition, and of the State Opposition, in wanting to privatise organisations like the Gladstone Port Authority. It is absolutely crazy.

There is another issue that really stands us apart. It is an issue that not only amuses me but also confuses me. The Leader of the National Party says in one of his releases that he wants in the longer term to abolish tariffs on imports of agricultural machinery and spare parts ahead of the ultimate abolition of protection by the year 2000. So in eight years tariffs are going to be abolished under the Opposition's Fightback, and the Leader of the National Party wants to speed it up. That is very fine if that is his point of view.

But the Leader of the National Party in the Senate was running all around Queensland only a few weeks ago with a story, saying that the overall impact of tariffs coming off will be a flood of subsidised sugar coming into Australia. Senator Ron Boswell is opposing the reduction in tariffs. There is either a communication problem between the Fightback package, Senator Boswell as the Leader of the Nationals in the Senate and the Leader of the National Party in the House of Representatives, or Senator Boswell fails to understand plain English or is simply not telling the truth. I am not accusing him of telling an untruth; I am simply making the observation that what he is saying in regard to tariffs is diametrically opposed to what the Opposition is proposing.

Over the last few years the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) has been a backwoods regulator and public protectionist, along with his mate the editor of the Proserpine paper, who has criticised me for supporting freer trade and the abolition of the sugar embargo. He has cried puppy-dog tears every time tariffs have come down, but has embraced with open arms the Fightback package. I do not know whether he has been prepared to tell the sugar growers in his area that he supports the abolition of tariffs on sugar within eight years but, if he has not, I am certainly going to tell them, as I am going to tell all the sugar growers not only in my area, but right throughout the State, that what Senator Boswell says does not stand up and is totally and diametrically opposed to his own Party's policy and his own Party's position vis-a-vis the Fightback package.

If Senator Boswell disagrees with that, he should publicly walk away from the Fightback package. But what he cannot do, and what the Nationals in Queensland cannot do, like the honourable member for Dawson, is have a dollar each way. They cannot be backwoods regulators and protectionists at home and then come here and put their arms around the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), saying, `We are with you all the way'. They have been caught out and they are going to be made to stand to account.

When the general public rightfully makes a determination at the next election between the One Nation statement and the Fightback package, surely to goodness it will be incumbent on politicians on both sides of the House to tell the public exactly what their policies stand for and let the community make a rational judgment. I pose this question: how can any primary producers, particularly those who want to maintain some level of tariff or protection, formulate an opinion on the position of the Queensland National Party or the Federal National Party when we have Senator Boswell opposing tariff reductions, the Leader of the National Party on the record as supporting a speeding up of tariff cuts, and the honourable member for Dawson embracing the Fightback package, which means the abolition of tariffs in eight years?

In the Australian of 16 April 1991 we saw the heading `Nationals split on backing tariff cuts'. Then today's Australian says there is pressure on the shadow Minister in regard to tariff cuts. That is all very fine. I really do not mind what sort of internecine warfare is held between members of the Opposition, but when we have some members—and senior members—of the Opposition promoting protection on the one hand, and another senior member of the National Party promoting the abolition of tariffs on the other, it is confusing to me and it certainly must be confusing to farmers.

Is it any wonder that we really need to ask this question: will the Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), be prepared to stand up and state his position? Does he stand for the abolition of tariffs in eight years, as he said in his press release, and will he bring Senator Boswell in and tell him to tell the truth and stick to the Fightback package? Will Senator Boswell be allowed to run around Queensland telling whatever story he wishes, and maintain his position on the Senate ticket to please the League of Rights and the Ku Klux Klan, or will he be made to be accountable and stick with the Fightback package?

I know it is going to be messy, because I have been criticised for supporting a reduction in tariffs. But ironically we will have a level of tariff protection, low though it may well be, under Labor. The Opposition is going to wipe it out. The irony is that the very argument that people such as Senator Boswell and the hillbillies in the National Party in Queensland have used for so long to hit us over the head with like a stick will be the very thing that convicts them. They will finally have to tell their own constituents that they support the Fightback package and thus support the abolition of tariffs in eight years. That is the point I would like to make.

That points to a massive break in the whole wall of the Fightback package, because if the tariffs do not stick, and if the Leader of the National Party in the Senate can say something on the public record that is totally contradictory to the Fightback package—and the Leader of the National Party in this House is not prepared publicly to discipline him and yet supports the speeding up of the abolition of tariffs—that means not only that there is a division, but also that we do not know which model or which aspect of the Fightback package in regard to tariffs the Opposition stands for. It then begs the question: what about tax, what about education and what about health? What about Medicare? What about the number of farmers who are doing it tough and cannot afford private insurance? How will they be treated under the new proposition of the Opposition, whereby Medicare will be torn apart bit by bit, limb by limb, arm by arm? As we go across all those other areas we will see it slowly fall down, brick by brick. Just as the Berlin Wall fell down, so too will the Fightback package.

Today with the comments in the Australian we see that the problems in regard to tariffs are just the start. After all the rhetoric and the nonsense that have been used by the Boswells, the O'Chees and Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen, all the nonsense over the last two years by the voodoo protectionists and backwoods regulators such as the honourable member for Dawson, now they have to stand up and say whether they really support that line or whether they support Fightback. They cannot do both. If they walk away from the nonsense they have peddled for the last two years, then they are in real trouble with their own constituents.

A 15 per cent goods and services tax on the fruit and vegetable industry, on farmers produce, and a 15 per cent tax on the tourist industry, in the seat of Dawson, in the Whitsundays, will do more damage than a cyclone. It will devastate the tourist industry. Of course, the honourable member for Dawson embraces that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bills before the House deal with certain funding arrangements in relation to the Government's overall budgetary policy. I take this opportunity to debate a broader range of economic matters and budgetary policies. In particular, it is important to consider the impact of the economic statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I will be concentrating on it from two perspectives: firstly, its significance to small business across Australia and, secondly, its impact within my own electorate of Forrest.

PARA.TAB: I would like to turn the attention of the House to the small business sector and consider what the Prime Minister's plans will mean for the single most important economic group in Australia.The importance of the small business sector must never be underestimated. Small business owners employ just on half of the private sector work force and contribute some 40 per cent to value added in this country. Notwithstanding this, the small business sector, which has suffered the most under this Government's economic policy onslaught in recent years—it has faced spiralling costs, including a crushing tax regime, an inflexible industrial relations system and drastic cuts in business activity due to the recession which the Prime Minister, the then Treasurer, said we had to have—has been decimated.

One of the most significant measures of the health of the small business sector is the level of bankruptcy. This vital economic indicator shows that the number of businesses forced into bankruptcy increased by 50.3 per cent in the 1990-91 financial year over the previous year.

My own background is in small business. Quite frankly, I believe a person has to be either brave or extremely stupid to go into business today. Of course, there is a lot of truth in the comment that any businesses which can survive, let alone prosper, in today's depressed economy will be in a strong position to gain when the economy turns around. The question is: when will this happen? When will the real interest rates be competitive with overseas rates and when will unemployment decline, thereby promoting retail demand? When will personal income tax rates be reduced sufficiently to give average Australians greater spending power and when will Australia reach its potential as a dominant exporter in world markets?

If the Prime Minister's economic statement is anything to go by, I for one will not be holding my breath waiting for these outcomes. Certainly it is encouraging that the Government has belatedly accepted the need for change in economic direction. After plunging Australia into recession because of its inability to do much apart from tightening monetary policy by pushing interest rates through the roof, the Government has at last been talking about the need for widespread reforms.

It is ironic that the same man who gave us the worst recession in 60 years has now said `I am sorry' to the Australian people and has admitted that we need economic policy reform. The problem is that some of the Prime Minister's so-called reforms will do more harm than good. Undoubtedly, the most significant part of the Government's budgetary approach is its decision to go on a $2.3 billion spending spree. The Prime Minister says this is needed to kick-start the economy—the same economy that he strangled to death with his own hands.

Indeed, some of the items of expenditure in themselves are commendable. For example, the emphasis on road, rail and electricity infrastructure is a ready admission by the Government of its failure to make improvements in nearly a decade of Labor leadership. These reforms do not withstand rigorous scrutiny. For example, what is the point of moving towards a single gauge rail system without first ensuring substantial productivity improvements are gained in the running of the railway system? What is the point of improving our roads without reducing freight operating costs, especially fuel prices?

The most damming criticism I have of the Government's spending programs is that they are unfunded. The Prime Minister has locked Australia into a Budget deficit for the next four years at least. In other words, the Government will be spending borrowed money because it simply does not have the guts to put its own House in order.

The Prime Minister and his new Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) have already demonstrated that they are unable to get their sums right. This hardly inspires confidence in their economic management of this country. Indeed, the Government has already taken the nation from a surplus of $1.9 billion this year to a forecast deficit of some $6.8 billion. Now we are told to expect a staggering $8 billion deficit in the year 1992-93. As if this were not bad enough, it is highly likely the Government's forecast could be wrong, in which case the forthcoming deficits would be even worse than the Prime Minister has admitted to.

I remind honourable members opposite that their Government has developed an extremely bad record of inaccurate Budget forecasts. In the year 1990-91 we were told to expect a huge surplus of more than $8.1 billion, but the actual result was in fact less than $1.9 billion. The Treasurer, now Prime Minister, scored just 23 per cent for accuracy in that case. He then forecast a deficit in 1991-92 of $4.7 billion but now admits the Budget will be as much as $6.8 billion in the red by the end of this financial year. In short, the Government will have taken Australia from a forecast surplus of $8.1 billion to a deficit of $8 billion in just two years. This is a turnaround of more than $16 billion and a clear demonstration of how unstable the Government's budgetary process has become. Of course, if the new Treasurer's forecasting is as inaccurate as that of his predecessor, we may witness an even worse result.

The bottom line is that the Government is pushing up Australia's level of debt at a time when we can least afford it. With foreign debt at nearly $200 billion, it amazes me that the Prime Minister plans to spend borrowed money to take the nation even further into the red.

I will not pretend to hide the fact that the Prime Minister's economic statement was a clever political instrument aimed at clawing back some of the electoral support this Government has lost in recent times, especially after the launch of the coalition's Fightback package. It is also designed to appear tough while actually not treading on any toes. For example, there is much talk about the need for a response to resource developments, but there is still no commitment on Coronation Hill. Last month's statement was couched in terms which could persuade many people that this Government will free up the centralised industrial relations system. Also, there was considerable emphasis on the need for genuine tax reform and tax reductions for wage and salary earners.

Behind this facade is the truth of it all, and the truth is that the so-called economic statement is nothing more than a grab bag of ideas cobbled together and promoted as an economic strategy. There is no common theme and no broad thrust for reform. More importantly, some of the more appealing aspects of the statement have their foundations set in quicksand. Immediately after the Prime Minister finished his speech, financial markets fell, reflecting the business community's apprehension and mistrust of the statement. Since then the nation's peak welfare group has slammed the Government's proposed tax cuts because they would actually make low income earners worse off. Even families on joint incomes of around $30,000 would be worse off according to ACOSS.

Overall there has been widespread scepticism of the Government's ability to deliver any of its long term commitments. The danger is that we will end up with a massive foreign debt and a crippling budget deficit with very little to show for it.

Let us consider where the small business sector fits within this scenario. Certainly the Prime Minister acknowledges the importance of small business and even goes so far as to say that many small businesses have experienced some difficulty in the present downturn. This is his understated way of describing the economic nightmare which has forced nearly 14,000 small businesses into bankruptcy in the last 12 months and has resulted in many more business owners simply closing their doors and walking away. Perhaps the Government's refusal to acknowledge the full extent of the situation helps explain why so little emphasis has been given to assisting small business in the Prime Minister's statement. While some measures will assist small business, the fact remains it is really too little too late.

Take changes such as the capital gains tax, for instance. Here we have the single biggest disincentive for small business owners to expand their operations. It is also responsible for stripping away the incentive and the reward for years of hard work by individual small business owners. Instead of major reform to the capital gains tax, the Government has tinkered around the edge by merely increasing tax-free thresholds from 20 per cent of goodwill to 50 per cent subject to certain eligibility criteria.

What incentive is this for a business owner who is thinking about expanding to bigger premises, thereby enabling him to take advantage of a new plant, better warehousing facilities and even hire some additional staff? This opportunity is being stripped from him. In this case, selling up existing premises could result in a significant capital gains tax assessment which would reduce the level of capital available for reinvestment in the expanded operation. On the other hand, allowing a tax free rollover of these funds would ensure that the full value of the sale of existing plant and premises could be ploughed back into the productive objective of expanding the business enterprise in question. This, of course, is the coalition's policy and highlights our genuine concern to assist small businesses which are striving to get on but which have been held back by an excessive tax burden imposed by this Government.

By comparison with the Government's refusal to acknowledge that the capital gains tax takes away the reward for many years of hard work, we have decided to introduce a range of concessions to small business owners who sell up or retire. Under our plans, capital gains of less than $3,000 would be tax free, while a business owner aged 60 or over could sell up and retire with no tax on gains of up to 10 times average annual earnings. That is currently around $300,000. All this is in addition to tax-free thresholds on goodwill.

How do the capital gains tax changes proposed by the Government compare with the coalition's Fightback initiatives? Obviously, the bottom line is how much tax will be saved by the small business sector under each proposal. Under the Prime Minister's proposal, and by his own admission, small business will save just $10m annually as a result of his Government's fiddling of the present capital gains tax system. Under the coalition's Fightback reforms, small business will save considerably more—40 times more in fact. Indeed, our proposals will cut capital gains tax imposed on small business by $200m in a full year. Unlike the Prime Minister's grab bag of give-aways, the coalition's tax reforms are fully funded as part of our comprehensive economic reforms.

The only other measure in the Prime Minister's statement aimed specifically at small business is the deferral of income tax for some companies. However, this has only been necessary as a result of the previous tax changes which impacted on the cash flows of small businesses. A number of new general policies will benefit some small businesses. For example, funding for export measures has been increased. However, the fact still remains that only 700 of the existing 800,000 small businesses will be encouraged to export over the next three-year period.

In some ways, the Prime Minister has actually discriminated against small business. For example, the move to reduce sales tax on passenger vehicles means that most business operators will be at a relative disadvantage over private buyers. By dropping the rate of wholesale sales tax on passenger vehicles to 15 per cent, the Government has reduced the prices paid by private individuals and by businesses which use the same sedans and station wagons. However, most small businesses do not use these types of vehicles solely for business purposes. The vehicles that are used principally or solely for small business are utilities, vans, delivery trucks, motorcycles for courier work, and other specialised vehicles. Yet none of these are included in the Prime Minister's statement of initiatives.

This is a clear indication that the so-called economic statement was in fact a political statement first and foremost. If we compare these hotchpotch tax changes with the coalition's concise commitment to abolish wholesale sales tax on all vehicles and to scrap fuel excise, it is easy to see why the Government's new scheme has caused little excitement within the small business community. Likewise, the Government's proposals in the field of industrial relations sound impressive but do not stand up to scrutiny.

Small business desperately needs a more flexible wages system so that each business can negotiate its own wages and conditions with its employees, subject to certain minimum wage safeguards. This is the only way to ensure that outdated concepts, such as penalty rates and restrictive work practices, can be discarded in favour of all-embracing employment contracts which suit the individual enterprise and which benefit productive and hardworking employees.

Unfortunately, the Government talks about workplace bargaining but its plans have little relevance to the small business sector, despite the significant bearing this issue has on the degree of competitiveness amongst smaller enterprises. More importantly, some would say that the massive burden of business costs has not been addressed by the Prime Minister's statement. For example, there has been no assault on the costs imposed by the wholesale sales tax, payroll tax, the training levy or the fuel tax, despite the crippling burden these taxes impose on business costs across the nation. We have to do something to reduce these costs if our private sector is to have any chance in keeping up with foreign competition, and yet the Government has done little more than pay lip service to this vital issue. The irony is that the Government talks about the need for business reform and the need to generate employment. Yet whenever it has the opportunity to take the tough decisions needed to address these problems, it runs a mile. The facts are very simple: these costs are crippling small businesses and costing jobs. Let us consider the taxes we pay today, especially payroll tax. This is a tax on the number of employees a business hires. There is no link to the profitability of a business or to any service the Government provides in return for the tax. The end result is that payroll tax reduces the private sector's capacity to employ. In harsh, cold economic terms, it makes people less competitive against other business inputs. In everyday English, it means that payroll tax costs jobs.

It is now well known that the coalition committed itself to abolishing payroll tax along with six other taxes. Our plans include scrapping the wholesale sales tax in favour of a fairer goods and services tax and rebating all taxes paid on business inputs. Overall, our Fightback strategy will reduce business costs by some $20 billion. This will be of enormous benefit to Australian businesses struggling to remain viable or to compete with overseas competitors. Another aspect of crucial economic importance is the need to promote development within Australia's resources sector to stimulate exports and to reduce our balance of payments by increased import substitution.

To this end, the Government has announced its commitment to a concept of resource security. Again, I welcome its belated recognition of the problems confronting our resources sector. However, this problem is entirely the Government's own doing. Instead of imposing a uniform, stable approach to resource issues, the Government all too often has acted according to short term political expediency. Senator Richardson's love affair with the Green movement saw a swing towards anti-development policies and killed off a number of major investment proposals. Now, faced with the stark reality of record unemployment and declining levels of new investment, down 14.5 per cent nationally on the latest annual figures, the Prime Minister would have us believe that his economic statement is strongly pro-development.

Certainly, some measures were welcome, including relaxing foreign investment guidelines and introducing more favourable depreciation arrangements. But I must question whether some measures are more cosmetic than anything else. For example, the new unit to be established to facilitate major projects looks good on paper. However, even the Prime Minister admits that many resource development issues are complex and cross over State-Federal boundaries of authority. In any event, what good would this new unit have done when the Government blocked Wesley Vale or Coronation Hill? None whatsoever, I would suggest.

Indeed, I do not blame our resources sector, particularly the timber industry, if it becomes more than a little disenchanted with its political representatives on the other side of the House. For instance, it is no wonder, after years of instability in the timber industry due to fluctuating levels of support from government, that the industry so desperately wants resource security cemented in place by legislation. Unfortunately, the Government's proposed legislation does not hold up to close inspection, as members on this side of the House pointed out during debate on the Forest Conservation and Development Bill. Coronation Hill, Wesley Vale and Marandoo, in my own State, have all become synonymous with the Federal Government's failure to come to terms with the importance of our resources sector and the damage that such poor decision making can cause to the nation's economic reputation.

It is all very well to talk about the need for more favourable depreciation allowances and sustained lower interest rates to attract large scale investors, but where is the incentive to spend well in excess of $1 billion on a state of the art pulp mill if there is no certainty that the raw materials will be available in the quantity required in years to come? The small business sector may not actually undertake a particular major resource project but the flow-on benefits to the small business sector are considerable. Orders flow-on to small businesses and their communities is vitally important in this country. In my electorate of Forrest the benefits will be substantial if the Government puts meaningful reforms in place. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) made a number of quite extraordinary assertions which I will deal with in a few moments. Let me give one example: he talked very critically of the growth in the deficit during the present financial year and over the last year or two, arguing that this would add to government debt as though this were a terrible thing. The fact of the matter is that Australian government debt is the second lowest, as a proportion of national income, of any Western country. I am disappointed that the honourable member could not afford the time to wait to hear what I have to say about his speech.
—Are you proud of it?

—I am indeed. I am disappointed that the honourable member is not prepared to involve himself in serious debate because he made some very serious mistakes. The fact of the matter is that our debt, as a proportion of national income, is one of the lowest in the Western world. The honourable member was confusing government debt with overseas debt. Of course we have a high overseas debt. That is a real worry. It is essential that we improve our current account position and, of course, this statement is aimed at doing that. I will come to the reasons why it will do it effectively in a moment.

PARA.TAB: It is an elementary mistake to confuse public debt with overseas debt and that was what the honourable member was doing. It is absolutely responsible for a government to increase its outlays at a time when the economy is recessed. It is absolutely essential that the Government do what it can to build up economic activity—and thus employment—at a time when there is a recession. The honourable member seemed to imply that he did not want that to happen. It is an extraordinarily irresponsible approach and that is consistent with the package of measures which the Opposition is now putting forward.

The Opposition is suggesting that by increasing indirect taxes through a goods and services tax which will increase the rate of inflation it will somehow improve the state of the economy. The logical consequence of introducing a goods and services tax is that inflation will rise. The Opposition does not dispute that; in fact, it accepts that the rate of inflation will go up by around 4 per cent. That will inevitably lead to an increase in interest rates. An increase in interest rates will depress the economy further and unemployment will rise. It is an extraordinary package of measures to be putting forward at a time when the economy is already recessed.

If one links that to the fact that the Opposition proposed to cut back on public outlays—so that not only will the quality and extent of public services decline, but also the Government will reduce its impact on economic activity and so contribute to further recession—one can see that it is talking about a major recessionary package. It is an extraordinarily perverse macro-economic approach.

Let me turn to more positive things. It is true that we are only just beginning to come out of a very severe recession. We have very high unemployment: about 960,000 people out of work. That is a tragedy of the first order which the Government accepts as a tragedy of the first order. The question is: how do we recover from that as rapidly as possible? An elementary beginning must be the introduction of what are called counter-cyclical policies. The Government should do everything in its power to lift the level of economic activity.

Fortunately, there are also some great strengths in the present situation. One of the very striking things is that, despite the fact that we are only just beginning to come out of a recession, our exports earnings, particularly for manufacturing goods, have been growing very rapidly. In fact, I have just received a recent analysis by the trade analysis section of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade which is dated March 1992. This shows that export earnings reached record levels in the second half of 1991. That was due both to buoyant commodity export prices and strong growth in manufactured exports.

The analysis goes on to describe that in much more detail, but the fact of the matter is that the level and value of our manufactured exports have been growing rapidly and continuously for about six years. Certainly, it began from a small base, but the fact that that growth in the value of manufactured exports has continued so strongly whilst we have been in recession shows that the policies that have been in place during that time have made a direct contribution to that outcome. Our exports are rising quite strongly. Our commodity exports, which have not been doing so well in the last two or three years, are starting to pick up. This is particularly true of wheat; to a limited extent, wool; and it is true of a number of the mineral products as well. Both our commodity exports and our exports of simply processed and complexly processed manufactured goods are rising strongly and can be expected to go on rising strongly.

As well as that, Australia has a very low inflation rate. That is an enormous benefit when trying to design policies which will stimulate economic activity. We now have a lower inflation rate than at any other time over the last two decades. That is of direct benefit in keeping our interest rates down.

Interest rates have fallen by about 10 per cent since they peaked and are now much lower than they were two years ago. It is true, as the honourable member for Forrest said, that they are still somewhat above those overseas levels but there is a very difficult juggling act involved. There may be scope for reducing them a little further but, at the same time, the honourable member should accept that activity in the housing industry, which is particularly influenced by interest rates, is starting to pick up very rapidly.

I was at a function organised by the St George Building Society about a week ago. I was told that its lending in February was the highest it had ever been for any month. Even better than that, not only was it its highest lending ever, but also it was double the figures for its best month ever. In February St George lent $370m. In its previous best month, it had lent $190m. That may be partly because it increased its market share, but it was principally because in its traditional market—New South Wales and the ACT—the demand for funds had grown very strongly.

It is a very encouraging development if growth of that kind is going on. That is, of course, only anecdotal evidence; we will have to wait a month or two to get the comprehensive statistics to be sure that that is a general trend. But if anything approaching that—anything remotely like that—is general, then the Government would have to be fairly careful about further reductions in interest rates for fear of stimulating the housing industry too rapidly. In any case, interest rates are now much lower than they were a couple of years ago—10 percentage points, as I have already said—and that is having an impact, not only on housing but also on small and large business, thus creating the main condition to encourage people to invest further.

In this situation, where we have some desperately serious problems but also some great strengths, the Government has introduced the One Nation statement, which is a particularly well targeted statement. It gives me great delight to say so because I have not always affirmed everything that the Government has done. This statement seems to me to be just about perfect in terms of its sense of direction. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Forrest, described it as a grab bag of ideas. In fact, it is a particularly well thought out and well-targeted strategy aimed at stimulating economic activity, national productivity and growth of employment in the most cost-effective ways. I will give some examples of that.

One of the most important initiatives in the statement was the major increase in funding over the next four years for technical and further education. There cannot be a more important sector at this time for increasing the skills of our work force than TAFEs. It is true that the proportion of students finishing secondary school has gone up from about a third a decade ago to about two-thirds now. That means that there has been a rapid increase in the number of students wanting post-secondary education. Some of them can go on to universities, some of them can go into apprenticeships, but many of them want to go to TAFE. We should be encouraging them to go to the TAFE.

Fortunately, and with great foresight, about two years ago the Government commissioned a report from a team headed by a man named Finn. The Finn report was completed about six months ago. It outlines a strategy for upgrading and extending many areas of technical and further education. In the One Nation statement funds were allocated for implementing the first parts of the Finn report.

Another vital part of the statement concerns the increased allocation for infrastructure. I am delighted that the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) is in the House, because I would like wholeheartedly to congratulate him on his part in achieving this billion dollar increase in infrastructure funding. It is true that in Australia public investment has been falling for about 15 or 20 years. As a proportion of national income it has come down quite substantially.

This initiative starts to reverse that trend. We must do that if we want the productivity of the economy to improve. There is a clear relationship between the level of public investment and private sector investment and productivity. That is logical, because public investment provides the infrastructure, the network of transport and communications and other facilities which are essential for efficient private sector activity.

In this statement about $400m is allocated during the next couple of years for upgrading the rail network and about $600m is allocated for improving roads, in a number of very important ways. Main roads between cities, ring roads around cities and vital transport and road links within cities will be improved. There will also be an increase in black-spot road funding—areas where there have been a number of accidents and where a small amount of additional work will improve the safety of those roads. That is a very important basis for improving the transport system. But, as well, it is a very important stimulus to employment.

That funding is being done in ways which have relatively little impact on imports. One of the great benefits of spending on infrastructure during a recession, and one like the present recession when we have a high current account deficit, is that it is an effective way of improving national efficiency without a substantial leakage to imports. Most of the equipment, all of the employment and all of the materials come from Australia. Therefore, there is not a direct loss to overseas producers through that initiative.

A number of other initiatives in the package also will have a direct impact on the current account as well as on the labour markets here. For example, there are the expansion of Austrade and the increased allocation to the development import finance facility—initiatives which, by the way, were advocated last October in a report of a committee which I chaired. I am very glad to see that ideas prepared by an all-party committee, which were tabled in a report last October, have been taken up.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good report.

—It was a very good report. I thank the Minister. As well there are initiatives in the One Nation package for increased funding on labour market programs and on apprenticeships. Finally, I want to mention one particularly important initiative—the establishment of the Australian Technology Group. The aim of that group is to link public sector research with private sector use. It is quite clear to anyone who has looked at our excellent research that sometimes there has been a failure to link that into manufacturing enterprises in Australia. The Australian Technology Group, based on a similar group now operating in Britain, will create that link and strengthen it. Again, this is something which I have been advocating for about 10 years. I am delighted that at last it has been accepted.

PARA.TAB: I think that those examples show what a well targeted program this is. It is true, as some people have suggested—although not in the Opposition—that it is a very moderate statement. In my view it could responsibly have been larger. However, it was a difficult task for the Government to judge at what level to pitch the package. One has to remember that it is constrained by opinion in financial markets in the business community. But the other side should remember that in November the British Conservative Government brought down an employment statement for #11 billion, or $A25 billion. This is the equivalent, given the respective sizes of the economies, of $A7.5 billion. Therefore, if we had followed the example of the British Conservative Government, we could have had a package that was three times larger.

The Opposition does not like to hear that, but the situations in the two countries are very similar. Britain has 10 per cent unemployment, a current account deficit and is in a relatively strong fiscal position. We could have quite responsibly had a larger statement because of the strength of our fiscal position. I have already said at the beginning of my speech that we have the lowest level of public debt of all but one other Western country.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about the national debt?

—National debt, exactly. Therefore, we have considerable scope for borrowing responsibly in order to pay for a package such as this. That is what the Government decided to do. Of course, the package is also linked with a strategy for moving back into surplus in about four years time—at a time when one could expect the economy to be booming again. It is entirely the responsible thing for government to do to expand its outlays when the economy is depressed and to cut them back when it is booming. That is simply common sense. It is simply responsible countercyclical policy.

PARA.TAB: I would like wholeheartedly to congratulate the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Ministers on their well-judged package. It is good to see that it is so well accepted in the wider community. Of course, it is accepted because people recognise that it will contribute directly to stimulating growth of employment. The future issue is what sort of Budget should be prepared. But that is another story, and I will not go into that tonight. I hope that it is more of the same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am taking advantage of the cognate debate tonight on the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1991-92 and other Appropriation Bills to bring to the attention of the House several issues of great importance to my constituents. They are not necessarily issues that are vital to the day-to-day running of this country, but nonetheless they are of great importance to the people of my electorate of Moore.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to see that the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) is here this evening, because there are a couple of matters that I want to address to him. It comes as no surprise to members of both sides of this House to hear about problems associated with Australia's land transport industries. Rail has generally been recognised as engendering some of the most incredible anomalies, inefficiencies and waste imaginable. I forget how long the Minister has been in this portfolio, but he has had a fair while to deal with them.

The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), in his response to the ministerial statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on Thursday, 27 February, referred to the way in which one section of the railways in Australia—and probably the most disastrous of all—the Victorian railways, is run. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in Victoria it would be cheaper to close down the rail system and give every commuter a small car than it is to try to run the railway. . . We have seen examples of train stations where, although trains do not stop, as many as 26 people man them. We have seen examples of firemen on electric trains.

This is laughable, although in reality it is not quite so funny. The Government in its `One Nation, One Job' statement has as one of its central planks an increased spending on roads and rail. However, not only does the statement fail to go to the heart of the problems inherent in our transport system, but its spending initiatives are actually unfunded. In other words, we cannot afford the $454m earmarked for rail without major reforms to cutbacks on areas of inefficiency and waste in our rail transport system. There is absolutely no mention of real labour market reform in One Nation, which is one of the most fundamental inefficiencies in our rail system today.

PARA.TAB: I have recently been told that the rail industry in Australia is improving. In 1986-87, Westrail, the Government-funded rail organisation in Western Australia, had only an 81 per cent cost recovery on its freight services. Australian National had 86 per cent recovery and State Rail in New South Wales had 83 per cent. Westrail and Australian National have improved their performance substantially. However, the Australian rail industry on the whole is still heavily subsidised by the taxpayer. Some sources say that the Australian rail system has cost taxpayers a staggering $20 billion in the last eight years. Last year it spent $4 billion more than it actually earned.

In the 1990-91 financial year, Westrail estimated it earned about $1.6m in profit for its freight services. For its overall freighting operations, Australian National recorded an operating loss of around $14.7m, which, after considering a series of abnormal items, turned into a profit of $9.7m. The New South Wales rail organisation, known as State Rail, made a huge operating loss of $330m during 1990-91, although there were no particular figures available for its freight operations.

This situation prompts concern when local road transport operators in my electorate have been put out of work owing to radical reductions in charges for rail transport of containers from Perth to Sydney. Freight transferred by rail over this distance travels under the rail systems of Western Australia, South Australia and New South Wales, or Westrail, Australian National and State Rail. Trains carrying cargo from Sydney to Perth are known to carry a heavier registered load than when travelling in the opposite direction from Perth to Sydney, basically because of the volume of goods transported from the east compared with the volume transported from the west.

In order to maximise usage of freightage volume, freight charges for loads being transferred from west to east by rail have historically been lower than the corresponding charges for freighting the other way around. For a long time road transporters have been contracted by removal businesses to carry householder furniture and effects from Western Australia to the east. Recently, Westrail lowered its fee for 100 cubic metres of storage space to $771 for freightage from Perth to Sydney. Local road transporters would normally have charged around $3,000 for 80 cubic metres of space moved from door to door.

As a result of Westrail's slashing its container freight charge, removal businesses are preferring to use rail freightage to reduce their costs. However, householders utilising rail services for their transport can expect their belongings to be loaded and off-loaded approximately four times in a move from Western Australia to the eastern States: once onto the truck transferring the goods to the rail yard; then onto the train; then off the train and onto a truck at the other side; and lastly at the final destination.

There is no doubt that one's furniture would have to withstand a fair bit of punishment and rough handling under these sorts of conditions. One would also not want to be in any great hurry to receive the goods at the other end. This huge difference in price has meant that road transport operators are going to the wall. They simply cannot compete with the taxpayer subsidised rates charged between Perth and Sydney.

Recently, there have been allegations of widespread fraud being committed on taxpayer owned, government managed railways. These allegations were raised in the January edition of Truckin' Life. For the first time in many years, Colin Nicalou, the former administrator of Westrail's Kewdale freight terminal, began in September last year weight checking inbound loads consigned on the east-west rail service.

Truck operators whose vehicles are regularly weight checked have noted the lack of a comparable zeal to chase down underdeclared weight on consignments on the railways system. The fact that checks were commenced last year is an indication that the understating of freight tonnage is a problem. The railways work on an honesty system where forwarders declare the weight of their container loads. However, it appears from the information uncovered by Truckin' Life that forwarders are taking advantage of the lack of checks by the railways to transport greater weights than those which they have paid for. In other words, they are ripping off the taxpayer.

The coalition supports government enterprises being made more competitive and more efficient so that the Australian taxpayers can realise the benefits financially.
