However, competition should occur on a fair and equal footing. We have reason to believe that there are significant barriers to competitive freighting between rail and road that have to be got rid of. Since 1983, the Government has been aware of problems associated with the rail industry, but has not been prepared to make the tough decisions to deal with them.

Rail reform is well overdue and a keystone of Australia's micro-economic reform. It is clear that there has to be a sharing of freight carrying between road and rail for safety as well as environmental reasons. There is tremendous scope for increasing efficiency, which will in turn lower transport costs and be a boost to mining, agriculture and manufacturing export industries. The rail system needs to be run with a more national outlook to get rid of many of the inefficiencies inherent in the current disaggregated State system.

The next coalition government of Australia will ensure that road transport will be a winner in the reform process. Each truck driver can expect to save around $40,000 per year in input taxes. The abolition of wholesale sales taxes and fuel excises, and the introduction of a 15 per cent goods and services tax—which is rebateable for businesses—will give a tremendous boost to transport operators who feel cheated under the Labor Government. Labor has admitted itself that road transport is taxed 3 1/2 times more than any other industry. But this Government has done nothing to change this unfair state of affairs other than to threaten to increase registration charges on top of existing taxes.

Under a coalition government, road funding will not be reduced and all business input taxes will be rebateable. A fair and equitable, simple to administer road user charge will apply. It would only be fair for road users to contribute to road maintenance. Overall, road transport under Fightback would be cheaper.

I now turn to the question of buying Australian. The waste and anomalies that have occurred in the administration of government departments under Labor have been extensively recorded. For instance, we hear about $24,500 being given to the Building Workers Industrial Union for musical theatre work about the labour market; just under $9,000 for a trade union women's cartoon project; and just under $6,000 for the Waterside Workers Federation to conduct writing activities with union members. To refer once more to the rail industry, $2,000 was also given to Chullora railway workers for a song writing project.

The coalition waste watch committee has highlighted a number of these areas of government spending and administration that raise the question: why were Government funds committed to this project, and how could this money during the worst recession in 60 years have been spent in other ways? Some other areas of government spending that could easily be made more accountable simply through a bit of discipline and common sense were recently brought to my attention.

In the worst recession for 60 years—and judging from unemployment figures and business confidence we are still not out of the woods—a number of Australian Government and government business enterprise contracts have gone to overseas interests when they could easily have been given to Australian companies. For example, the Western Australian offices for the Australian Taxation Office recently purchased over 1,000 chairs which were essentially imported from Germany, with upholstery and assembly being the only component of Western Australian manufacturing in the product.

Small business in Australia is the worst casualty of the recession. The number of small business and personal bankruptcies has skyrocketed, with the October-December quarter figure in 1991 being the second highest ever recorded. This figure of 4,352 small businesses and individuals that went broke around Australia was only outdone by the figure for the previous 1991 September quarter of 4,764; this being the largest number for 50 years. In the December quarter, the number of bankruptcies in Western Australia jumped by a huge 37.8 per cent from 447 to 616.

In the example I quoted of 1,000 imported chairs, why were Australian manufacturers not sought to fill the contract? A small business in Western Australia could very well have been saved if locally manufactured chairs had been chosen. To give another example: $250,000 worth of totally imported vinyl wall covering has been ordered for an Australian Taxation Office project. Why was a comparable Australian product not chosen instead?

Telecom recently fitted out an office for directory services in Perth and 450 metres of American fabric was ordered for work station screens at $42 per metre. Australian screen fabrics cost around $15 a metre for wool blended textiles. With the Australian textile industry in its current state, surely it would have been more beneficial for the sake of Australian industry to compromise and support Australian produced materials.

Obviously, where imported goods outclassed the Australian counterpart on price and quality, the decision for choosing an overseas product could be justified. However, when Australian taxpayer funds are being spent on an Australian Government department or government business enterprise, for the sake of Australian industry all efforts should be made to look into buying the comparable Australian product, even if some compromise has to be made.

I want to deal now with a more localised problem in my constituency. It is a problem that has occurred with the younger section of the population in my electorate. No. 2 Flight Air Training Corps Wanneroo has applied for Federal funding to assist in the construction of premises at Landsdale in my electorate. The No. 2 Flight is the largest cadet group of its type in the State and involves about 125 local boys and girls aged from 14 to 18 years. It has been proposed to relocate the Flight Corps to Leederville in the inner suburbs of Perth—a long way from Wanneroo. In fact, this would see the loss of a valuable community service for youth in the Wanneroo area, which is particularly distressing at this time of massive youth unemployment in Western Australia.

Youth unemployed in Western Australia climbed to a shocking 35.5 per cent in February this year from 32.8 per cent in January. During the past five years No. 2 Flight has already raised $70,000 independently for infrastructure development on its Landsdale site. However, this funding is not sufficient to provide adequate premises for the cadets. Facilities include a hangar and meeting and storage rooms. Unfortunately, they are only partially completed and it is unlikely that No. 2 Flight will raise the extra $150,000 needed to complete the works by itself. The problem is, of course, that the Government has not yet made a decision on the approval of funding for the Flight Corps. In fairness to the Minister, he has not made the decision yet, and I can only urge him to support this very valuable community group in the city of Wanneroo.

In November last year a motion was carried by councillors at the Wanneroo City Council meeting, approving the assignment of the lease held at the Western Australia Squadron Air Training Corps No. 2 Flight at Kingsway Reserve. In December the Wanneroo City Council wrote to the Minister advising that a site for the Corps would be made available for lease; however, Federal funding was required to pay for facilities. The No. 2 Flight cadets have recently been told they will no longer be able to meet at a local school where meetings have been held while they wait on news from the Minister. This is a most destabilising situation for the cadets, who have worked so hard in raising money for their group and who are facing the prospect of the flight's uncertain future. The situation is becoming more desperate as time runs out for No. 2 Flight. Indeed, it would be a tragedy if, after this lengthy process, the flight was not successful in being granted assistance, and a valuable community service in Perth's northern suburbs—the second fastest expanding residential area in Australia—was lost to local youth.

I now turn to the question of health care. In my speech during the second reading debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1991-92 in September last year, I brought to the attention of the House a number of constituent cases that told the sorry story of our public health care system and Medicare. The Western Australian Labor health Minister, Keith Wilson, said last year that the Federal general revenue and public hospital funding to Western Australia had declined in per capita terms by about 22 per cent since the introduction of Medicare. Unfortunately, it is the people of Western Australia who ultimately suffer from the declining standard in the provision of health care services in that State.

One of my constituents, Mrs Carol Smart, and her 21-year-old daughter, Sonya, recently experienced first-hand the effects of funding cuts to our public hospitals. On 16 December last year Sonya and her boyfriend were on their way to her Carine home when they were involved in a car accident on Marangaroo Drive. A car pulled out from a stop sign and smashed into the car they were travelling in, writing it off completely.

Both Sonya and her boyfriend were badly shaken and in pain. Sonya had cuts and lacerations to her body and her boyfriend had injured his back. Not knowing the extent of their injuries, they were taken to Wanneroo Hospital accident and emergency section to be checked out. They arrived at about 6.30 p.m., completed the required paperwork and were told by an attendant to wait for medical attention.

For four long hours Sonya and her boyfriend waited. Sonya was in agony. She could not sit down because she was suffering such discomfort and was forced to stand for an unbearable four hours. At approximately 10.30 p.m., having still not received any medical attention, Sonya was taken home by her mother, exhausted and in pain, still not knowing the extent of her injuries. Sonya and her boyfriend, due to the shortage of staff at the hospital, had not even been perfunctorily examined, let alone treated for shock. The next day Sonya and her boyfriend went to a local doctor. Sonya was diagnosed as suffering from severe bruising and her boyfriend was diagnosed as having a strained back and was put on anti-inflammatory medication for four weeks.

I will give the House another case. Local ex-serviceman Harold Atkinson was also on the receiving end of staff shortages in the public hospital system, this time at Royal Perth Hospital, RPH as it is colloquially known. Mr Atkinson has been a voluntary driver for Royal Perth Hospital since 1977 and is presently the President of the Voluntary Drivers Association. Unfortunately, on this occasion Mr Atkinson's good service to the community did not rate in his treatment within the State public health care system. Seventy-nine year old Mr Atkinson had been ill for some time, requiring a blood transfusion every two to four weeks. He is subject to a heart attack at any time.

At 11.45 p.m. on 4 September last year, Mr Atkinson experienced sudden severe chest and neck pains and was taken by ambulance to the accident and emergency section at Royal Perth Hospital. He was given an ECG as well as being X-rayed. He was also given an injection and told to wait. At 3.10 a.m. he was told that a bed was not available for him and he would have to go home and come back to the hospital if his pains returned and worsened.

Fortunately, Mr Atkinson was able to contact his son and be picked up from the hospital by him even though it was 3.45 in the morning. Fortunately, he is alive today to tell the story. Luckily for Sonya Smart, she did not have internal bleeding from her car accident. Luckily, Sonya's boyfriend has not permanently damaged his back. These days it seems as though our public hospital systems are relying more on luck than anything else, and sooner or later that luck will run out.

Finally, I want to talk about another section of my community, a section of the senior citizens community that is experiencing problems with the Government. I refer to the members of that community who are receiving a British pension. Pensioners from the United Kingdom are worse off under the current taxation system and pay more tax on their pension income than do their Australian counterparts. These people feel they are being discriminated against in that they have to cough up the same rates of tax as everyone else on their pensions earned overseas, but are not entitled to a pensioner rebate on their tax.

Local seniors earning a British pension have come to me absolutely outraged at the current system. If they have tax payable over $3,000, they may be subject to provisional tax that was originally intended for business and investors. Some people are having difficultly in meeting these payments and are justifiably angry about the Government's taxation arrangements that came into effect last year. These people may be living off a pension of about $20,000 a year and are being subjected to this misplaced tax that will whittle away their savings.

There is little scope for these people to invest their money and to save for the future. Provisional tax has and will continue to leave them out of pocket before they have even started to count their savings. Under a coalition government the tax-free threshold will be raised to $7,000, and all pensioners will benefit. Pensioners will benefit from the abolition of a compulsory retirement age, an 8 per cent increase in pensions, substantial tax breaks and widened eligibility for the pharmaceutical benefits card. Pensioners can rest assured that under a coalition government they will be compensated for the effect on savings of the introduction of a goods and services tax through a special wealth compensation provision of up to $2,500. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I intend to deal with the Government's strategies for obtaining a strong future for this country, principally in two particular areas, the small business community and trainees and apprentices. This speech tonight allows me to build on and amplify some points I was making earlier this afternoon in the MPI debate on small business—and amplify and expand I will.

PARA.TAB: The One Nation statement is a plan which incites economic recovery and reform. There is no real comparison with the Opposition's Fightback strategy, which it has to be said in this place, and recognised outside it, is the death knell for many small businesses and the creator of so much socioeconomic disparity. We have heard the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and his sidekicks espouse the praises of their supposed glorious Fightback plan, a plan supposedly to rebuild and reward Australians. But in the end one has to ask and, indeed, I ask tonight: which Australians?

The Fightback plan has put the burden of the Public Service restructuring program on the shoulders of the small business community. As I was saying earlier today, all small businesses in Australia would effectively become Tax Office agencies, completing consumption tax collection sheets as they go. The shopkeepers of my electorate will become unpaid clerks for the Tax Office during their own personal time, limited as it is as small business people, or in the GST-imposed quiet periods. In fact, there would actually be a compliance cost to businesses for the honour of collecting this information free of charge for the government.

The Canadians found that the cost of the GST is $9 in every $100 earned. In New Zealand the cost to the business sector is 25 per cent of its turnover. But this is just the initial molestation of the future of small businesses. If we look at the Canadian experience, we can say that the small business community will see quite a few GST-promoted silent moments. A study by the Canadian Federation of Independent Business indicated recently that a survey of 25,362 businesses in Canada found that 70.6 per cent of respondents indicated that the GST had had a negative impact on their businesses. The smallest firms had the most problems, with sales decreasing and costs rising as a direct result of the GST. Most people would think that was enough of a burden for anyone to have to contemplate, for any one group in the community or in the economy to have to bear. But, no, Opposition members are relentless ideologues.

Their next brilliant strategy is to transform the small business community into their own certification agency. As I also said earlier today, each unemployed person would be required to have two written certificates each fortnight from business people to verify that he was seeking work. The mind boggles at the enormity of the resulting generation of paper and work that small business people would have, even in terms of simply turning people away from their shops and enterprises. The Department of Employment, Education and Training has estimated that if we had 500,000 unemployed, a six-minute interview would multiply to 1,824 person years per annum provided by employers at a cost of some $72m each year.

The Opposition's strategy is clearly farcical. Small businesses throughout Australia should heed these warnings. They should indeed heed the terrified calls from across the Tasman. John Morine, a New Zealand accountant, recently stated:

If you and the other 800,000 or so small business proprietors throughout Australia do not succeed in getting the GST removed from the political agenda, you will rue the day you took no action. Act now. Otherwise you may not survive.

SPEECH.PARA: During the MPI debate today, the Opposition had the effrontery to attack the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) and the Government generally on the handling of the small business sector. It backfired badly. I can only come to the conclusion, based on what has happened today and in recent weeks, that the Opposition now knows that what it has so very often described as its own traditional heartland—small business—is about to desert it. Today was a manifestation of some further panic in the Opposition ranks, particularly about Fightback, and particularly on the point of small business policy.

PARA.TAB: By contrast, the One Nation statement acknowledges the important role played by small business in the economy. Small business provides employment creation and innovation, which are two very important components in the overall plan for a more competitive, efficient and fairer nation.

Small business, indeed, must be seen as the seed for future new industries. In order to nurture these important characteristics, the One Nation economic strategy has implemented the following strategies. The first is a substantial increase in capital gains tax relief for small and growing businesses which will increase capital mobility and growth in the sector. There will be an increased capital gains tax free area on the sale for goodwill from 20 per cent to 50 per cent and the extended number of businesses under it.

This strategy is better than a simple, straight rollover for capital gains on goodwill because it will materially affect business people who are looking to sell and to use the proceeds of that tax free area of goodwill to retire on and, therefore, use the proceeds as a type of superannuation. This is a perfect example of this Government knowing and understanding the needs of small business and bringing about reform. Personally, I am very pleased about that because, at the last election, I gave an undertaking to my electorate in writing that I would work for some capital gains tax relief for small business.

The second thing we have done is recognise the impact of the current recession and its ramifications on the cash flow capabilities of small businesses. There will be a three-month extension for the 1991-92 company tax payments for small businesses which will approach the issues raised during the consultations of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) with small business representatives in recent times. This strategy will have an instant impact of reducing uncertainty and promoting further optimism.

Thirdly, there will be no increase in the prescribed minimum superannuation levy for businesses with payrolls of $500,000 or less until 1994-95. Fourthly, the funding support for assisting small to medium enterprises to enter export markets through the export access program has been tripled to $12m. This is a far-sighted program. It is targeted at assisting the small and medium businesses which need this sort of assistance to do what we want them to do; that is, to develop export and international business for a long period ahead. Export access has revealed that small businesses would like to diversify their markets by entering those export markets. In particular, they are well placed to contribute to new areas of export activity in the high value added goods and services area, the very target that this Government has been about for so long.

Another aspect of the statement is the pooled development funds, which will provide longer term equity capital for small and medium sized Australian companies with total assets of less than $30m. The funds are to be used principally for the expansion of existing firms rather than new operations. This is an imaginative approach and it will provide a tax incentive for equity investment in Australian businesses. This support system will be enhanced by the dividends from the funds being tax exempt while the profits will be taxed at a concessional rate of 30 per cent.

We have also, by the introduction of legislation to prevent the unnecessary foreclosure by banks of viable businesses unable to meet debts, sought to have a major impact on the continued survival and revival of small businesses. Banks will be able to claim tax deductions for partial debt write-offs and also for losses on debt for equity swaps which will give firms in difficulty a chance to trade their way out of trouble rather than being prematurely wound up by the banks.

Further to that, we have brought about four initiatives which are designed to improve the tax treatment of depreciation of assets. Of particular benefit is the further acceleration of taxation depreciation deductions for plant and equipment beyond effective life rates of most asset classes. I am sure that, when the small and medium business community examines and compares the two strategies, it will be evident that the One Nation plan is far more equitable and far-sighted and will promote more effectiveness and competitiveness than anything on offer from the Opposition.

I now turn to the strategies set in place by the One Nation plan to protect our skilled workers resource pool. Before I came into this place I was working in industrial relations. During the Liberal-induced recession of the 1980s it was evident to anyone and everyone who worked in the manufacturing industry that what this nation was then doing, in circumstances encouraged by government policy, was throwing thousands of young people onto the scrap heap, giving them a very limited future, and, almost as bad as that human tragedy, making sure that this country would have a labour shortage in the trades and other skilled areas in the years to come.

If we turn our minds back a few years, we see that that was exactly the problem that this Government inherited. It can have all sorts of ramifications; not just in reducing skill in the community, but also in artificially driving up certain wage rates across the economy, with all the attendant flow-on effects of that. In contrast to that, the Prime Minister's One Nation plan is doing something about making sure that our future generations of tradesmen are home grown rather than having to be imported when we are panic stricken upon the sudden realisation that there will be shortages.

This Government will immediately boost the financial assistance for apprenticeships and traineeships by $100m. Importantly, young people—unlike those of a generation ago—will see greater hope for their future. Local employers will receive added incentives to retain or employ apprentices and trainees in addition to those whom they are already employing. This is, of course, a continuing commitment of the Government and carries on from initiatives that were introduced in February aimed at increasing incentives to employers to recruit 9,000 first-year apprentices and 10,000 trainees in 1982, as well as providing a wages subsidy to save some 3,200 second-year apprentices from retrenchment.

Additional measures have been introduced as part of the One Nation plan to stimulate further growth in school training opportunities and to continue to save our young people from the prospect of, individually, a dark future and, collectively, a national want. These additional measures include $49m to continue prevocational training places for presently unemployed people, $5.7m to encourage group training schemes and $11.7m to extend for a further year the existing package in place to assist 7,000 at-risk apprentices and trainees, and the unemployed. This is a perfect example of government intervention in the marketplace, not only for the effect on and welfare of our citizens but also for the future of the country.

Rather than letting the ups and downs of the market throw these 7,000-odd at-risk apprentices and trainees onto the scrap heap in the future, in most cases perhaps never to be picked up, this Government has deliberately designed means of intervening to see our skilled labour force of the future through this torrid period. Tackling unemployment is, of course, a cornerstone of the economic statement. The expansionary policies introduced will maintain this skilled work force for the future and build on it.

The Opposition's Fightback plan is now seen in this place as a sham and, I suspect, outside this place more and more as being well and truly on the nose. How can Opposition members honestly continue to support such a package when the Treasury's analysis has shown that some 70 per cent of Australians—that is, the vast majority of ordinary Australians; people who live in my electorate—will be worse off? When, one has to ask, will the Opposition escape from this self-imposed time capsule, when all it seems to want to provide is a restrictive and backward plan which will increase the disparities between Australians and pull our economy into the backwaters of the international market?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a load of rubbish that was no doubt written in the back rooms of the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). All the empty rhetoric and all the previously proven inaccuracies have been trotted out this evening. What a time for them to come out as we debate the Appropriation Bills, which provide ongoing funding for the business of government in the period ahead. Some of the programs that are included in these Appropriation Bills are to finance the implementation of aspects of the One Nation statement announced recently by the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: This is also an opportunity to debate and review the progress of our nation. Where have we been going now that we have had two years of this current term of Government? Yesterday marked the two-year anniversary of the return of the Labor Government. The class of 1990—those members who were elected to Parliament at the last election—have now had two years in this place. I am sorry to say, as one of those members, that it seems to me that it is very difficult to find anything in Australia that is better as a result of what has happened in those two years.

Like all new members who come into this place, I came with some ambition to be a part of building a better Australia. Sadly, during the first two years we seem to have gone backwards. Labor's report card for this period is particularly bleak: the depression it said it would make sure we would not have and then told us we had to have, record debt, continuing deficits in our trade balances, a million unemployed, social despair everywhere, division and degradation. There is a real attitude of despair in our community as we look towards the future. The only slightly brighter notes perhaps are lower inflation and lower interest rates, but they have been achieved for the wrong reason. Labor has so crushed demand and so crushed optimism that no-one is buying in our country any more.

As an Opposition member, as least I have the satisfaction of knowing that the coalition parties alone have prepared a package and have produced a document which provides a blueprint for the future. They provide Australian people with some real optimism that there still is hope in this once great country of ours.

We have succeeded in capturing the imagination of the Australian people with a Fightback package built on hope and opportunity. The package includes fundamental change to our taxation system and the way in which we administer so many aspects of our country's way of life. It restores incentive to the principal place in encouraging development and encouraging individual initiative. That is so important as we as a country plan for our future.

The future of our country is dependent on the future of individuals and our Australian families. If we can encourage each Australian family and each individual to produce a little more, our country will also benefit. The Fightback package is built around that fundamental theme—that it is necessary to encourage and provide incentives to individuals if our country too is to grow and prosper.

The package has so overwhelmed Labor that it became sufficiently desperate even to dump its own Prime Minister. The man who navigated the Titanic onto the icebergs has been rewarded by being made captain of the ship. The Labor Party wanted change irrespective of the consequences. It dumped the man it had loved for someone it hated. It dumped a sports-loving larrikin—a man of the people—for a rude, arrogant individual detested by most Australians. Not only is he not a sports fan but he cannot tell the difference between soccer and rugby league. The Labor Party has dumped consensus and given way to division. It has dumped the idea of cooperation and replaced it with confrontation.

There have been amazing policy reversals, as if Australia had been enduring these years of pain all to no avail. Labor got it all wrong. It wants to change everything. There will be no Medicare co-payments any more. After cutting depreciation allowances for so many years, they are now to be increased. After increasing wholesale sales tax over the years, suddenly there are to be cuts. This is from the Government that trebled wholesale sales tax collections during its term in office. Now there are to be tax cuts, but only for high income earners, and not for 28 months, and not for four million Australians who earn less than $20,700 a year. This is all from a government that has doubled income tax receipts during its term of office.

The massive deficits that we have before us now are in marked contrast to Labor's demands over the years for fiscal responsibility and budgets with surpluses. Everything seems to have changed. As if to reinforce Labor's apology to the Australian people, we are to have this famous apology payment to Australian families of $125 to those with one child, coming curiously on 2 April, just a few days before the Wills by-election.

The One Nation statement delivered all of these goods. It is a remarkable title, I thought—`One Nation'; `One Nation', coming from the Prime Minister who is seeking to divide our country, to set Australian against Australian. His insults to Australia's friends, his republicanism statements, his degradation of the flag—hardly the kinds of comments that one would expect from a Prime Minister who is endeavouring to encourage an attitude of one nationhood. Indeed, his comments about the Australian flag demonstrate an arrogant disregard for the feelings of Australian people.

Our flag in particular is one of our country's most important symbols. It naturally evokes deep feelings of loyalty from many Australians, and it has been an important element in maintaining the unity and spirit of our nation. The Labor Government has refused several attempts by the coalition parties to enact legislation to protect the Australian flag. The Prime Minister's current outbursts suggest that he cannot be trusted not to get rid of the Australian flag, even without consulting the Australian people. When his predecessors in Labor governments tried to change the national anthem, at least they asked the Australian people to choose the alternative. I call on the Prime Minister to give an undertaking that he will not seek to change the Australian flag without putting the question to the Australian people by way of referendum.

It is quite clear that our Prime Minister, in making his attacks on the flag, on the monarchy, on the British, the Americans, the Japanese and just about anyone else he can find, is endeavouring to deflect attention from his abysmal economic record. Australia has few enough friends in the world as it is, and if this man stays as Prime Minister for too long we will lose what few we have. It is quite obvious that at this time, when Australians are becoming more conscious of the importance of our past, our Prime Minister is trying to rewrite history to support his republicanism campaign.

Ironically, while the Prime Minister denigrates our flag, the Labor Party continues to use it in its logo and masthead designs. However, I think we can expect some changes here, too. The latest edition of the official organ of the Australian Labor Party in South Australia, the Herald, has defaced the design of the Australian flag and has nominated Bob Hawke as the ideal man to be the first President of the republic of Australia. In putting forward Mr Hawke as the ideal nomination, it has listed his qualifications as being a former union leader and champion beer drinker. It is quite clear that in our Prime Minister's approach he has demonstrated to all Australians that they will always have to be vigilant if we want to protect our national institutions. These sorts of things make it clear that the One Nation statement had nothing to do with creating national unity; nor does it endeavour to provide benefits for everyone in Australia.

Despite the maps that the Government is endeavouring to circulate to electors around Australia and all the diagrams showing where the money has been spent, it is quite clear that the basic allocations have been made to Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra; the golden triangle has done well again. Rail funding, road funding and urban development are all, or largely, centred on the capital cities.

It is true that there is the odd throwaway, to try to remember that the rest of Australia is still there. Perth has been granted $20m for sewerage works. I was in Perth recently and this contribution came as a great surprise to the people of Western Australia. It seems that nobody had been asking for it and that nobody knows what it will be spent on.

There was also the classic $20m provided to Townsville to build a new outer harbour and transport infrastructure. It is again a development that no-one has asked for and no-one intends to use. It is true that the Greenvale nickel refinery needs new port facilities, but it wants them built at Halifax Bay. That is clearly the most economically sensible place for those port facilities to be provided. Like so many developments under this Government, spurious environmental grounds are being used to endeavour to block that project, potentially at the expense of almost as many jobs as the new project in Townsville is likely to create.

Let us look at some other proposals in this great spending spree, such as the new airport developments for the cities. Luxurious new terminal buildings are planned for capital cities while country areas will be forced to do without the aerodrome local ownership plan. This Government is speeding up the relinquishment of its responsibilities under this program—responsibilities, I might add, that have been in place for as many as 40 years. These are programs that have been the result of exchanges of correspondence and signed agreements between local government and Federal governments over the years. This Government is walking away from those commitments and is leaving country airports in a parlous position. Many of these airports will be unable to continue to operate as maintenance costs get beyond the capacity of local ratepayers to meet the growing demands. So, at taxpayers' expense, we can have great new developments in the urban areas while country communities that are so vitally dependent upon airport facilities, particularly in times of crisis, are being asked to do without.

Fortunately, the return of the coalition government and its restoration of ALOP will offer new hope. The commitment by the National and Liberal parties to restore a 50 per cent subsidy for essential maintenance work on country airports will recognise the community responsibility we have to serve not just Sydney and Melbourne but also the provincial areas which contribute so much to the economic wealth of our nation.

The One Nation statement is the Government's eighteenth attempt to get it right for Australia; it is its eighteenth economic statement. All the others have sunk without a trace. But this is not really an economic statement; it is a $20 billion unfunded spending binge. No wonder we need extra Appropriation Bills like the ones under debate tonight when we keep spending money that we have not raised.

The Prime Minister has just given some advice to the struggling Australian families who cannot balance their budgets. His advice, given through his own example, is to spend more and earn less. Somehow or other that is supposed to solve both the families' problems and Australia's problems. This kind of approach is clearly doomed to fail.

All this comes at a time when our country is confronted with one million unemployed. When we say it quickly, perhaps we do not appreciate the tragedy that that figure implies. It does not convey the hardship and the personal distress that is associated with every story of unemployment. There are now 262,000 families that have a chief breadwinner who is unemployed. That figure is up 40 per cent in just one year.

There are 218,000 Australian children who live in families where no-one has a job, and 248,000 Australians have been unemployed for more than a year, which is an 88 per cent increase in just 12 months. Half a million children are living in poverty, 75,000 are homeless and an extra 140,000 families a year have been plunged into extended poverty because of this recession.

My electorate of Wide Bay has above the national average unemployment and so I confront these issues every day. The Government has no answer. All it is proposing is to create artificial jobs which last as long as the Government pays the salary; alternatively, it is proposing a whole new range of training schemes. Labor's approach to unemployment seems to be to try to hide the unemployed in schools and TAFE colleges. That was the theme taken up by the chief economist of the Australian Chamber of Commerce, Mr Brent Davies, when he described Labor policies. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It amounts to little more than taking unemployed off the dole queues and hiding them away in schools and TAFE colleges.
Training is, of course, important. If we are going to have a large number of unemployed people, it is better that they should occupy their time learning rather than getting into trouble.

PARA.TAB: Training schemes of themselves do not create jobs. The unemployed are better skilled but still unemployed. These schemes tend to become mere minding schemes for the unemployed. We could provide some kind of meaningful work for these people while they are on the dole to maintain their skills, to help establish and retain their work ethic.

I commend the scheme initiated by the Hervey Bay City Council in my electorate which provides opportunities for unemployed people to do work in its botanical gardens and in other community projects around the city—work which otherwise would not be done but which is the pride of the city and which has given some people the opportunity to continue to maintain their skills and their work ethic.

Australians, though, should not give up; there are many things that could be done to help address our national unemployment crisis. Labor could do things such as abolishing payroll tax—the $5.8 billion disincentive for unemployment, this punishment, this regressive tax that gets higher and tougher for every extra employee. It could get rid of things such as the training guarantee levy, another iniquitous tax which employers have to pay whether they can afford it or not, whether or not one pays income tax. There is a levy on employment. It could abolish the wholesale sales tax, a $9.6 billion ramshackle, inconsistent, inequitable, ill-targeted, complicated tax, a secret consumption tax which has been trebled by the ALP in Government. It is a tax which offers no compensation for the poor; it is taxation by stealth. Some of it falls on business. The wholesale sales tax hampers economic productivity. It taxes exports, an extra load for those who would contribute to our national profitability. Labor could abolish the fuel excise, a $6.6 billion tax on isolation, a sectional tax on provincial Australia.

This tax has helped to create the tyranny of distance, has been multiplied seven times by Labor in government and is totally inappropriate for a vast country such as Australia. It disadvantages travel to the shops, to the doctor, to the schools, to the sports grounds and is a burden on all regional industry. It is a tax on decentralisation in a country that should be encouraging it. It is a tax on exports because most of our exports also come from rural areas. Indeed, if we were to abolish the fuel excise alone, Queensland rail would save $20m, probably enough to fund the rail improvements proposed in the One Nation statement.

Indeed, if the Labor Government had not abolished the coalition's infrastructure plan which was in place at the time we left government last, most of these projects being talked about today would have been completed. There are many other aspects of this program which merely reflect this Government's bankruptcy in ideas. The One Nation, the `One Banana', the `One Job', statement adopts a patch-up bandaid solution typical of ALP solutions to problems.

We need a radical new approach, a fight back for Australia that creates real jobs in productive industry and lasting employment that can contribute continually to our national profitability. This is the future for Australia. This Government is tired. On its second birthday it deserves to be taken away to rest. Its failed policies have failed Australia. We need a change. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the Appropriation Bills is certainly a wide ranging one, and I intend to range very widely myself. As the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) is in the chair and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Johns) is at the table it is remiss of me to say this in this House, but I think we really have turned the corner. I noticed that on our back bench six or seven months ago everyone seemed downhearted and depressed because we seemed to have lost our way. Now I cannot find anybody on this side of the House who did not vote for the Prime Minister, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), in the challenge. It is quite remarkable.

PARA.TAB: As somebody who is retiring at the next election, I can take a very objective view of the parliamentary scene. I quite firmly believe that the stocks of the Government have gone up considerably since the honourable member for Blaxland became the Prime Minister. I think we will be in government for a very long time. The thing about the Prime Minister is that he is prepared to bite the bullet. I think the One Nation statement that he has put forward is very progressive and has been very well received. Particularly in my electorate, people who barely acknowledged me in the past are now stopping to have a bit of a yarn. There is no doubt that the stocks have turned.

As I said earlier, my remarks will be quite wide ranging. One of the things that I want to highlight—I want to speak constructively about this and I hope that we can remedy it—is very near and dear to my heart. That is the problem of the reduction of funding to the disabled. I think the disabled people are a group that we do not acknowledge, and I do not think we give them the credit that they richly deserve for the way that many of them, despite some of their horrific injuries, have tried to get back into the work force. I think we should be extending more money and more finance to these people rather than reducing it, particularly as those of us who are able-bodied worry about job prospects and other matters affecting our everyday existence. These are genuine concerns. We are all aware that there is a problem.

I feel certain that the Prime Minister's economic statement will soon make inroads into these problems faced by the able-bodied unemployed in this great country. I wonder, however, how many of us sitting in this chamber ever look beyond the political bickering and point scoring on the backs of the unemployed to spare a thought for a group of people—the number of which is ever-increasing all over this country—who dare not even think of job prospects. If the able-bodied people are battling to find employment, what hope do the disabled have?

There are those amongst us who may say that the disabled have attracted a great deal of attention during the reign of the Labor Government. It would be correct to say that the lot of the disabled has improved under this Government. One has only to look at the disability reform package to note the positive changes that have been made recently to assist the disabled community. Change is fine. However, funding does not always march hand in hand with the implementation of improvements. Disabled clients in my electorate suffer the most when funding is not readily available for their employment, support accommodation and respite care.

Rearing children is an important responsibility. Rearing a disabled child or caring for a disabled adult is an even greater responsibility and is much more demanding. To care for a disabled person is a mammoth task indeed. It places a burden of increased responsibility on all members of the family unit. By these words it is not my intention to indicate that such families would cast the burden of love and care aside. Those carers whom I come in contact with are totally dedicated. Their dedication to caring does not mean that we, the able-bodied, should walk away and let them get on with it. On the contrary, it behoves us in our own way to assist these families in whatever way we possibly can.

There is a lady named Annie Lockwood in the city of Whyalla. I never think of the disabled without being reminded of the community fundraising Annie has done, in particular for the Disabled Peoples International branch at Whyalla. I pay tribute to Annie Lockwood. She keeps up her community work even though she recently celebrated her ninety-second birthday. I wish that we had more Annie Lockwoods. I pay tribute to a great lady.

It is with sadness that I greet the news of per capita fiscal liquidisation of funding from the Commonwealth to the States. I can only assume that the decision makers have no inkling of what it means to these families to withdraw even one position for respite care or to run around closing support accommodation without making proper provision for these people within the community. I can tell honourable members what it means. It means that parents of disabled children and adults will be under such extreme stress that we will witness marriage breakdowns, nervous breakdowns, collapse, possibly even fatalities, because there are not enough respite care or support accommodation places in South Australia. Inadequate funding for these two services in particular will cost us more as a community when the carer is no longer around to care. Government agencies will then have the total responsibility for such disabled clients.

What does per capita fiscal liquidisation have to do with the disabled? Let me tell honourable members what it has to do with the disabled, particularly carers of the disabled in South Australia. When I speak of funding, I refer to Commonwealth funds, not the respective State funded programs or, indeed, State complementary components of various programs. In the 1980s a policy decision was taken that service development should be more community based with an emphasis on integrating disabled clients into the community. I have no argument with that. It is my belief that the disabled should be allowed to live their life within the community as independently as is possible without endangering their safety or their own well-being. We the able bodied within the community can learn many lessons of life from the disabled.

SPEECH.PARA: On a personal basis, when I see how valiantly some of them cope with problems which seem insurmountable, I feel truly humble. They have a capacity for laughter in the face of adversity, a joy for living and a will to survive which is second to none.

PARA.TAB: I understand the claim is that South Australia was overfunded during the 1980s. It spent the money wisely, so it must have needed what it received. In South Australia, services were developed using the funding for capital assets and equipment. Recurrent funding for salaries of support workers was provided separately. Pursuing the policy of integration, the South Australian State office initiated the development of large numbers of small community based services, blowing out the recurrent funding commitment for staff; whereas I understand that other State offices committed relatively larger proportions of their funding to large capital items which did not attract the same expansion of support worker funding.

South Australia needed to develop its program based on support workers, as it has a vast isolated country and rural areas, mainly in my electorate of Grey, now covering 91 per cent of the State. The equalisation principle now being adopted is based on the recurrent funding. The mechanism was introduced in the late 1980s and involved a reduction in the allocation to South Australia with increases to Queensland and Victoria. Prior to this, the national allocation of funds for new services had been made on the basis of the proportion of population in each State. The estimated time span on the new equalisation policy was on that basis to take place over 20 to 25 years. In 1988-89, the reduction to the State of South Australia was $639,000. In 1990-91, the rate of reduction in South Australia was increased with the intention of reaching equalisation within five years.

In the 1990-91 Budget, a four-year funding program was announced. Funding was allocated on the basis of places and services for individuals. Under the increased rate of reduction, places allocated to South Australia each year with 1991-92 funding allocation for the whole State are as follows: attendant care scheme, one place, $22,238; accommodation support, one place, $22,464; respite care, 13 places, $37,050; employment, 28 places, $145,152; other services, $110,334. This makes the total funding for the whole State of South Australia $337,238 from a national allocation of $15,940,000—how appalling!

Funding for the specified services just named cannot be interchanged. There is not enough accommodation support funding to establish the infrastructure for a new service which is desperately needed in my electorate. Instead, we have the scandalous situation of one place being added to an existing service each year—not for my electorate, but for the whole of South Australia. The situation is totally unacceptable. Demand is increasing and funding decreasing. My State colleagues inform me that there is at the present time in South Australia an unmet demand for at least 200 supported accommodation places for intellectually disabled clients alone.

I am aware that when the Commonwealth-State disability agreement is implemented there will be a transition payment of almost $5m made to the State of South Australia which should assist the State Government in addressing unmet demand for services—other than employment, which will remain the responsibility of the Commonwealth. But what have my constituents to do in the meantime? This may be too little, too late, on respite and supported accommodation care.

I am pleased to say that my electorate of Grey is provided with excellent service agencies for disabled employment through the auspices of the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service, which does an excellent job. However, once again its role is being diminished at the present time due to the lack of referrals, again because we are waiting on the assessment panels of the new disability support pension to come into full operation.

I feel that the Department and its clientele would have been better served had the decision-makers seen it as more of a priority to get the assessment panels into place rather than concentrate their agencies and energies on making sure that South Australia's disabled people were divested of funding 20 years sooner than they should have been. I find the contraction of the time element for per capita fiscal equalisation appalling, as no thought has been given to those who are suffering and whose suffering will be exacerbated because of such mindless decisions.

Last, but certainly not least, I would like to ask the Minister whether the disability services award is a key factor in the delay in the implementation of the Commonwealth-State disability agreement and, consequently, the release of the additional $5m transition funds. If this is the case, then I urge my colleague the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) to take immediate steps to rectify the situation by reaching agreement with the States in relation to recurrent funding to meet the cost of this award over and above the additional funding for the award which has already been agreed to.

I cannot emphasise enough to the House that the situation for disabled clients and their parents in my electorate of Grey in relation to respite care and supported accommodation is critical and most urgent. I trust that the responsible Minister takes on board what I have said on this important issue and remedies the situation as speedily as possible. In saying that, I certainly hope that this is not seen as just hot air and that my colleagues will take on board this terrible anomaly and try to rectify the situation.

On a more pleasing note, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am delighted that you are in the chair—and I will be gracious enough to give some credit to the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) also—because as former members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, we were very forthright in trying to bring forward a national rail system. I am delighted that we were all part of that report Rail: Five Systems—One Solution, which basically brought about the formation of the National Rail Corporation. I think that that was brought about through the bipartisan and genuine work that we did on that Committee. I am delighted. That is one of the great things that this Government is bringing into being.

The One Nation package announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 26 February this year is a visionary, positive statement which will have enormous benefits for Australia well into the future. I am particularly pleased with the announced spending on rail and road upgrading. There is a $1.1 billion package to renovate the Australian interstate rail network and to employ more people to build and fix up roads to lift Australia out of recession. It is extremely heartening that the statement sets out a two-year program that will boost road spending by just over $600m by June 1994 and rail spending by just under $500m. About 70 per cent of that spending will be in the coming financial year.

Despite its smaller size, the rail program is the more ambitious of the two. In just two years, it proposes to fill the main gaps in Australia's standard gauge network, improve track standards enough to slice at least an hour and a half off Melbourne-Sydney freight times, and guarantee reliable delivery. One of the things that our Committee found was that people wanted reliability of delivery and wanted to know that when they ordered that service goods would be delivered on time. I am delighted that, through discussion with the rail unions, it seems that this positive step will most certainly take place.

The rail plan includes $115m to build a standard gauge rail link between Melbourne and Adelaide. This would complete the standard gauge network linking Australia's five main cities, enabling the new National Rail Corporation to send freight and passenger trains from capital to capital uninterrupted. The link would turn Melbourne into the hub of the NRC network, with east-west freight trains and the Indian Pacific tourist trains destined to pass through the city. It would, however, leave headaches for the Victorian railways in western Victoria which would have links to several broad gauge links, such as the Portland line, cut off.

On the subject of that massive spending on rail, one of the things I am delighted about is the upgrading of the Port Augusta railway workshops. Three and a half million dollars will be spent on the upgrading of the Port Augusta workshops. This modernisation will mean an upgraded locomotive shop to allow its effective utilisation as an overhaul facility; modern maintenance/manufacturing and materials handling equipment; and an ecological waste management system.

Railway workers at Port Augusta have been very dedicated to making their workshops equal to the standard of any railway workshop in Australia and they have been very cooperative in regard to the changes that are taking place. I also hope that the concrete sleeper works at Port Augusta will get a large part of the sleepering for the new system.

I am also delighted that Whyalla, where I live, will get a tremendous spin-off from this. The Federal Government's decision to upgrade the interstate railway network could bring major benefits to Whyalla. I welcome the announcement of the $465m investment program which includes completion of the standard gauge network from Brisbane to Perth. I will, of course, be encouraging BHP to tender for the contract to supply the railway lines for this project. Many honourable members might not be aware that the hard-headed rail that is manufactured at Whyalla is the best in the world and is exported all over the world. Canada, which has the most modern railway in the world, is one of the recipients of that hard-headed rail.

Again, I pay tremendous tribute to the trade union movement at Whyalla which, under the leadership of the Secretary of the Combined Unions Council, Doug Elkins, has done a superb job. I think industrial relations in Whyalla at the present time are second to none. The superb cooperation between employers and employees in Whyalla certainly makes it the standard bearer for industrial relations within Australia. I can see that it is nearly time to wind up my comments. I am delighted with the One Nation statement. I believe that we have a Prime Minister who is full of vision and who has really been prepared to grasp the nettle. I can see him being Prime Minister of this country for a long time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) for his generous remarks.
—And the man in the chair.

—Yes, I also thank the Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). I might turn to the issue of railways a bit later, albeit very briefly. Tonight I want to say something about the broader issue of the apparent determination of honourable members on both sides of the House to internationalise the Australian economy. It is noticeable that throughout the years when the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was the Treasurer, for the little time he was a backbencher, and now as the Prime Minister he has constantly come back to the need for the Australian economy to be internationalised. In terms of those words, it is a sentiment that I concur with very strongly—although anybody can say anything. The question is not what people say. As parents often tell their children, `Do not judge people by what they say. Judge people by what they do'.

PARA.TAB: The interesting thing about the Australian economy, its capacity to internationalise and its success in internationalising is that over the last 30 years or so we have seen a very rapid growth in international trade, particularly in manufacturing trade. One of the constant features of OECD countries—honourable members should not worry about the boasts of Australian politicians—is that their exports have continued to grow as a proportion of their GDP. Exports have become more and more important to the creation of wealth in each of the OECD countries.

I am sorry to say that the notable and sole exception amongst OECD countries is our own country. Perhaps one would not expect very much of some honourable members opposite who have decided that all politics will be about between now and the next election is a constant and semi-deranged abuse of their political opponents, rather than a consideration of any real issue. However, I wonder whether in the years ahead people might wish to contemplate why it is that in 1961-62 exports made up 13.6 per cent of Australia's GDP, whereas in 1990-91 the figure was 13.8 per cent. From 1961-62 to 1990-91 there was some fluctuation, but a very slight fluctuation, in exports as a proportion of our GDP. As a matter of fact, if one were to make a party political point, exports hit a high point under the Fraser Government. In 1979-80, at the time of the resources boom, exports reached 15.1 per cent of GDP. Basically, they have hovered at around 13 or 13 1/2 per cent.

Therefore, the fact is that in a world with rapidly growing trade we, as a country, have not really succeeded in getting hold of very much of that trade. That is something that as a country we ought to reflect on more than we do. By the way, those countries that have a bigger proportion of international trade than Australia—and that is every single OECD country, even New Zealand—have had a growth in their exports as a proportion of GDP, and most of those countries have GSTs. You might be interested to hear that, Mr Deputy Speaker. Australia does not have a GST because it is one of those many issues that we play out here in a rather political sense which—when looked at from the objective position of how the totality of the world economy works—is seen to be a commonsense and ordinary thing to do.

As I said, in that context the Government talks a lot about the need to internationalise the Australian economy. That is the rhetoric. One needs to look at what the Government is actually doing in order to achieve that. As other honourable members said earlier during the evening, we had the One Nation statement two or three weeks ago. The interesting thing—as every honourable member would know—is that if a member goes out into his or her electorate and asks people about the One Nation statement they will not have a clue what the member is talking about. People would not know of one single initiative in the One Nation statement because the Government, instead of trying to promote its One Nation statement, has run off with a whole range of different diversions.

Of course, people on the other side of the House are going to argue, as did the honourable member for Grey, that spending money on a range of different projects is a good thing. It is rather like my announcing a policy that I will spend $100 billion or so building a bridge across the Tasman and saying, `If we had a bridge instead of having to use ships, it would facilitate trans-Tasman trade. We would be able to get a truck across the Tasman in the course of a day instead of three days. That would cost $100 billion. Isn't that terrific? Doesn't it look glittering?'. The reality, of course, is that it has to be paid for. The cost-benefits of building a bridge across the Tasman, as anybody would know—no-one would disagree with this—never add up.

The question to be asked about the One Nation statement is whether it adds up, whether all these glittering things that apparently the Government can do with taxpayers' money can ever be financed. I suppose we need to look at what others say rather than depend on the words of politicians, because they have become somewhat discredited. It is interesting to note three different comments which have been made about the One Nation statement. The first and the latest came today when the Syntec organisation estimated that the funding challenge that One Nation will leave Australia with—something like $18 billion in unfunded spending commitments over the next four years—will increase interest rates by 4 per cent, which will cost the business community around $8 billion. That increase in interest rates is caused by the fact that this extra spending is unfunded and therefore the Government has to go out into financial markets and compete with the private sector to borrow money. That forces up interest rates and that means that other borrowers, such as small, medium sized and large businesses, all have to pay more for that money. That is where the $8 billion bill comes from.

They get accelerated depreciation in the One Nation statement. Remember how the Labor Party took away the Fraser Government's 5 : 3 depreciation provisions and the investment allowance? We are halfway back again with some accelerated depreciation provisions which are entirely unfunded. They will probably be worth a bit over $1 billion to the business community. That is fine; they are a good thing. On the face of it, to reduce business costs, to reduce the cost of capital by $1 billion is a good thing, but where is the $1 billion coming from? We can see that it comes from an $8 billion increase in business costs over the four-year period.

So the whole issue of the funding of politicians' promises is a very fundamental one. I come first to the honourable member for Grey from South Australia, who said, `We have had years of the State Government going around funding wonderful projects'. There is the REMM development, this massive new Myer shopping centre funded by a State Government instrumentality. But now the bills are coming in. When my children are my age, as taxpayers, they will still be paying their share of a $200m a year bill left because the Labor Government in South Australia went on a spending spree and did not have a clue where the money was going to come from. Of course, that is the record of Labor in Victoria and it is the record of Labor in Western Australia. It is always the way with the Labor Party. It is not really interested in what it sees as the cold calculations of accountants and economists; it is just interested in big spending programs. Remember the Whitlam Government, and we have seen it here with the Hawke-Keating Government.

Part of this program is designed to kick-start the economy in the very short term, and to ensure that it is internationalised—and I do not want to lose track of that important theme. Will it help kick-start the economy and do the one social thing that we really want done in this country, that is, create jobs to try to compensate for the terrible things that have been done to people over the last couple of years through the recession that we had to have? If we are going to create jobs, if the One Nation statement is going to have an impact on jobs, it has to have an impact on investment. Jobs do not come from nowhere; jobs come as a result of investment. Who would know? I suppose the people in business would know because they are the people who are going to do the investing.

The Australian Chamber of Manufactures, a very important organisation representing manufacturers in Australia, as its name suggests, recently did a survey of its members, which was published yesterday. In it, 92 per cent of its members said that the Government's One Nation statement would not encourage them to increase investment; 3 per cent said that it would; and the balance, which is 5 per cent, were undecided. That, I would have thought, is a fairly savage indictment of the One Nation statement, which is little more than a game being played by politicians trying to get re-elected, and who will fail in the process. As the Confederation of Australian Industry said the other day:

SPEECH.PARA: The economic statement is not about economic management. It is political from top to bottom . . . One ultimately becomes weary of trying to fit all of the pieces into a coherent recovery strategy.

Those are not the words of politicians; that is not the Opposition trying to be horrid about the Labor Party or something like that. They are simply the words of the people who really matter in this exercise—the business people who are going to make the investment decisions that are going to create jobs. There is no sign of that at all.

PARA.TAB: In terms of getting the economy going again, we are making very little progress in this country. As people will see during the rest of this year—although, of course, there will be fluctuations in a whole range of different economic indicators—there will not be any substantial recovery and there will not be any improvement in the ghastly level of unemployment that we have in Australia.

Once all the ballyhoo of the Prime Minister's quite extraordinary statements about national symbols and so on passes, as inevitably it will, people will turn around, the dust will begin to settle, and they will say, `Now do we have a sparkling rich new economy with the unemployed back in jobs?'. They will see that they have not. When they see that there has been a lot of rhetoric but nothing has been achieved by it, I am afraid that as far as the Labor Party is concerned the new sense of disillusionment will be very profound, and justifiably so.

The present Prime Minister has been strong on this rhetoric about internationalising the Australian economy. As we can see from the statistics on exports as a proportion of our GDP, it has been all talk but little success. The present Prime Minister has argued through his time in government that one of the ways—and this is correct—to internationalise the Australian economy is to wind back tariffs progressively over a period.I just want to remind the House of some of the things he said. On 12 March 1991, which was the date of the sixteenth consecutive economic statement by the Hawke-Keating Government, when the now Prime Minister was Treasurer, just over 12 months ago, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Within this decade, Australia will have renounced once and for all the fallacious doctrine that prosperity can be found behind the insular wall of protection.
In the same speech he said:
The package of measures announced today—
that is, on 12 March 1991—
ends forever Australia's sorry association with the tariff as a device for Australia's industrial development.

He went on the following day with a range of very similar remarks. The point is that we on this side of the House made those difficult decisions by the Government possible by giving them our support. If we had taken the politically expedient position and opposed those decisions, they would simply have become politically impossible for the Labor Party. History will judge that to be a very important contribution that we have also made whilst in opposition to the process of internationalising the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: The trouble is that we heard today that, owing to a by-election in Victoria and for no other intellectual reason, the present Prime Minister has decided to change his mind. He does not believe these things any more. Suddenly he has decided that he is not really in favour of tariff reductions at all and believes that industries can be saved by just maintaining tariffs.

I suppose he has really more than one motive for that. He has the obvious political motive, but he has another motive, which is that, while he has been moving to lower tariffs, he has done nothing to improve the capacity of those firms that used to be assisted by tariffs to compete more successfully without tariffs. Clearly, if one just takes away tariffs without doing anything else to improve the capacity of business to compete, one will create a catastrophe. That is exactly what we have in Australia today.

When we talk about having a similar program for the reduction of tariffs to that of the Government—at least until today; we do not know what its program is now—we talk about reducing tariffs to negligible levels by the year 2000. That is defined as somewhere in the vicinity of 5 per cent, which is identical to the Government's program. However, when we talk about that we are not just talking about throwing Australian industry out into the cold without any additional assistance to compensate for the abolition of tariffs. We provide a range of very substantial benefits to compensate for them. Those benefits are identified in our Fightback program.

I will take the opportunity of reminding honourable members on the other side of the House of what the Treasury said in its document about the benefits that would flow to Australian industries as a result of the introduction of the Fightback program. The rhetoric from the Labor Party is that when the coalition comes to power, everything will go wrong—there will be massive unemployment; there will be earthquakes and heavy rain; people will be washed away in floods; the world will just become a nightmare. I suppose it is the rhetoric one would expect from a government in a desperate position.

Interestingly enough, what the Treasury says is dramatically different. For example, the Treasury estimates that the impact of the introduction of the Fightback program will be to reduce the cost of agriculture in Australia by over $1 billion; that is over $8,000 for every farm in Australia. Manufacturers, who are the principal beneficiaries of tariffs, get something like $3 1/2 billion in tariff assistance at the moment. When the Government's program is completed in 1997 that figure will be significantly lower, but just at the moment it is $3 1/2 billion. Under the Fightback program, according to the Treasury's figures, the coalition provides a benefit of over $5.3 billion to manufacturing industries through the abolition of the range of taxes it abolishes, and also as a result of the introduction of the GST.

Taking individual industries, we have heard a lot about the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. The Prime Minister says that in Wills the textiles, clothing and footwear industry has no future. We point out that the Treasury's own figures show that the Fightback program would reduce costs in the textile industry by $177m and in the clothing and footwear industry by $139m. So the list goes on.

The previous speaker talked about rail transport. What is the impact of the Government's program on rail transport? It is increasing spending by $450m or so, totally unfunded. We have said that we will continue infrastructure spending in so far as it can be funded. That is obviously something that we will have to look at when the time comes, because it will depend on the level of growth in the economy over the next two or three years. According to the Treasury document, the Fightback program alone—a program which is fully funded, as I think everyone now concedes—provides railways with a benefit of $306m and road transport with a benefit of $1.1 billion.

Those on the other side of the House claim that tourism will be affected by the Fightback program, and what a disaster it is going to be, yet air transport gets a $376m benefit and restaurants, hotels and clubs—the absolute essence of tourism—get a $318m benefit. Finally, defence industries—which may have something of a future in Australia if we are creative about them—get a $90m benefit.

I began with the internationalising of our economy, and that is where I will finish. The Treasury estimates that we will reduce the cost of exports by $1.9 billion, or 3 per cent. That is internationalising the economy; that is making Australia more productive. People who support the Labor Party oppose all of those things. They oppose all of those benefits. They want to retain that higher cost structure and reduce tariffs, which is what they are doing rather than what they are saying. If they pump up costs and reduce tariffs, they will smash Australian industry. If tariffs and costs are reduced, Australian industry will thrive and our economy will finally internationalise. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing government appropriations, which is really a debate about government expenditure. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), was quite right to identify the nature of government expenditure as well as the level of that expenditure as being the two critical elements that we should debate in appropriations.

PARA.TAB: I want to take up both of those points. In terms of the level of expenditure that any government should undertake at a given time, a government has to ask itself whether it needs to stimulate the private sector activity in an economy at any time or whether it needs to withdraw its expenditure in order to give room for expansion of the private sector. In those booming years from 1986 through to the early part of 1990 the Commonwealth Government took the view that it would run surpluses in its own Budget and, therefore, by implication, withdraw expenditure from the economy, move aside and let the private sector do its best to stimulate employment and wealth. I think we made a correct decision there.

However, of more recent days with a troubled economy it was imperative—in fact, the business sector asked this of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) earlier this year—that the Government should re-enter the fray and begin to stimulate activity in the Australian economy. Honourable members should forget the ideology. A government needs to think through the role which the public sector needs to play. At the moment it is imperative that the public sector re-enter the fray to stimulate the Australian economy.

That is the whole purpose of the One Nation package. The beauty of it politically is that the Prime Minister, when he travelled around Australia during his consultations, was asked by the private sector, the business community, to spend public money in a way that would assist the private sector and give
