SPEECH.PARA: the greatest possibility for job creation, which is the goal of both sides of this House. The level of government expenditure needs to remain as a response to a level of activity in the economy.

PARA.TAB: In the second instance, how the money is spent counts most. That is quite right. We are not aiming to do as previous governments did 10 years or 15 years ago: take people off dole queues by putting them on the roads, digging holes and filling them in again. That is not a very sensible way to spend public money. I want to contrast some of the sensible ways that we now wish to spend some of the public money through the One Nation package, moneys which are being appropriated in these Appropriation Bills.

First of all, let me point to the alternative, the punitive view that the Opposition has in its Fightback package of the public sector's role in stimulating the economy. The Opposition is seeking—I am quoting from the figures in the Fightback document—to reduce the general purpose payments to the States and the Territories by 5 per cent in its first years of government. This would involve cuts of about $756m on 1991-92 figures. In other words, the Opposition would be withdrawing funding from the States that would be used for capital programs, public money that would be used to stimulate the sorts of infrastructure investments that we are deciding to make through the One Nation statement which the private sector requested of us. Through the Fightback package, the Opposition is moving in precisely the opposite direction to cut $756m from those general purpose payments to the States.

In addition, there is a particular program that the Opposition has some desire to destroy. It is seeking to abolish the better cities program. This would mean a cut of around $56m in 1991-92 programs. I refer to the better cities program per se and its objective. The Opposition faces the problem that if it were to make such severe cuts in general purpose payments it would add to the stringency under which State governments have travailed under our regime. The Commonwealth has actually been very tough on the States over a number of years. I think we had to be; we had to pull their expenditure into line. But there is a time when one stops. When the flesh has been cut from the bone one needs to make an intelligent decision about what are minimum levels of expenditure that States and Territories undertake on behalf of the Commonwealth, essentially because we fund a number of these things.

The cuts that the Opposition would make need to be assessed against the background of significant real declines in these general purpose payments that were made through the latter half of the 1980s. In fact, general purpose assistance fell by 15 per cent in real terms between 1985-86 and 1991-92. By contrast, the Commonwealth, this Government, has agreed to a guarantee for general revenue assistance, in real terms, for the three-year period 1991-92 to 1993-94. This reflects a judgment that it is now time to consolidate the sorts of constraints that we placed on the States but not to cut further. There is a time to cut and there is a time to build.

TALK.START.PARA: —A time for laughter; a time for crying.
—I like it. Nevertheless, this is the time to build; it is time to build the one nation. We have done the hard yakka.
—You sound like Solomon.
—Do I? With his wisdom? Is there a female equivalent to Solomon? There must be.
—The Book of Ecclesiastes.

—Good, I have not read it—perhaps I will do so later. I shall contrast the levels of government expenditure. The Government has stepped in when the private sector has been unable to cope. The Government withdrew in the mid-1980s when the private sector was able to cope. In fact, we threw the private sector into it holus-bolus. We said, `Get on with it—stimulate the advancement of the nation'. Of course, the private sector made some gross errors.

PARA.TAB: The better cities program is an example of the recent stimulus from the public sector. There comes a time when governments need to place some basic hard infrastructure in some of our cities. For instance, we will stimulate the Queensland State Government's desire to build a rail line from the city of Brisbane to the Gold Coast. We will do that because it is sensible planning; it is something that the State Government desires to do as a way of directing massive suburban growth between the southern suburbs of Brisbane and the Gold Coast, which are two of the fastest growing local government areas in the nation. The Government has promised to spend a fairly modest amount of money there to help the State Government stimulate the building of a rail line.

The whole purpose of building that rail line is to try to get some substitution. There is a need to get some of the commuters off the road and the freeways, on which they drive for an hour and a quarter or so between the Gold Coast and the city of Brisbane, onto a rail system. Planners have noted that by laying down a dedicate transport route—specifically a rail line—one can have an enormous impact on the shape of suburbs.

We are not throwing money at the State Government. In return for Commonwealth money, the Government is asking for the following things: that when the State Government builds the rail system it considers how it houses people close to the line and the sorts of densities that are desirable; that it gives us an estimation of the number of people who will travel by the rail system; and that it gives us an estimation of the substitution of mode of travel—that is, the number of people it believes will get out of the car and into the rail system.

There are flow-on effects in terms of a better use of land and a better use of infrastructure such as water reticulation, sewerage systems and so on, kerbing and guttering, the sealing of local roads—all those bits of expenditure that governments would normally undertake. We can actually ensure that in time there are enormous savings for the public sector by planning that area between Brisbane and the Gold Coast more intelligently. In other words, a little bit of expenditure at a time when sensible people have agreed that the public sector should re-enter the fray can produce returns that any investor would be proud of. The public sector will be returned many millions of dollars because we will not need to build enormous water reticulation systems and sewerage systems, and we will not need to lay down as many roads per taxpayer, per householder, as we might otherwise have done.

The better cities program, introduced at the perfect time, produces a return to the public sector, a return in lower taxes—a decent investment, a sensible investment if taken at the right time and at the right levels. We are making other sorts of investments through the better cities program. For instance, it is well known that the number of people who reside in our inner cities has been declining for many years, mainly because the size of families is declining. Whereas once there was a mother, a father and two or three children living in a house close to the city, there are perhaps one or two persons remaining in the same house.

So we have a very valuable stock of housing situated close to existing services which is well serviced by means of water reticulation, electricity, public transport and so on, but underutilised. Again, a fairly modest amount of public sector expenditure through the better cities program will produce returns by ensuring that we get some renewal of housing—medium density housing—that will place more people around those areas so there is a return to the schools, a use of the parks, more people paying taxes for the use of water and sewerage, more people jumping on the train to commute and more people using the local swimming pool. The whole business will flow. In other words, there will be a return to what is a sensible investment.

The Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Jim Soorley, has been a wonderful advocate for renewal in the inner north-eastern suburbs. He has persuaded the Goss Government to ensure that the better cities program stopped at the inner north-eastern suburbs of Brisbane and that we funded his project. This means that we can now also look at the big picture of a contiguous set of four or five suburbs from which, for instance, the Coca-Cola factory has indicated that it will move to the outer suburbs at some stage, leaving vacant a number of hectares of space for which we can find a better purpose. There are houses that are coming pretty close to a time when they need to be renewed. There are some public facilities, like the RNA showgrounds, which are pretty well underutilised and which with a certain amount of thinking and stimulus can be better used to produce a return on the capital, the public's investment in that land.

So Jim Soorley and the local communities whom he is consulting in conjunction with the Commonwealth Government are intent on ensuring that about $30m will be spent over about five years in this area, meaning that we will get an enormous influx of people to the area, we will get a better use of its roads, and we should be able to build a light rail system to assist people to commute from new medium density dwellings to the city. Generally speaking, we will revive that area. That is not something that is done lightly or easily; it is usually a very expensive process. It is a process about which the private sector is often very nervous, but the private sector welcomes this particular stimulus, this Commonwealth involvement in better cities, because it will end up making a quid out of it; it will end up helping us to build the medium density houses that we desire. That is the extent of the remarks that I wish to make tonight. There is a time to spend and there is a time to make intelligent public expenditure.
Debate interrupted.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:
That the House do now adjourn.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Before I call the honourable member for Parkes, for those who like me, because of duty, have been prevented from watching the cricket, I inform honourable members of the wonderful result that Pakistan has won the cricket match by 22 runs.

TALK.START.PARA: —As you said, Mr Deputy Speaker, only minutes ago the World Cup one-day cricket tournament concluded. I would like to add my congratulations to Pakistan, the winning team. After a very slow start to the competition, it finished very strongly. I believe it was the best team in the competition overall. I commiserate with the losing finalists, England, and indeed the other two semi-finalists, New Zealand and South Africa. I was very sorry, of course, that Australia missed out.

PARA.TAB: The main purpose of my rising tonight is to alert the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) of the need for farmers to have adequate access to restocking finance. In response to calls by me and other members of the coalition, the Minister recently accepted the necessity of providing $10.8m in 1991-92 and $6m in 1992-93 for crop planting assistance. This, of course, gives a 75 per cent interest subsidy on commercial carry-on loans for farmers in dire financial circumstances to allow them to get their crops in this year, particularly wheat crops.

The plight of these farmers is, in large part, due to the ridiculous high interest rate policy that the Government has been running in recent years and the removal or emasculation of many of the concessions or assistance measures to farmers, such as income equalisation deposits.

The Minister, I think, has finally recognised that, if the wheat does not go in this year, not only will the farmers not benefit but also Australia, because of the lost export income, will not benefit. In other words, if there is no crop, there will be no income. Many farmers will be sold up; their expertise will be lost from the land. This is particularly tragic in the case of young families on farms. Having accepted that principle, I believe the same principle applies with the need for restocking finance. If pastoralists are not running sheep on their property, they have no income.

In western New South Wales and over the borders in significant areas of Queensland and South Australia a raging drought is still going on. Even though the drought may have broken in eastern New South Wales, many areas in the west have only had an inch or so of rain this year. The sheep numbers are down because of that drought and because of the wool crisis over the last year or so. Sheep numbers have plunged and those sheep left in the paddocks are often too weak to be brought to the sheds to be shorn or to be crutched.

I will read out some figures that have been phoned in to me from the Louth, Tilpa, Cobar and Wanaaring areas of New South Wales. One property only has 1,500 sheep left out of 5,700; another has 1,300 left out of 10,000; another has only 300 left out of 14,000; and another has 1,100 left out of 11,000; another has lost 30,000 sheep out of 50,000; another has only 5,000 left out of 7,000; another has 4,000 out of 8,000; another has 1,200 left out of 9,800; and another has 2,000 left out of 14,000 sheep. There are, I am sure, worse examples around; however, those examples show to what extent the numbers have plunged.

I remind the Federal Government that it took a decision in April 1989 to remove drought from the national disaster relief arrangements; in other words, no Federal assistance is now available to people in this position. When the drought policy review task force reported in May last year, it strongly recommended that assistance be given in such circumstances. We are now well into 1992 and there still has been no proper government response to this report. The Government must act and at least expand funding through part B of the rural adjustment scheme, as it has with crop planting.

Many pastoralists are financially destitute and the mental stress they are suffering is horrific, particularly for their families. I think the only comfort they are getting at the moment is that their situation is not of their own making and that many of their neighbours are in a similar plight. They are even pulling their children out of schools because they cannot afford the fees. I believe the Government has let them down badly. It has crucified them with the ridiculous economic policies it has pursued. At the very least, it should redress the balance a little by providing restocking finance as soon as it is needed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Within the context of the continuing debate, both within this House and in the wider community, about the proposals to integrate repatriation hospitals into the State hospital system an important element has been ignored, or not really taken into full consideration, by some parties. It is that the broader communities around these repatriation hospitals at the moment have very limited access to the services provided by repatriation hospitals, but with integration they will gain much better use of the excellent facilities that exist within repatriation hospitals.

PARA.TAB: I draw particular attention to the excellent services provided at the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital, an outstanding institution in the electorate of Moreton which I have the honour to represent in this House. Community access to this hospital was raised with me recently by one of my own constituents who had the opportunity to be a community patient at Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital. He wrote to me wishing to express his very strong support for Greenslopes hospital because of the quality of service he received there, and his support for repatriation hospitals being integrated into the State hospital system because of the expansion of services that that would entail for the broader community.

I draw the attention of the House to the letter that this constituent of mine, Mr Frank O'Connor, a resident of Nicholson Street in Greenslopes, wrote to me because it indicates one of the benefits and very positive elements that will flow to general community patients from the integration of repatriation hospitals.

Mr O'Connor is not a war veteran. He is an older gentleman who would not normally get access to Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital unless there was some difficulty elsewhere. That was the problem for him: he would have had to wait several months to get treatment elsewhere for his condition. His GP referred him to Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital and he got treatment the very next week. He received excellent treatment at Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital—as I know he would, because it has an outstanding reputation for the provision of excellent service to war veterans and to the broader community in the limited capacity that it works in that area. I will read into Hansard the letter that Mr O'Connor has written to the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital, which he has sent me a copy of. It says:
It is with pleasure that I write this letter of appreciation following on my recent operation and treatment in Ward Six (6) of your Hospital.

From the time of my arrival in Ward Six until departure I cannot speak highly enough of the kindness, friendship and help that I received from all members of your Staff. I am sure that these qualities which were shown to me helped in no small way to make my period in your Hospital as pleasant as possible.

Whilst I know that to mention names invariably means that someone's name is accidentally omitted, may I start off by thanking the Sister in Charge, all Sisters and Nursing Staff of Ward Six. They will always be remembered by me for their kindness throughout my period in the Ward, particularly on the late afternoon and evening of Wednesday 26th February when I was in severe pain following on my operation.
To Dr O'Connor and his Medical Staff one cannot thank enough.
I would like to extend thanks to the Staff in the Waiting section prior to me being wheeled into the Anaesthetic Room. Their encouragement helped in no small way a very nervous patient.

SPEECH.PARA: Frank O'Connor's letter indicates a very important part of the dimension of the debate about the integration of repatriation hospitals into the State system. They provide an excellent service for their patients. I think the broader community needs to get access to these hospitals. I am delighted at the prospect of the residents of the suburbs of Greenslopes and Tarragindi having access to that hospital. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw two matters to the attention of the House. On the adjournment debate on Thursday, 26 February I raised a number of issues regarding war veterans and their poor treatment by the Government. The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) and the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) believe that I mentioned these issues unnecessarily and they disagreed with me. The sacrifices of these war veterans should be respected by this Parliament. We should have a one-minute silence on Armistice Day, there should be more than a handful of Government members at the War Memorial on Armistice Day and, above all, this institution which has sent our people to war should respect their sacrifices.

PARA.TAB: The other matter I wish to raise relates to the Kalgoorlie Press. The general editor is the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell).

TALK.START.PARA: —Going to buy shares, are you, Frank?

—Yes, I am going to buy shares in it. I congratulate the honourable member for Kalgoorlie on his newest publication, The Beginning of the End, which is certainly worth while. It is about the MFP. It is certainly the beginning of the end of South Australia if South Australians think that it is going to work there. It is a major failure in the making. It is about a twenty-first century city on a mangrove swamp. And that is what it will do—it will disappear into the swamp. I am sorry the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) is not here to hear this. I am sure that he will sink with it.

PARA.TAB: The MFP ignores a couple of basic facts as far as commercial reality is concerned. It has nothing to do with customers, supplies or financiers. It is all about the Government putting money into a mangrove swamp. It is all expressed very well in the honourable member for Kalgoorlie's publication which I recommend to the House as virtually compulsory reading. I congratulate him again.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I want to say something about the divisive effect of the Opposition's 15 per cent goods and services tax on Australian families and, if time permits, on Australian small business. In essence, the goods and services tax would function to shift the tax burden from higher income earners to lower income earners. No amount of obfuscation, figure juggling, literature distribution or confused presentation can disguise that fact. It is very simple and Australian families understand it. They understand that any proposal to impose a 15 per cent tax on the food they put in their mouths and on the clothes they put on their backs will substantially add to their cost of living. Most of all, this tax will hit families on incomes of $20,000 per year and less. I say to those opposite that, no matter how they twist and turn and no matter how they try to wriggle, struggling Australian families are seeing through the proposal. They are seeing through the fanfare and the razzamatazz that went along with the presentation of the Opposition's package last year.

PARA.TAB: I also want to mention the bleating of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) more recently. When anybody focuses upon the unfairness and the harshness of the goods and services tax and how it will split the Australian community and starts to expose the deceit that is the Fightback package, they cry foul. They say that it should not be done and that we are trying to divert the argument.

Let me say to our friends opposite that far from diverting the argument, we are going to direct the discussion more and more at the unfairness, the inequity, the divisiveness of what they are about. No matter how hard they try, they are not going to pull the wool over the eyes of the Australian people, particularly Australian families on incomes of less than $20,000 a year.

I want to refer to figures I have had taken out which go to the costs to a family of supplies from the baker, the butcher, the fruiterer-greengrocer and the milk vendor. These figures come from the Australian Commissioner of Taxation. They are based on Australian income tax rulings. They have been extrapolated to accommodate an Australian family of two adults with two children under 16. In arriving at the taxable income of people in those employment categories, the Taxation Commissioner for the year ended June 1990 attributed the use of own stock for a baker at the rate of $178 per adult and $89 per child.

If we multiply those figures for two adults and two children we come to these expenditure figures: on bakery products, $534; on butchery sales, $1,244; on supplies from the fruiterer-greengrocer, $1,956; on purchases from the grocer, $3,914; and on purchases from the milk vendor, $534. That is a total annual outlay of $8,182. If we add to that the 15 per cent GST, $1,226, we have a total of $9,408. In other words, that family of four will be required to pay out an additional $1,226 in goods and services tax. The Taxation Commissioner tells us that 50 per cent of all families have an average income of less than $20,000.

Under phase one of the Opposition's tax scale there will be a reduction in income tax for that category of $814. The effect of that is that that family will be $412 a year worse off; in other words, $8 per week worse off. No amount of misrepresentation, no amount of confusion, no amount of marketing by the Opposition can move away from the very basic fact that those families—50 per cent of Australian families—are going to be worse off.

We turn to what is happening to small business. Small business will have the burden imposed upon it of collecting the goods and services tax, and that burden is equivalent to about 2 per cent on sales after net profit. So that is a major reduction for many sole traders in their net rate of profit. But on top of that, incorporated small businesses—and many of them would not be paying payroll tax—will be slugged with an increase in the company tax rate from 39c in the dollar to 42c in the dollar. It does not matter how one goes around it, looks at it and tries to present it, families on incomes of $20,000 a year are going to be considerably worse off. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The empty and hollow threat of the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) to take the fight up to the Opposition on the GST is hardly likely to leave us quivering with fear when his own leader, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), refuses to debate the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) on this very issue at this time of the Wills by-election. So if the honourable member for Shortland is really genuine about his threat to debate the GST package to the last person standing, we will call it on—we most certainly will. Let us have the two leaders of the respective sides of politics convince the people of Wills, which will be the best and most accurate guide to how people are thinking.

PARA.TAB: But if the threat to debate this issue with the Opposition leaves us unmoved, so does the absurd claim by the honourable member for Shortland that people on an income of $20,000 or less will be worse off under the Fightback package. The audacity of a member of the Government to stand up, having participated in the One Nation package, which expressly excludes anybody on $20,700 and below from any tax cuts—

TALK.START.PARA: —For years.

—For years. Such a person will not obtain a tax cut under this Government in the foreseeable future. Remember that those earning less than $20,700 a year amount to almost half the Australian adult population—more than four million taxpayers. So how dare the honourable member for Shortland stand up and say that the Fightback package ignores those earning under $20,000, when, in fact, we will reduce the personal income tax rate from 20 to 16.2 per cent. There is already a massive reduction in the personal income tax rate for those earning below $20,700.

PARA.TAB: Why has this Government turned its back on low income earners? Simply because during the 1980s it became the party for the pampered, the rich, the mates, big business, big unions and big bureaucracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new class.

—The new class. Kim Beazley Snr was reported many times since he first said some years ago that, when he joined the Labor Party in the 1940s, it comprised the cream of the working class; when he left in the 1970s, from the parliamentary scene at least, it comprised the dregs of the middle class.

PARA.TAB: Under the coalition's Fightback package, income earners of less than $20,000 receive a doubling of family allowances. The threshold for taxation is lifted from $5,400 to $7,000. There is an immediate extra $1,600 tax free income. Fuel for the family car will be cheaper under the GST. It will average $11.40 per week. Moreover, we will abolish wholesale sales tax—and over half the items in a supermarket attract wholesale sales tax. It is a lie for anybody to say that the cost of living will increase by 15 per cent in the supermarket. On our conservative estimates, the one-off effect on the CPI will be 4.4 per cent. The Government's own Treasury document—that mammoth collection of overtime of so many public servants—estimates the impact on the CPI at 3.9 per cent. So how can the honourable member for Shortland claim that the cost of living for people will go up by 15 per cent? We will abolish the wholesale sales tax, fuel excise and payroll tax. Consequently, the impact on prices in the supermarket will be 4.4 per cent at worst.

With regard to payroll tax, the Government can talk all it likes about assisting people of any income bracket—$20,700 or below especially—but it is no good unless they have jobs. The abolition of payroll tax is the single best way by which anybody can bring about greater employment. A tax on a tax is a terrible disincentive to employment, and so we will abolish it.

There is hardly a small business in Australia that does not enthusiastically welcome the Fightback package. Those in small business know a hundred things about GST, but let me seize on the three most important ones. Firstly, we will abolish wholesale sales tax; secondly, the reporting conditions will be minimal—probably a reporting period of two months or six times a year on a one-page taxation form; and, thirdly, small business men and women will get a cash flow from the time they sell the goods until the time of remittance.

I challenge those opposite to name a small, medium or large business organisation that opposes the GST. The Fightback package is a comprehensive package bringing together different strands of economic policy to assist low income earners which the Government has abandoned. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Information from the Australian Securities Commission indicates that a new publication in Bundaberg called the Guardian newspaper, under the guise of the Guardian Publication (Qld) Pty Ltd, ACN 051 159 641, was incorporated in Queensland on 22 February 1991 by Australian Companies Pty Ltd, 614 Stanley Street, Woolloongabba. Its principal activity was, and still is, a shelf company. Its original directors were Matthew James Neibling and Joel Kingsley Topping, both of 23 Siemon Street, Toowong. Neibling was born at Mackay on 11 March 1968. Topping was born at Brisbane on 13 March 1953. Neibling and Topping were appointed and ceased to be directors on the same day—that is, 22 February 1991. TALK.START.PARA: —In the brief time available to me, I wish to highlight the record of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on employment, or rather unemployment. We must realise that 262,000 Australian families have the chief breadwinner unemployed now. That figure has risen 40 per cent in a year. In 236,000 Australian families nobody has a job at all—representing a rise of 40 per cent in that group in a year. Further, 218,000 Australian children live in a family where no-one has a job at all. That figure is also up 40 per cent in a year. As well, 248,000 Australians have been unemployed for more than a year, which is an 88 per cent increase in just 12 months. Altogether we have a million people unemployed in this country. It is a sorry situation in country towns, particularly as one sees small businesses closing when driving down the main streets. There are no jobs to be had.

PARA.TAB: The Government should remove the taxes on business to allow them to earn a bit of profit so that they can afford to employ people. That is what the coalition has done with its GST package. It is going to remove $20,000m of taxes—sales tax, payroll tax, fuel excise tax and other taxes—so that real jobs can be created in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 2 January 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What progress has been made on the development of a national registration system for agricultural and veterinary chemicals following the endorsement of such a system by the Australian Agricultural Council at its meeting of 2 August 1991.
(2) When is the system expected to be operating.
(3) Will the system be funded by (a) the Government, (b) the agricultural and veterinary chemicals industry or (c) a combination of both.
(4) If the agricultural and veterinary chemicals industry is to fund the system, will this be through (a) a re-registration fee, (b) an application fee or (c) a sales levy.
(5) If the Government proposes a form of industry funding other than those referred to in part (4), (a) what form will it take and (b) how will it be collected.
(6) If fees are to be applied, at what dollar value will they be set.

(7) Is it proposed to review the status of existing chemicals; if so, (a) how will the review be conducted, (b) what powers will be exercised by those conducting the review and (c) what factors will be taken into account when assessing State-registered chemicals.
(8) Has the agricultural and veterinary chemicals industry been consulted in the development of the system; if so, to what extent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Considerable progress has been made in the development of a national registration scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals. With State cooperation, progress has included the establishment of revised efficacy review procedures, agreement of a product compliance and surveillance program, the development of a national computer database, and an off-label approval program. Phasing in of registration activities at the national level has already commenced while the writing of draft legislation is well advanced. Progress to date was reported to the February 1992 meeting of Australian Agricultural Council.
(2) The national scheme is expected to be introduced on 1 July, 1992.

(3) The Government has agreed that costs associated with the national registration scheme will be cost recovered from the agricultural and veterinary chemicals industry, initially at a level of 50% and rising to 100% over 4 years.

(4) and (5) The Government is yet to take a final decision on how charges will be applied. However a combination of re-registration fee, application fee and a sales levy is being considered in consultation with industry.
(6) The exact level of fees for the range of services and product assessment activities undertaken through the national registration scheme are yet to be determined.

(7) The review of existing chemicals is due to commence in 1993. The procedures to be followed in conducting the review have not yet been decided but it is anticipated that priority chemicals for review would be determined by the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council in cooperation with health, environmental and agricultural authorities. A program of consultation with community organisations and the chemicals industry is also likely.

It is anticipated that the powers of the national registration body will be such that new information can be requested and products can be removed from the market if considered unacceptable by modern day standards.
Nearly all State-registered chemicals have been assessed at some time. Individual State registered products will be considered when determining overall priorities.

(8) There has been extensive consultation with the agricultural and veterinary chemicals industry on all matters relating to future national registration arrangements. There has also been consultation with consumer and environmental lobby groups and the National Farmers Federation.

NSW7
VIC7
QLD7
SA4
WA4

NT1

States/NT have responsibility for receiving and initially assessing proposals. Assessment of proposals is in process and four States are currently engaged in joint assessment with the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: Did an accident occur during service by Qantas of an RAAF Boeing 707; if so, (a) what are the circumstances of the accident, (b) was the aircraft fitted for in-flight fuelling, (c) is the aircraft repairable; if so, at what cost and in what time scale; if not, what replacement arrangements are in train, (d) what are the remaining RAAF Boeing 707 assets in service and (e) what is the impact of the accident on the operational effectiveness of the RAAF's FA/18 force.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: Yes.

(a) During scheduled maintenance at QANTAS Engineering Facility Mascot on 10 January 1992, a RAAF B707 sustained damage while being lowered from supporting jacks to its undercarriage following a functional check of the landing gear.

A technical misjudgment and lack of communications between the supervisor and the jack operators resulted in overloading and subsequent failure of the aircraft's rear jacking point. The aircraft fell approximately 42 inches sustaining damage to the right hand wing and engine cowls, jacking points and fuselage, galley door and tail section. There were no injuries to personnel and the aircraft was subsequently recovered without further incident.

An internal investigation was conducted by QANTAS and disciplinary action taken with the persons directly involved with the lowering operation. Administrative and technical action has been taken by QANTAS to ensure this type of accident does not recur.

(b) Yes. The B707 involved had been modified for air to air refuelling (AAR). A20-627 was the second aircraft to be completed in the four aircraft AAR program and was delivered to the RAAF in March 1991. The AAR system was not damaged in the incident.

(c) Yes. The aircraft will be repaired by QANTAS in accordance with Boeing approved repair procedures. The work will take approximately 25,000 man hours or 16 weeks, at a cost of about $A1.5m. Repair work is proceeding with an estimated completion date of 11 May 1992.

(d) The RAAF B707 fleet comprises five aircraft, four multi-role tanker/transports and one transport only. Discounting the damaged aircraft at QANTAS, the RAAF currently house two tankers and one transport B707 available for operational tasking. The remaining aircraft is undergoing AAR modification at Tullamarine and is scheduled for delivery in May.
(e) Rescheduling of some operational tasks and changes to planned maintenance schedules have helped reduce the impact of the accident on RAAF B707 operations.

The crash of A20-103 last year and the continued tanker modification program have contributed to a reduction in aircraft availability for both tanker and transport roles. These have had a minor adverse impact on F/A-18 receiver training.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 26 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: Will full Medicare rebates be made available to all women who undertake mammographic screening; if not, why is this form of preventive medicine being treated differently from other forms which are fully rebatable.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Medicare rebates are payable for diagnostic mammography, that is, where a woman has been referred by a doctor because she has symptoms or indications of malignancy in the breast which require investigation, or if a woman has a family or personal history of breast cancer. However, if a woman requests a mammogram and she does not fit into this category then the service is considered to be health screening which does not attract Medicare benefits.

The Government is extremely concerned about the incidence of breast cancer in Australia and has committed $64 million over three years to the introduction of a National Program for the Early Detection of Breast Cancer. The program is to be implemented over five years from the time each State and Territory government agrees to participate. After initial Commonwealth funding of an expansion phase, the program will be cost shared with the States. Queensland agreed to join the National Program in May 1991.

The decision to establish a national program was based on an evaluation of Australian pilot projects and the findings of a number of overseas studies. The conclusions of the evaluation were that screening mammography can be effective in reducing breast cancer mortality rates if provided through a dedicated, accredited program which is accessible to women in the appropriate age range and includes assessment and referral for treatment. The current system of ad hoc provision of diagnostic mammography is not geared to successfully screen those women in the population most likely to benefit.

For this reason the national program will establish a national network of screening and assessment services which will be dedicated to the purpose of screening mammography and which will be required to meet stringent standards to achieve accreditation. The program is being progressively implemented over five years and all women over 40 years of age will be eligible at little or no direct cost.

Under the provisions of Section 19(5) of the Health Insurance Act Medicare benefits are not generally payable for health screening services, that is, medical examinations or tests that are not reasonably required for the management of the medical condition of the patient.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 27 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: Is it a fact that $23.5 million is being paid to pensioners who reside in Yugoslavia; if so, (a) what is the basis of the payments, (b) is there a reciprocal agreement, (c) are the recipients Australian citizens, (d) what are the criteria for receiving the payments, (e) is there a similar situation with respect to other countries; if so, what are the details and (f) is there any evidence that some of the recipients are freelance soldiers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Department of Social Security currently pays pensions totalling $21.5m pa to Australian pensioners residing in Yugoslavia, Croatia and Slovenia;
(a) payments are made under the overseas portability provisions of the Social Security Act 1991. In February 1992 there were 2092 pensioners in Yugoslavia, 682 in Croatia and 86 in Slovenia;
(b) no;
(c) the Department does not keep records of whether its clients are Australian citizens as citizenship in itself is not a qualification requirement;

(d) pensioners in Yugoslavia must continue to satisfy the basic qualification rules for the type of pension they are receiving. However, the rate of pension may be lower than the rate payable to them if they had remained in Australia. This is because from 1986 Australia began to pay many of its pensions overseas at a proportional rate depending on how long the pensioner had lived in Australia during working life. The income and assets tests continue to apply;
(e) the rules for portability of Australian pensions are the same for all countries unless there is a Social Security Agreement with a particular country which changes those rules;
(f) no evidence of this kind is available to the Department.
